Translation:
The explosion of a car in the Italian city of Milan in May 2023 is still causing a stir in local online circles (1.2). Users claim that it was an electric car. The video of the car in flames is shared primarily among critics of electromobility. However, important information is left out.
Assessment: The recording shows an explosion of oxygen cylinders in a delivery truck. Numerous media reported about it. According to the fire department in Milan, it was not an electric car, but one with a combustion engine.
Verification: The fire occurred on May 11, 2023 in downtown Milan on Via Pier Lombardo (3). There is a tweet from the Italian fire department (4) and several media reports (5,6,7,8,9) about the incident. Contrary to claims on social media, it was also reported on German television (10). All media outlets unanimously reported that there were several explosions in a delivery truck loaded with oxygen cylinders.
The Italian daily newspaper “Il Fatto Quotidiano” (11) says: “First the van's engine caught fire, then more than ten explosions were heard, two of which were very violent. “The explosion that occurred today in Milan, which also affected several floors of a building on the corner of Via Pier Lombardo and Via Vasari, was due to a defect in the delivery truck that was transporting a dozen oxygen cylinders and containers.”
According to reports (5), the burning vehicle belonged to a transport company from the Novara region. The driver said in an interview that the fire started in the engine and he tried in vain to fight the flames with his hands.
The news agencies APA (12) and AFP (13) also wrote about the incident. There is no indication anywhere that it could have been an electric car.
The car model cannot be seen in the video itself. Several APA inquiries to the police in Milan, the fire department in Milan and the transport company in Novara remained unanswered until the fact check was published. However, the Milan fire department confirmed to the AFP news agency (14) that the van that was on fire was not an electric vehicle.
The Polish fact-checkers from “Fakenews.pl” (15) were also able to obtain a statement from the fire department in Milan through an Italian journalist, which also announced that it was a car with a combustion engine.

Une vidéo partagée plusieurs milliers de fois sur Facebook mi-mars prétend montrer le président ukrainien Volodymyr Zelensky et sa femme Olena Zelenska chanter ensemble. C’est faux: il s’agit d’une reprise de la chanson “Endless Love” par la chanteuse britannique Connie Talbot et l’un des membres du groupe de rock Boyce Avenue, Alejandro Manzano.
Un moment “plus fort que les Bombes”, s’émeut cet internaute, qui partage la vidéo d’un homme et d’une femme en train de chanter ensemble. “Le président ukrainien chante avec son épouse”, poursuit l’auteur de la publication belge, relayée plus de 500 fois depuis le 18 mars 2022.
“J’espère qu’il pourra continuer à résister”, commente une internaute, en référence à la guerre en cours en Ukraine.
La même vidéo a été partagée plus de 8 000 fois en France depuis le 12 mars avec l’affirmation qu’il s’agit d’une “chanson pour la paix chantée par le président d’Ukraine et sa femme”. Elle a également été relayée avec une affirmation similaire en anglais et vérifiée par l’AFP dans cette langue.
Mais une recherche inversée de vidéo grâce à l’outil InVid – voir ici comment procéder – renvoie vers de nombreux articles en plusieurs langues (1,2,3,4) démentant que les deux interprètes soient le président Volodymyr Zelensky et son épouse.
La vidéo s’avère être une reprise du titre de 1981 “Endless Love”, chanté à l’origine par Diana Ross et Lionel Richie. Dans les publications que nous vérifions, la chanson est interprétée par la chanteuse britannique Connie Talbot et le chanteur du groupe de pop rock américain Boyce Avenue, Alejandro Manzano.
La vidéo a été publiée sur le 20 février 2022 sur la chaîne Youtube de Boyce Avenue et sur la page Facebook du groupe, plusieurs jours avant l’invasion de l’Ukraine par la Russie le 24 février.
Elle a également été relayée sur la chaîne Youtube de Connie Talbot le 2 mars 2022.
Si Connie Talbot et Alejandro Manzano présentent quelques ressemblances avec le président ukrainien et sa femme, il ne s’agit donc pas des mêmes personnes. Ci-dessous une comparaison des quatre personnes.
Depuis le début de la guerre en Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky est régulièrement la cible d’affirmations trompeuses, voire erronées, vérifiées par l’AFP ici, ici ou encore ici. Olena Zelenska a également fait l’objet de fausses affirmations, notamment avec une photo, vérifiée par l’AFP, prétendant la montrer à Nice pendant la guerre.
Ancien comique et star de la télé dans son pays, Volodymyr Zelensky s’est affirmé en chef de guerre depuis l’invasion russe de l’Ukraine. Sa détermination à rester à Kiev malgré le conflit lui a rendu une popularité en baisse depuis son élection en 2019.
Lundi 28 mars, plus d’un mois après le début de l’invasion russe, les autorités ukrainiennes s’inquiétaient de l’aggravation de la situation dans le port assiégé de Marioupol, à la veille de pourparlers entre négociateurs russes et ukrainiens à Istanbul.
D’après un bilan de la mairie mi-mars, plus de 2.000 civils ont été tués à Marioupol depuis le début de l’invasion russe de l’Ukraine.
Translation:
A video shared several thousand times on Facebook in mid-March purports to show Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his wife Olena Zelenska singing together. This is false: it is a cover of the song “Endless Love” by the British singer Connie Talbot and one of the members of the rock group Boyce Avenue, Alejandro Manzano.
A moment “stronger than the Bombs”, is moved by this Internet user, who shares the video of a man and a woman singing together. “The Ukrainian president sings with his wife,” continues the author of the Belgian publication, relayed more than 500 times since March 18, 2022.
“I hope he can continue to resist,” comments one Internet user, referring to the ongoing war in Ukraine.
The same video has been shared more than 8,000 times in France since March 12 with the claim that it is a “song for peace sung by the president of Ukraine and his wife”. It was also relayed with a similar claim in English and verified by AFP in that language.
But a reverse video search using the InVid tool – see here how to do it – returns numerous articles in several languages ​​(1,2,3,4) denying that the two interpreters are President Volodymyr Zelensky and his wife.
The video turns out to be a cover of the 1981 song “Endless Love”, originally sung by Diana Ross and Lionel Richie. In the publications we check, the song is performed by British singer Connie Talbot and the singer of the American pop rock band Boyce Avenue, Alejandro Manzano.
The video was posted on Boyce Avenue's YouTube channel and the group's Facebook page on February 20, 2022, several days before Russia's invasion of Ukraine on February 24.
It was also relayed on Connie Talbot's Youtube channel on March 2, 2022.
If Connie Talbot and Alejandro Manzano have some similarities with the Ukrainian president and his wife, they are not the same people. Below is a comparison of the four people.
Since the start of the war in Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky has regularly been the target of misleading, even erroneous, assertions, verified by AFP here, here and here. Olena Zelenska has also been the subject of false claims, notably with a photo, verified by AFP, claiming to show her in Nice during the war.
A former comedian and TV star in his country, Volodymyr Zelensky has asserted himself as a warlord since the Russian invasion of Ukraine. His determination to stay in kyiv despite the conflict has given him declining popularity since his election in 2019.
Monday March 28, more than a month after the start of the Russian invasion, Ukrainian authorities were concerned about the worsening situation in the besieged port of Mariupol, on the eve of talks between Russian and Ukrainian negotiators in Istanbul .
According to a report from the town hall in mid-March, more than 2,000 civilians have been killed in Mariupol since the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Rosyjska machina dezinformacji po raz kolejny używa starych materiałów, by udowodnić, że teraz w Ukrainie giną polscy żołnierze. I znów te obrazy są rozpowszechniane w polskiej sieci.
W sieci pojawiła się kolejna odsłona fałszywego przekazu prokremlowskiej dezinformacji o ginących w Ukrainie polskich żołnierzach-najemnikach. W rosyjskich mediach społecznościowych opublikowano zdjęcie kilkunastu polskich żołnierzy, którzy asystują przy pięciu trumnach przykrytych flagami Polski. Fotografię wykonano na płycie lotniska – w oddali widać samolot oraz hangary.
Zdjęcie opublikowało między innymi telegramowe konto, które regularnie zamieszcza materiały pokazujące martwych ukraińskich żołnierzy. Teraz do opublikowanego kadru użytkownik konta dołączył komentarz wskazujący, że na fotografii widać martwych najemników z Polski, którzy właśnie zginęli w Ukrainie.
Zdjęcie z Telegrama szybko trafiło na różne rosyjskie strony, np. Anna-news.info, gdzie zilustrowano nim artykuł “Polacy chcą zniszczyć Rosję”. Jego przedruk trafił do polskiej sieci – został przetłumaczony i opublikowany na stronie Gloria.tv.
Fotografia pojawiła się także na polskim Twitterze, gdzie na jednym z kont opublikowano je 12 lutego 2023 roku. “Uroczysty powrót polskiego mięsa armatniego z [tu wstawiono flagę Ukrainy]. Ciekawe, dlaczego nie pokazują tego żadne media?” – napisał użytkownik w komentarzu. Część internautów uwierzyła, że zdjęcie pokazuje powrót ciał poległych w Ukrainie Polaków. Pod zdjęciem widać inne polskojęzyczne komentarze: “Dlaczego honorowa asysta, skoro ci ludzie byli najemnikami?”; “Żony i matki chłopaków teraz będą dumne”; “korporacyjne mięso najemne bez świadomości”; “A kazał im ktoś? Chcieli,to mają”; “Ciekawe dlaczego chowają ich z honorami? Przecież to najemnik z własnego wyboru” (pisownia wszystkich wpisów oryginalna).
Jak sprawdziliśmy, zdjęcie jest stare i nie ma nic wspólnego z trwającą wojną.
Żołnierze polegli w Afganistanie, nie w Ukrainie
W rzeczywistości zdjęcie pokazuje powrót ciał polskich żołnierzy poległych w Afganistanie w 2011 roku. Zilustrowało m.in. artykuł, który został opublikowany w portalu Tvn24.pl. Zostało zrobione 23 grudnia 2011 roku przez fotografa Polskiej Agencji Prasowej Grzegorza Jakubowskiego. Nadal jest dostępne w bazie PAP.
Przypomnijmy: 21 grudnia 2011 roku pięciu żołnierzy z 20 Bartoszyckiej Brygady Zmechanizowanej zginęło w pobliżu głównej drogi łączącej Kabul z Kandaharem. Pod ich transporterem eksplodował silny ładunek wybuchowy. Do ataku na ich konwój przyznali się afgańscy talibowie. 23 grudnia trumny z ciałami żołnierzy przywieziono do Polski. Na warszawskim Okęciu polegli zostali przywitani z ceremoniałem wojskowym (za: Prezydent.pl). Właśnie wtedy powstało zdjęcie, które teraz wykorzystano do dezinformacji na temat wojny w Ukrainie. O śmierci pięciu polskich żołnierzy i przywiezieniu ich ciał do kraju w grudniu 2011 roku informowały polskie media.
“Krążące w mediach społecznościowych zdjęcie mające pokazywać domniemany pogrzeb polskich żołnierzy, którzy walczyli na Ukrainie jest nieprawdziwe. To kolejny przykład fake newsa wpisujący się w działania dezinformacyjne szerzące się zwłaszcza w mediach społecznościowych” – odpowiedział nam Wydział Prasowy Centrum Operacyjnego Ministra Obrony Narodowej i po raz kolejny zwrócił się z apelem do przedstawicieli mediów i użytkowników mediów społecznościowych o szczególną ostrożność przy rozpowszechnianiu informacji, publikowaniu filmów i zdjęć sprzętu wojskowego. “Należy przykładać szczególną ostrożność w kwestii wiarygodności informacji pojawiających się w przestrzeni informacyjnej i korzystać z wiarygodnych źródeł” – stwierdzono w przesłanym nam e-mailu.
Kolejny raz prokremlowska propaganda wykorzystuje to samo wydarzenie
To nie pierwszy raz, gdy rosyjska propaganda używa tragicznego zdarzenia z 2011 roku, by podczas trwającej w Ukrainie wprowadzać fałszywe informacje do sieci. Kilka miesięcy temu, o czym pisaliśmy w Konkret24, rosyjskie źródła, a za nimi inni, rozpowszechniały dziesięciosekundowe wideo sprzed ponad jedenastu lat, przedstawiające kilka ujęć polskich żołnierzy asystujących przy trumnach przykrytych flagami Polski z przekazem, że to aktualne nagranie, a Polacy zginęli w Ukrainie.
Translation:
The Russian disinformation machine is once again using old materials to prove that Polish soldiers are now dying in Ukraine. And again these images are distributed on the Polish network.
Another version of false pro-Kremlin disinformation about Polish mercenary soldiers dying in Ukraine has appeared on the Internet. A photo of a dozen or so Polish soldiers assisting with five coffins covered with Polish flags was published on Russian social media. The photo was taken on the airport tarmac - the plane and hangars can be seen in the distance.
The photo was published, among others, by a Telegram account that regularly posts materials showing dead Ukrainian soldiers. Now the account user has added a comment to the published frame, indicating that the photo shows dead mercenaries from Poland who have just died in Ukraine.
The photo from Telegram quickly found its way to various Russian websites, e.g. Anna-news.info, where it was used to illustrate the article "Poles want to destroy Russia." Its reprint was published on the Polish network - it was translated and published on the Gloria.tv website.
The photo also appeared on Polish Twitter, where it was published on February 12, 2023 on one of the accounts. “The ceremonial return of Polish cannon fodder from [Ukrainian flag inserted here]. I wonder why no media shows this?” – wrote the user in a comment. Some Internet users believed that the photo showed the return of the bodies of Poles who died in Ukraine. Under the photo you can see other Polish-language comments: "Why honorary assistance if these people were mercenaries?"; “Boyfriends' wives and mothers will now be proud”; “corporate hired meat without awareness”; “Did someone tell them to? They wanted it, they got it"; “I wonder why they bury them with honors? After all, he is a mercenary by his own choice” (original spelling of all entries).
As we checked, the photo is old and has nothing to do with the ongoing war.
The soldiers died in Afghanistan, not in Ukraine
In fact, the photo shows the return of the bodies of Polish soldiers killed in Afghanistan in 2011. Illustrated, among others, an article that was published on the Tvn24.pl website. It was taken on December 23, 2011 by Polish Press Agency photographer Grzegorz Jakubowski. It is still available in the PAP database.
Let us recall: on December 21, 2011, five soldiers from the 20th Bartoszyce Mechanized Brigade were killed near the main road connecting Kabul with Kandahar. A powerful explosive exploded under their transporter. The Afghan Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack on their convoy. On December 23, the coffins with the bodies of the soldiers were brought to Poland. At Warsaw's Okęcie airport, the fallen were greeted with military ceremonies (source: Głos.pl). That's when the photo was taken and now used to disinformation about the war in Ukraine. The Polish media reported on the death of five Polish soldiers and the bringing of their bodies to the country in December 2011.
“A photo circulating on social media purporting to show the alleged funeral of Polish soldiers who fought in Ukraine is untrue. This is another example of fake news that is part of the disinformation activities spreading especially on social media," the Press Department of the Operations Center of the Minister of National Defense replied to us and once again appealed to media representatives and social media users to be particularly careful when disseminating information, publishing videos and photos of military equipment. “You should pay particular attention to the credibility of information appearing in the information space and use reliable sources,” it said in an email sent to us.
Once again, pro-Kremlin propaganda uses the same event
This is not the first time that Russian propaganda has used the tragic event of 2011 to introduce false information online during the ongoing protests in Ukraine. A few months ago, as we wrote on Konkret24, Russian sources, followed by others, distributed a ten-second video from over eleven years ago, showing several shots of Polish soldiers assisting with coffins covered with Polish flags, with the message that this is a current recording and Poles died in Ukraine .

FALS | Diana Iovanovici-Șoșoacă (Senator, ales pe listele AUR, actualmente în grupul neafiliaților): „În timpul stării de urgență au dispărut 3.000 de copii, nu i-a găsit nimeni, niciodată. […] În timp ce toată lumea era în casă, 3.000 de copii dispăreau de pe teritoriul României”.
FALS | Diana Iovanovici-Șoșoacă (Senator, ales pe listele AUR, actualmente în grupul neafiliaților): „În timpul stării de urgență au dispărut 3.000 de copii, nu i-a găsit nimeni, niciodată. […] În timp ce toată lumea era în casă, 3.000 de copii dispăreau de pe teritoriul României”.
Sursa afirmației : Facebook (min. 30:34)
Publicat miercuri 24 mai 2023 la 15:43
(Foto copertă: Facebook / Diana Șoșoacă)
CONTEXT
În 24 aprilie 2023, în sedința Comisiei pentru Muncă și Protecție Socială și a Comisiei pentru Sănătate și Familie de la Camera Deputaților s-a discutat proiectul de lege nr.145/2023. Într-un live făcut de deputatul și liderul AUR George Simion în cadrul acestei ședințe, senatoarea Diana Șoșoacă a făcut următoarea afirmație:
„În timpul stării de urgență au dispărut 3.000 de copii, nu i-a găsit nimeni, niciodată. […] În timp ce toată lumea era în casă, 3.000 de copii dispăreau de pe teritoriul României”.
CE VERIFICĂM?
Câți copii au dispărut în perioada stării de urgență din România și câte dintre aceste dispariții au fost soluționate.
VERIFICARE
România a fost în stare de urgență între 16 martie 2020 și 14 mai 2020.
Conform răspunsului primit de la Poliția Română, „în perioada 16.03-14.05.2020, la nivel național, au fost înregistrate 611 sesizări privind dispariția de minori, fiind soluționate 692 (unele dintre sesizările de dispariție au fost înregistrate în perioada anterioară perioadei de referință). Menționăm că această statistică reprezintă numărul sesizărilor de dispariție, nu și numărul persoanelor, întrucât acestea pot fi semnalate dispărute de mai multe ori într-un interval de timp, iar dacă după clarificarea situaţiei se revine cu o nouă sesizare, aceasta va fi înregistrată ca o nouă lucrare de dispariție”.
Ca atare, cifrele prezentate de senatoarea Diana Șoșoacă nu au absolut nicio bază reală.
Organizația Salvați Copiii a anunțat în că, în perioada aprilie 2019-mai 2020, „au fost înregistrate 6.475 de sesizări privind minori care au dispărut de acasă, un bilanţ dramatic, în condiţiile în care 192 au vârste până la 10 ani, 1.623 cu vârsta cuprinsă între 10-14 ani şi 4.660 mai mari de 14 ani, potrivit datelor furnizate de Direcţia de Investigaţii Criminale din cadrul Inspectoratului General de Poliţie”. În aceeași perioadă, 6.742 de minori au fost găsiți. Cifra cuprinde și cazuri sesizate mai devreme și soluționate în perioada menționată.
CONCLUZIE
Afirmația senatoarei este falsă. În perioada stării de urgență, au fost sesizate 611 dispariții în rândul minorilor. În plus, se observă că, de obicei, mai mult de 90% din sesizările de dispariții ale minorilor sunt soluționate.
Translation:
FALSE | Diana Iovanovici-Şoșoacă (Senator, elected on the AUR lists, currently in the non-affiliated group): "During the state of emergency, 3,000 children disappeared, no one ever found them. [...] While everyone was at home, 3,000 children were disappearing from the territory of Romania".
FALSE | Diana Iovanovici-Şoșoacă (Senator, elected on the AUR lists, currently in the non-affiliated group): "During the state of emergency, 3,000 children disappeared, no one ever found them. [...] While everyone was at home, 3,000 children were disappearing from the territory of Romania".
Source of the statement: Facebook (min. 30:34)
Published Wednesday, May 24, 2023 at 3:43 p.m
(Cover photo: Facebook / Diana Sosoacă)
CONTEXT
On April 24, 2023, the draft law no. 145/2023 was discussed at the meeting of the Committee for Labor and Social Protection and the Committee for Health and Family at the Chamber of Deputies. In a live broadcast by deputy and AUR leader George Simion during this meeting, Senator Diana Sosoacă made the following statement:
"During the state of emergency, 3,000 children disappeared, no one ever found them. [...] While everyone was at home, 3,000 children were disappearing from the territory of Romania".
WHAT DO WE CHECK?
How many children disappeared during the state of emergency in Romania and how many of these disappearances were solved.
VERIFICATION
Romania was in a state of emergency between March 16, 2020 and May 14, 2020.
According to the response received from the Romanian Police, "between 16.03-14.05.2020, at the national level, 611 notifications regarding the disappearance of minors were registered, 692 of which were resolved (some of the notifications of disappearance were registered in the period prior to the reference period) . We note that this statistic represents the number of reports of disappearance, not the number of people, since they can be reported missing several times in a period of time, and if, after clarifying the situation, a new report is returned, it will be registered as a new extinction work".
As such, the figures presented by Senator Diana Sosoacă have absolutely no real basis.
The Save the Children organization announced that, between April 2019 and May 2020, "6,475 complaints were registered regarding minors who disappeared from home, a dramatic balance, given that 192 are under the age of 10, 1,623 with the age of between 10-14 years and 4,660 older than 14 years, according to the data provided by the Directorate of Criminal Investigations within the General Police Inspectorate". During the same period, 6,742 minors were found. The figure also includes cases reported earlier and resolved during the mentioned period.
CONCLUSION
The senator's claim is false. During the state of emergency, 611 disappearances among minors were reported. In addition, it is noted that typically more than 90% of reports of missing minors are solved.

Viral advarsel i omløb: Nej, disse fem personer er ikke på jagt efter danske børns organer
-
På Facebook og TikTok er der i øjeblikket en advarsel om fem kidnappere i omløb
-
I flere opslag kan man nemlig se de fem formodede gerningspersoner og læse, at kidnapperne er på færde i Danmark - særligt i Taastrup - og har til hensigt at sælge børns organer
-
Men Københavns Vestegns Politi har ikke modtaget anmeldelser, der tyder på, at advarslen har noget på sig
-
Opslaget stammer fra udlandet, og personerne på billedet er anholdt for lommetyveri i Rumænien
Fem kidnappere er på spil i Danmark med det formål at bortføre børn og sælge deres organer.
Det er i hvert fald advarslen i opslag på både TikTok og Facebook, hvor man også kan se et billede af de fem formodede gerningspersoner.
I en video på TikTok kan man også læse, at kidnapperne er blevet spottet mindst to gange i en beskidt sort bil med en pose tomme flasker. Derudover står der, at man skal være særligt opmærksom, hvis man bor i Taastrup omkring Parkvej.
TjekDet har rakt ud til National enhed for Særlig Kriminalitet (NSK), der arbejder med efterforskning og retsforfølgelse af organiseret kriminalitet, økonomisk kriminalitet samt IT-kriminalitet, for at spørge, om de kender til sagen. Men de henviser til Københavns Vestegns Politi.
"Vi er bekendt med opslaget og efterforsker det. Vi har ikke modtaget anmeldelser, der på nogen måde understøtter det, der beskrives i videoen," skriver Københavns Vestegns Politis kommunikationsafdeling i en mail.
I et opslag, der florerer på Facebook, TikTok og tilsyneladende også Snapchat, advares der mod fem personer, som angiveligt kidnapper børn med henblik på at sælge deres organer. Men ifølge Københavns Vestegns Politi og National enhed for Særlig Kriminalitet er der ingen grund til bekymring over den pågældende advarsel. (FOTO: Skærmbillede fra Facebook)
Advarsel stammer fra udlandet
Det er ikke så underligt, at Københavns Vestegns Politi ikke kender noget til sagen.
For tager man et skærmbillede af facebookopslaget og laver en omvendt billedsøgning, dukker der flere identiske opslag op på flere forskellige sprog.
Det tidligste opslag, TjekDet har fundet frem til, stammer fra den 26. oktober 2023. På en tysk facebookprofil står der på serbisk, at de fem kidnappere er på spil i byen Zagar, som enten kan være i Rumænien eller Bosnien-Herzegovina.
Teksten til opslaget, der har flere end 930.000 delinger på tværs af Facebook, kan hos nogle danske facebookbrugere risikere at være blevet automatisk oversat til dansk, og af den grund kan det have snydt nogle til at tro, at advarslen stammer fra Danmark. I opslagets kommentarspor er det da også tydeligt at se, at facebookbrugere fra store dele af verden har delt opslaget i deres område.
Med til selve billedet af gerningspersonerne hører også en tekst, hvor der står, at kidnappere kører rundt i Vilnius-regionen i Litauen og jagter børn.
Talskvinde for politiet i Vilnius-regionen, Julija Samorokovskaja, oplyser dog til TjekDets litauiske fakatjekkolleger fra Patikrinta 15min, at de ikke har modtaget anmeldelser angående det.
“Men vi har også set lignende opslag om sådanne sager i forskellige regioner, hvor nogle angiveligt kidnapper børn,” skriver hun til Patikrinta 15min, som har videresendt svaret til TjekDet.
Rumænske lommetyve
Det kan jo være en smule forvirrende med opslag på forskellige sprog og med advarsler i forskellige byer. Men laver man en omvendt billedsøgning, hvor det kun er billedet af de fem påståede kidnappere, man søger efter, begynder det at give mening, hvorfor man finder forskellige versioner af opslaget.
TjekDet har nemlig fundet frem til et opslag fra 2016, hvor man kan se et billede af de fem personer. Og til opslaget står der på rumænsk: “Opmærksomhed på tyvene i sporvognen, værsgo!!!” I opslaget står der altså ikke noget om, at personerne er kidnappere.
Billedet af personerne dukker også op i flere rumænske artikler, der beskriver, at de er blevet anholdt for lommetyveri. I ingen af artiklerne associeres personerne med kidnapning af børn.
Ikke helt grebet ud af den blå luft
Selvom de fem personer, der hænges ud med billede på sociale medier, ikke har noget med kidnapning i Danmark at gøre, er historien om, at der er kidnappere på spil, måske ikke grebet helt ud af den blå luft.
3. november skriver Fredericia Dagblad, at politiet bekræfter, at de har fået en anmeldelse fra en mor på en ifølge hende mistænkelig hændelse, hvor en mand henvendte sig til hendes søn.
Men Mikkel Ross, der er vicepolitiinspektør i Patruljecenter Syd, maner til besindighed.
“Vi har intet hørt om lignende sager, og vi har intet at gå efter. Vi har intet, der indikerer, at der stjæles børn eller skulle være forsøg på det i Fredericia,” siger han til Fredericia Dagblad.
Moren til drengen har også lavet et facebookopslag, som ifølge avisen er gået viralt og sidenhen har udviklet sig til, at der måske er en rumænsk bande på spil, der kidnapper børn for at sælge deres organer.
8. november skriver flere danske medier så, at en 20-årig rumænsk mand er blevet anholdt for kidnapningsforsøg på to kvinder på henholdsvis 18 og 22 år i Herning. Begge kvinder slap fri efter at have gjort modstand. Politiet leder stadig efter en anden gerningsmand i sagen.
Hvis du kan lide vores artikler og vil være sikker på ikke at gå glip af den nyeste, så følg os på Facebook ved at klikke her.
Translation:
Viral warning in circulation: No, these five people are not looking for the organs of Danish children
-
On Facebook and TikTok, there is currently a warning about five kidnappers in circulation
-
In several postings you can see the five suspected perpetrators and read that the kidnappers are on the move in Denmark - especially in Taastrup - and intend to sell children's organs
-
But Copenhagen's Vestegns Police has not received any reports that indicate that the warning has any merit
-
The post originates from abroad, and the people in the picture have been arrested for pickpocketing in Romania
Five kidnappers are at play in Denmark with the aim of abducting children and selling their organs.
At least that is the warning in posts on both TikTok and Facebook, where you can also see a picture of the five suspected perpetrators.
In a video on TikTok, you can also read that the kidnappers have been spotted at least twice in a dirty black car with a bag of empty bottles. In addition, it says that you must be particularly careful if you live in Taastrup around Parkvej.
TjekDet has reached out to the National Unit for Special Crime (NSK), which works with the investigation and prosecution of organized crime, financial crime and IT crime, to ask if they know about the case. But they refer to Copenhagen's Vestegns Police.
"We are aware of the post and are investigating it. We have not received any reviews that in any way support what is described in the video," writes Copenhagen's Vestegns Police's communications department in an email.
In a post that abounds on Facebook, TikTok and apparently also Snapchat, a warning is issued against five people who are allegedly kidnapping children in order to sell their organs. But according to Copenhagen Vestegns Police and the National Unit for Special Crime, there is no reason to worry about the warning in question. (PHOTO: Screenshot from Facebook)
Warning originates from abroad
It is not so surprising that the Copenhagen Vestegns Police know nothing about the case.
Because if you take a screenshot of the Facebook post and do a reverse image search, several identical posts appear in several different languages.
The earliest post that TjekDet has found is from October 26, 2023. On a German Facebook profile, it says in Serbian that the five kidnappers are at stake in the town of Zagar, which can either be in Romania or Bosnia-Herzegovina.
The text of the post, which has more than 930,000 shares across Facebook, may have been automatically translated into Danish by some Danish Facebook users, and for that reason it may have tricked some into thinking that the warning originates from Denmark. In the post's comment track, it is also clear to see that Facebook users from large parts of the world have shared the post in their area.
Along with the image of the perpetrators, there is also a text stating that kidnappers are driving around the Vilnius region of Lithuania hunting children.
However, spokeswoman for the police in the Vilnius region, Julija Samorokovskaja, informs TjekDet's Lithuanian professional Czech colleagues from Patikrinta 15min that they have not received any reports regarding it.
"But we have also seen similar posts about such cases in different regions, where some allegedly kidnap children," she writes to Patikrinta 15min, which forwarded the response to TjekDet.
Romanian pickpockets
It can be a bit confusing with notices in different languages ​​and with warnings in different cities. But if you do a reverse image search, where you are only looking for the image of the five alleged kidnappers, it starts to make sense why you find different versions of the post.
TjekDet has actually found a posting from 2016, where you can see a picture of the five people. And the notice says in Romanian: "Attention to the thieves in the tram, beware!!!" In the notice, there is therefore nothing to the effect that the persons are kidnappers.
The picture of the people also appears in several Romanian articles describing that they have been arrested for pickpocketing. In none of the articles are the persons associated with the kidnapping of children.
Not completely plucked out of thin air
Although the five people who are posted with pictures on social media have nothing to do with kidnapping in Denmark, the story that there are kidnappers at play may not be plucked completely out of thin air.
On November 3, Fredericia Dagblad writes that the police confirm that they have received a report from a mother about what she says is a suspicious incident where a man approached her son.
But Mikkel Ross, who is deputy police inspector at Patruljecenter Syd, urges caution.
“We have heard nothing about similar cases, and we have nothing to go by. We have nothing to indicate that children are being stolen or that there are attempts to do so in Fredericia," he says to Fredericia Dagblad.
The mother of the boy has also made a Facebook post which, according to the newspaper, has gone viral and has since developed into the idea that there may be a Romanian gang at play that kidnaps children to sell their organs.
On November 8, several Danish media reports that a 20-year-old Romanian man has been arrested for attempted kidnapping of two women aged 18 and 22 respectively in Herning. Both women escaped after resisting. The police are still looking for another perpetrator in the case.

Wissenschaftler betonen, das Niveau der derzeitigen Vulkan-Aktivität sei nichts Außergewöhnliches, auch wenn in sozialen Medien in vielen Posts das Gegenteil behauptet wird. Experten erklärten AFP gegenüber, dass es zwar in einigen Ländern bemerkenswerte Eruptionen gegeben habe, im Großen und Ganzen das Jahr aber eher am unteren Ende der typischen globalen Vulkanaktivität liege.
“Vulkane brechen gleichzeitig in Italien, Island, Japan, Mexiko, Russland, den Philippinen usw. aus. Unten sehen Sie eine Karte der vulkanischen Aktivität von 2013 und 2023. Völlig normal, oder?” sagte Internet-Kommentator Kim Dotcom in einem Beitrag vom 14. November 2023, der auf X (ehemals Twitter) veröffentlicht wurde. Der Post erreichte Tausende Interaktionen, bevor er entfernt wurde. Ähnliche Behauptungen verbreiteten sich auch andernorts auf X.
Bemerkenswerte vulkanische Aktivität wurde im November 2023 aus Italien, Island, Japan, Mexiko und Russland gemeldet. Doch Expertinnen und Experten sagten AFP gegenüber, 2023 sei bisher ein normales Jahr gewesen, was Ausbrüche anginge.
“Es gibt in der vulkanischen Aktivität natürliche Schwankungen von Jahr zu Jahr, aber es gab keinen allgemeinen Anstieg der vulkanischen Aktivität”, sagte Wendy Bohon, eine Erdbebengeologin, am 15. November 2023.
Vulkane sind ein häufiges Thema von Klima-Falschinformationen. AFP hat unter anderem bereits belegt, dass Vulkane nicht mehr Kohlenstoffdioxid ausstoßen, als von Menschen produziert wird oder Falschbehauptungen widerlegt, dass diese für den Klimawandel verantwortlich seien.
Unterschiedliche Arten der Aktivität
Die Karten aus dem X-Beitrag geben keinerlei Aufschluss über den Zeitrahmen oder die Art der Aktivität. Das ist wichtig, weil nicht alle vulkanischen Aktivitäten das gleiche Ausmaß oder dieselben Auswirkungen haben.
Der ursprüngliche Beitrag enthielt auch keine Quelle für die Daten oder Angaben darüber, ob die Karte auch andere Ereignisse, wie etwa durch Vulkane ausgelöste Erdbeben, enthält.
Eine Stichwortsuche legt nahe, dass es sich bei den Bilden um Screenshots einer Website namens Volcano Discovery handeln könnte, die nach eigenen Angaben mehrere Datenbanken zusammenfasst. Die interaktiven Karten mit Symbolen auf der Seite ähneln denen in den auf sozialen Medien geteilten Bildern. Die Kreise stellen Erdbeben dar und die Dreiecke zeigen vulkanische Aktivität, so die Legende auf der Webseite.
Ein Überblick über die vulkanische Aktivität allein für den November 2023 zeigt weniger Ergebnisse, als es die X-Beiträge nahelegen. Außerdem enthält die Karte auch mehrere gelbe Dreiecke, die Unruhen von Vulkanen darstellen — ein Zustand, der Monate oder Jahre andauern kann.
Durchschnittliche Zahlen
Mehrere Experten verwiesen AFP auf das US-amerikanische Smithsonian Global Volcanism Program (GVP, hier archiviert), um wissenschaftliche Daten über jährliche Vulkanereignisse zu finden. “Die jüngste Aktivität war nicht höher als normal”, sagte Edward Venzke, ein leitender Datenforscher am Smithsonian, am 15. November 2023.
Die verfügbaren Daten des Instituts zeigen, dass es im Jahr 2023 bis zum 11. Oktober 2023 insgesamt 67 Ausbrüche gegeben hat, darunter 17 neue und 21, die aufhörten. Zum gleichen Zeitpunkt im Jahr 2013 sei die Zahl der Ausbrüche höher gewesen: 80 insgesamt, 37 neue und 42 beendete, sagte Venzke.
“Normalerweise gibt es in einem Kalenderjahr zwischen 70 und 80 Ausbrüche. Es sieht also so aus, als ob 2023 eher am unteren Ende der Norm liegt”, sagte er und wies darauf hin, dass bis zum Ende des Jahres noch weitere Aktivität möglich sei. Venzke fügte hinzu, dass die historischen Durchschnittswerte den technischen Fortschritt und die bessere Berichterstattung nicht berücksichtigen.
Das GVP erklärt auf seiner Website, dass der seit den 1990er-Jahren beobachtete Anstieg der Aktivität auf “neue Meldeeffekte” zurückzuführen ist, etwa Internetzugang und verstärkten Einsatz von Fernerkundungssatellitendaten.
Ländervergleiche
Der mexikanische Vulkan Popocatepetl — dessen Aktivität Mitte November 2023 leicht zunahm — hat nach einem jahrzehntelangen Dornröschenschlaf verschiedene Aktivitätsphasen erlebt.
“Seit seinem Erwachen im Dezember 1994 hat der Popocatepetl ein breites Spektrum an eruptiven Aktivitäten gezeigt, von kleinen Gas- und Ascheemissionen bis hin zu strombolianischen und vulkanischen Ausbrüchen”, erklärte Alejandra Arciniega Ceballos, Vulkanologin an der Nationalen Autonomen Universität von Mexiko, bereits zu einem früheren Zeitpunkt gegenüber AFP. Er bezog sich dabei auf unterschiedliche Eruptionstypen, die sich unter anderem in Explosivität und Flussgeschwindigkeit der Lava unterscheiden.
Auch der Mount Mayon auf den Philippinen bricht seit Monaten aus.
Auf der isländischen Halbinsel Reykjanes kam es seit 2021 zu drei Ausbrüchen, nachdem die Region jahrzehntelang inaktiv war. Sie beheimatet 33 aktive Vulkansysteme — die höchste Zahl in Europa. Nach Ansicht von Vulkanologen könnte die jüngste starke Aktivität den Beginn einer neuen Ära andeuten.
Der Vulkanologe und Forscher an der University of California, Berkeley, Stephen Self betonte jedoch, dass nicht alle Vulkanausbrüche gleich sind. “Denken Sie daran, dass der nächste Ausbruch eines Supervulkans höchstwahrscheinlich ein kleiner sein wird, denn Vulkane aller Art haben viel mehr kleine Ausbrüche als große”, sagte er am 15. November 2023 gegenüber AFP.
Fazit: Weltweit sind aktuell Vulkane aktiv — doch das ist vollkommen normal. Tatsächlich könnte 2023 sogar am unteren Ende der typischen Aktivität liegen, sagen Vulkanforscher. Eine in sozialen Medien geteilte Karte zeigt viele unterschiedliche Arten von Aktivität, von kleinen Unruhen über Erdbeben bis hin zu aktiven Ausbrüchen.
Translation:
Scientists emphasize that the level of current volcanic activity is nothing unusual, although many social media posts claim the opposite. Experts told AFP that while there were notable eruptions in some countries, overall the year was at the lower end of typical global volcanic activity.
“Volcanoes erupt simultaneously in Italy, Iceland, Japan, Mexico, Russia, the Philippines, etc. Below you can see a map of volcanic activity from 2013 and 2023. Totally normal, right?” said internet commentator Kim Dotcom in a November 14, 2023 post published on X (formerly Twitter). The post received thousands of interactions before it was removed. Similar claims spread elsewhere on X.
Notable volcanic activity was reported in Italy, Iceland, Japan, Mexico and Russia in November 2023. But experts told AFP that 2023 has been a normal year so far when it comes to outbreaks.
“There are natural year-to-year fluctuations in volcanic activity, but there has been no overall increase in volcanic activity,” said Wendy Bohon, an earthquake geologist, on November 15, 2023.
Volcanoes are a common subject of climate misinformation. AFP has already proven, among other things, that volcanoes do not emit more carbon dioxide than is produced by humans or refuted false claims that they are responsible for climate change.
Different types of activity
The maps from the X post do not provide any information about the time frame or type of activity. This is important because not all volcanic activity has the same magnitude or impact.
The original post also did not provide a source for the data or whether the map included other events, such as earthquakes caused by volcanoes.
A keyword search suggests that the images could be screenshots from a website called Volcano Discovery, which claims to aggregate several databases. The interactive maps with icons on the page are similar to those in the images shared on social media. The circles represent earthquakes and the triangles represent volcanic activity, according to the legend on the website.
An overview of volcanic activity for November 2023 alone shows fewer results than the X contributions suggest. The map also contains several yellow triangles that represent unrest of volcanoes — a condition that can last for months or years.
Average numbers
Several experts referred AFP to the U.S. Smithsonian Global Volcanism Program (GVP, archived here) for scientific data on annual volcanic events. “Recent activity has not been higher than normal,” said Edward Venzke, a senior data researcher at the Smithsonian, on November 15, 2023.
The institute's available data shows that there have been a total of 67 outbreaks in 2023 as of October 11, 2023, including 17 new ones and 21 that have ceased. At the same time in 2013, the number of outbreaks was higher: 80 total, 37 new and 42 terminated, Venzke said.
“Typically there are between 70 and 80 outbreaks in a calendar year. So it looks like 2023 is more on the lower end of the norm,” he said, noting that further activity is still possible through the end of the year. Venzke added that the historical averages do not take into account technological advances and better reporting.
The GVP explains on its website that the increase in activity observed since the 1990s is due to “new reporting effects,” such as Internet access and increased use of remote sensing satellite data.
Country comparisons
The Mexican volcano Popocatepetl — whose activity increased slightly in mid-November 2023 — has experienced various phases of activity after a decades-long slumber.
“Since its awakening in December 1994, Popocatepetl has shown a wide range of eruptive activity, from small gas and ash emissions to strombolian and volcanic eruptions,” explained Alejandra Arciniega Ceballos, a volcanologist at the National Autonomous University of Mexico earlier to AFP. He was referring to different types of eruptions, which differ, among other things, in the explosiveness and flow speed of the lava.
Mount Mayon in the Philippines has also been erupting for months.
Iceland's Reykjanes Peninsula has seen three eruptions since 2021 after the region was inactive for decades. It is home to 33 active volcanic systems — the highest number in Europe. According to volcanologists, the recent strong activity could signal the beginning of a new era.
However, volcanologist and researcher at the University of California, Berkeley, Stephen Self emphasized that not all volcanic eruptions are the same. “Remember that the next eruption of a supervolcano will most likely be a small one, because volcanoes of all types have many more small eruptions than large ones,” he told AFP on November 15, 2023.
Conclusion: Volcanoes are currently active all over the world - but that is completely normal. In fact, 2023 could even be at the lower end of typical activity, volcano researchers say. A map shared on social media shows many different types of activity, from small riots to earthquakes to active eruptions.

Bewertung
Die Behauptung ist falsch. Die Masern-Schutzimpfung gehört mit 98 bis 99 Prozent Schutz vor einer Masern-Infektion zu den wirksamsten Impfungen überhaupt. Bei einer Impfquote von über 95 Prozent kann man die Masern ausrotten. Die Masern-Schutzimpfung ist Fachleuten zufolge daher sehr nützlich. Mögliche Komplikationen, die bei einer Masernimpfung auftreten können, werden öffentlich einsehbar dokumentiert. Sie sind daher kalkulierbar.
Fakten
Die Masernimpfung ist wirksam. Laut Gesundheitsministerium schützt die Masernimpfung nach zweimaliger Verabreichung zu 98 bis 99 Prozent vor einer Maserninfektion: «Damit gehört die Masern-Schutzimpfung zu den wirksamsten Impfungen überhaupt.»
Wenn nur einmal geimpft werde, sei die Schutzwirkung geringer, heißt es auf der Seite masernschutz.de. Rund acht Prozent der Geimpften seien nach der einmaligen Impfung nicht immun gegen Masern. Um die Eliminierung von Masern durch Herdenschutz zu erreichen, ist eine Impfquote von mindestens 95 Prozent erforderlich. Um diesen Wert zu erzielen, ist eine zweite Impfung notwendig.
Wer nicht geimpft ist, gefährdet seine Gesundheit. Besonders für ungeborene Kinder ungeimpfter Mütter ist eine Masern-Infektion gefährlich. »Denn die Masernviren können durch die Plazenta hindurchgelangen und das Kind infizieren. Außerdem kommt es bei jeder vierten maserninfizierten Schwangeren zu vorzeitigen Wehen, die sich nicht aufhalten lassen, und somit zu einer Fehl- oder Frühgeburt», schreibt der Berufsverband der Frauenärzte auf seiner Webseite.
Wenn die Mutter allerdings Antikörper dank der Impfung oder einer überstandenen Masern-Erkrankung hat, schützen diese das Baby während der Schwangerschaft und auch in den ersten Lebensmonaten. Die Immunproteine der Mutter werden nach der Geburt langsam abgebaut und schützen den Säugling noch über mehrere Monate. Dieser Effekt nennt sich «Nestschutz». Er hält circa drei Monate lang an und beginnt dann nachzulassen.
Masern gefährden vor allem kleine Kinder
Die Masern-Schutzimpfung wird allerdings frühestens ab dem elften Lebensmonat verabreicht. In der Phase zwischen dem Nestschutz und der ersten Impfuzng sind Babys daher besonders gefährdet.
Masernviren sind neurotrop, das heißt, sie überwinden die Blut-Hirn-Schranke und wirken auf das Nervensystem. Etwa eines von 1000 Kindern mit einer Masern-Infektion entwickelt als Folge eine Entzündung des Gehirns. Diese kann folgenlos ausheilen.
Bei einer Masern-Infektion besteht allerdings auch das Risiko einer «Slow-Virus-Erkrankung». Kennzeichen dieser Krankheiten sind sehr lange Inkubationszeiten und Verläufe, sie enden außerdem immer tödlich. Eine Maserninfektion kann zur subakuten sklerosierenden Panenzephalitis (SSPE) führen. Diese Krankheit tritt bei Kindern circa fünf bis zehn Jahre nach der Maserninfektion auf und betrifft das Zentrale Nervensystem (ZNS).
«Bei der SSPE wird das Gehirn sukzessive in Bindegewebe umgebaut», sagt Professor Horst von Bernuth, Leiter der Immunologie an der Charité Berlin. Die Krankheit führt über vier verschiedene Stadien nach drei bis fünf Jahren immer zum Tod. Symptome im Krankheitsverlauf sind Krampfanfälle, Demenz und Wachkoma. Bei rund der Hälfte der SSPE Fälle fand die Masern-Infektion vor dem zweiten Lebensjahr statt.
Weitere Folgen einer Masern-Infektion sind laut dem Berufsverband der Kinder- und Jugendärzte ein für sechs Wochen stark geschwächtes Immunsystem, was weitere Infektionskrankheiten begünstigen kann. «Diese Kinder entwickeln nach den Masern dann beispielsweise schwere Pneumonien, da sie sich nicht mehr ausreichend gegen bakterielle Erreger der Lungenentzündung wehren können», sagt Professor von Bernuth, «Diese sogenannten Immunamnesie nach Masern sorgt vermutlich für die 100 000 bis 200 000 Maserntoten pro Jahr weltweit.»
Masern verbreiten sich durch Tröpfcheninfektion und gehören zu den ansteckendsten Krankheiten der Welt, die schwerwiegende Spätfolgen haben können. Die Masern-Schutzimpfung ist daher sehr nützlich, um Menschen vor der Krankheit und etwaigen Folgen zu schützen.
Risiko von Schäden infolge einer Masern-Schutzimpfung
Leichte Impfreaktionen auf die Masern-Schutzimpfung haben circa fünf bis 15 Prozent der Geimpften nach der ersten Impfung. Dazu gehören Rötungen und Schwellungen an der Injektionsstelle oder auch Fieber. Bei circa fünf Prozent tritt ein leichter Hautausschlag auf, dieser ist aber nicht ansteckend. Nach der zweiten Impfung treten die aufgeführten Reaktionen nur noch sehr selten auf.
Impfschäden sind laut Paragraf 2 des Infektionsschutzgesetzes «die gesundheitliche und wirtschaftliche Folge einer über das übliche Ausmaß einer Impfreaktion hinausgehenden gesundheitlichen Schädigung durch die Schutzimpfung». Diese Schäden sind meldepflichtig, sie sind einsehbar in der Datenbank des Paul-Ehrlich-Instituts.
(Stand: 03.10.2023)
Translation:
Evaluation
The claim is false. With 98 to 99 percent protection against measles infection, the measles vaccination is one of the most effective vaccinations of all. With a vaccination rate of over 95 percent, measles can be eradicated. According to experts, the measles vaccination is therefore very useful. Possible complications that can occur with a measles vaccination are documented for public access. They are therefore calculable.
Facts
The measles vaccination is effective. According to the Ministry of Health, the measles vaccination provides 98 to 99 percent protection against measles infection after two doses: “This makes the measles vaccination one of the most effective vaccinations of all.”
If you only get vaccinated once, the protective effect is lower, according to the website masernschutz.de. Around eight percent of those vaccinated are not immune to measles after the one-time vaccination. To achieve measles elimination through herd protection, a vaccination rate of at least 95 percent is required. In order to achieve this value, a second vaccination is necessary.
Anyone who is not vaccinated is putting their health at risk. Measles infection is particularly dangerous for unborn children of unvaccinated mothers. »Because the measles viruses can pass through the placenta and infect the child. In addition, one in four pregnant women infected with measles experience premature contractions that cannot be stopped, resulting in a miscarriage or premature birth,” writes the professional association of gynecologists on its website.
However, if the mother has antibodies thanks to the vaccination or after surviving measles, these protect the baby during pregnancy and also in the first months of life. The mother's immune proteins are slowly broken down after birth and continue to protect the infant for several months. This effect is called “nest protection”. It lasts for about three months and then begins to wear off.
Measles is particularly dangerous for small children
However, the measles vaccination is only given from the age of eleven months at the earliest. Babies are therefore particularly at risk in the phase between nest protection and the first vaccination.
Measles viruses are neurotropic, meaning they cross the blood-brain barrier and affect the nervous system. About one in 1,000 children with a measles infection develops inflammation of the brain as a result. This can heal without consequences.
However, with a measles infection there is also the risk of a “slow virus disease”. These diseases are characterized by very long incubation periods and progression, and they are always fatal. Measles infection can lead to subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE). This disease occurs in children approximately five to ten years after the measles infection and affects the central nervous system (CNS).
“In SSPE, the brain is gradually converted into connective tissue,” says Professor Horst von Bernuth, head of immunology at the Charité Berlin. The disease always leads to death after three to five years over four different stages. Symptoms during the course of the disease include seizures, dementia and vegetative state. In around half of the SSPE cases, the measles infection occurred before the age of two.
According to the professional association of pediatricians, other consequences of a measles infection include a severely weakened immune system for six weeks, which can promote further infectious diseases. “After measles, for example, these children then develop severe pneumonia because they can no longer adequately defend themselves against bacterial pathogens that cause pneumonia,” says Professor von Bernuth. “This so-called immune amnesia after measles is probably responsible for the 100,000 to 200,000 measles deaths per year worldwide.”
Measles spreads through respiratory droplets and is one of the most contagious diseases in the world that can have serious long-term consequences. The measles vaccination is therefore very useful in protecting people from the disease and its possible consequences.
Risk of harm as a result of measles vaccination
Around five to 15 percent of those vaccinated have mild vaccination reactions to the measles vaccination after the first vaccination. These include redness and swelling at the injection site or fever. Around five percent experience a mild skin rash, but it is not contagious. After the second vaccination, the reactions listed only occur very rarely.
According to Section 2 of the Infection Protection Act, vaccine damage is “the health and economic consequence of damage to health caused by the vaccination that goes beyond the usual extent of a vaccination reaction”. These damages must be reported and can be viewed in the Paul Ehrlich Institute database.
(As of: October 3, 2023)

Guerre en Ukraine : Attention aux détournements du discours de Vladimir Poutine
Guerre en Ukraine : Attention aux détournements du discours de Vladimir Poutine
Publié le jeudi 23 février 2023 à 11:06
- Auteur(s)
Maïwenn Furic (20 Minutes)
Dans son discours annuel à la nation, mardi, le président russe n’a pas dit que la France avait peur d’affronter son pays. Il n'a pas non plus déclaré que l’Otan ne lui faisait pas peur, contrairement aux propos que des internautes lui attribuent
Mardi 21 février, à trois jours de l’anniversaire du début de la guerre en Ukraine, Vladimir Poutine a prononcé son discours annuel à la nation. Le président russe s’est longuement exprimé devant l’Assemblée fédérale, et a annoncé la couleur dès le début de son heure de monologue : « il y a un an, pour assurer notre sécurité, nous avons lancé une opération militaire spéciale en Ukraine. Nous allons atteindre pas à pas et méthodiquement nos objectifs chiffrés. » Les propos de Vladimir Poutine ont ensuite été détournés, à plusieurs reprises. 20 Minutes fait le point.
De nombreuses publications partagées sur les réseaux sociaux permettent d’avoir accès au discours du président Russe. Des vidéos qui émanent des chaînes de télévision telles que LCI ou France Info, qui ont leurs propres traducteurs. Pas de doute sur la fiabilité de ces vidéos. Ce qui pose problème, ce sont les descriptions jointes aux publications.
« Zelensky paiera pour sa trahison »
Vladimir Poutine n’a ni annoncé que le président Ukrainien était un traître, ni qu’il paiera pour cela. Comme l’a rappelé notre journaliste Cécile De Sèze dans son article, le patron du Kremlin a appelé à poursuivre les « traîtres » en Russie. « Ceux qui ont choisi de trahir la Russie doivent être tenus responsables devant la loi », a-t-il déclaré. Il a bien évoqué la présence de « traîtres » au sein même de son pays, mais pas à l’étranger. Il n’a donc, à aucun moment, associé ses propos à Volodymyr Zelensky.
Il n’a d’ailleurs jamais nommé explicitement le président ukrainien dans son discours. Il faut lire entre les lignes pour comprendre qu’il est évoqué à plusieurs reprises. Comme lorsque Vladimir Poutine avance : « Nous ne sommes pas en guerre contre le peuple de l’Ukraine, il est otage des propriétaires occidentaux qui occupent ce pays. »
« Nous sommes avec la Chine »
Vladimir Poutine n’a pas non plus affirmé que la Chine était son alliée. Si la Russie s’est retrouvée isolée sur la scène internationale après l’offensive lancée contre son voisin, elle a toujours conservé des liens étroits avec la Chine. Cependant, l’empire du Milieu a tenu a précisé que la Russie n’était pas son allié mais son partenaire.
Le ministre chinois des Affaires étrangères, Qin Gang, a déclaré ce mardi que la Chine était « très inquiète » du conflit en Ukraine. Et d’ajouter, lors d’une conférence à Pékin : « Nous continuerons à promouvoir le dialogue de paix (…) et à travailler avec la communauté internationale pour promouvoir le dialogue et la consultation. »
Mais, selon le secrétaire d’Etat américain, Antony Blinken, la Chine s’apprêterait à livrer des armes à la Russie pour mener sa guerre en Ukraine. L’information a depuis été démentie. Si elles advenaient, ces livraisons marqueraient une rupture majeure dans l’approche chinoise du conflit.
« L’Otan ne nous fait pas peur »
Vladimir Poutine a effectivement parlé de l’Organisation du traité de l’Atlantique nord (Otan) tout au long de son discours. Il a de nouveau accusé les Etats-Unis et l’Otan d’avoir orchestré le conflit pour rayer la Russie de la carte.
Selon le président russe, « avant même le début de l’opération militaire spéciale, Kiev négociait avec l’Occident des livraisons à l’Ukraine de systèmes de défense aérienne, d’avions de combat et d’autres équipements lourds ». Il a également dénoncé « des actions concrètes : le déploiement de l’Otan ou des contingents militaires » à la frontière russe. Mais dans son discours, il n’a pas déclaré ne pas avoir peur de l’organisation intergouvernementale. En revanche, il a prononcé ces mots en avril 2014, lors d’une séance de questions-réponses télévisée à Moscou.
« La France a peur de nous affronter »
Si le président Russe n’a pas directement nommé la France dans son discours, le pays était bien sûr visé à travers les différentes attaques faites aux Occidentaux et à l’Otan.
C’est l’ancien Premier ministre britannique, Boris Johnson, qui avait avancé, en novembre dernier, qu’Emmanuel Macron avait « peur de la Russie ». Actuellement, plusieurs personnalités politiques françaises le pensent aussi. En cause, l’attitude précautionneuse du président pour s’engager fermement aux côtés de l’Ukraine, contrairement à d’autres pays occidentaux. Le président français avait également déclaré qu’il ne fallait pas « humilier la Russie » : la formule ne passe pas auprès de certains.
Translation:
War in Ukraine: Beware of misappropriation of Vladimir Putin's speech
War in Ukraine: Beware of misappropriation of Vladimir Putin's speech
Published on Thursday February 23, 2023 at 11:06
- Author(s)
Maïwenn Furic (20 Minutes)
In his annual address to the nation on Tuesday, the Russian president did not say that France was afraid to confront his country. He also did not declare that NATO did not scare him, contrary to what Internet users attribute to him.
Tuesday February 21, three days before the anniversary of the start of the war in Ukraine, Vladimir Putin delivered his annual address to the nation. The Russian President spoke at length before the Federal Assembly, and announced the color at the start of his hour of monologue: “a year ago, to ensure our security, we launched a special military operation in Ukraine. We will achieve our quantified objectives step by step and methodically. » Vladimir Putin's words were then diverted several times. 20 Minutes takes stock.
Numerous publications shared on social networks provide access to the Russian president's speech. Videos from television channels such as LCI or France Info, which have their own translators. No doubt about the reliability of these videos. The problem is the descriptions attached to the publications.
“Zelensky will pay for his betrayal”
Vladimir Putin has neither announced that the Ukrainian president is a traitor, nor that he will pay for it. As our journalist Cécile De Sèze recalled in her article, the Kremlin boss called for the prosecution of “traitors” in Russia. “Those who chose to betray Russia must be held accountable under the law,” he said. He did mention the presence of “traitors” within his country itself, but not abroad. He therefore did not, at any time, associate his remarks with Volodymyr Zelensky.
He never explicitly named the Ukrainian president in his speech. You have to read between the lines to understand that it is mentioned several times. As when Vladimir Putin says: “We are not at war against the people of Ukraine, they are hostage to the Western owners who occupy this country. »
“We are with China”
Vladimir Putin also did not claim that China was his ally. If Russia found itself isolated on the international scene after the offensive launched against its neighbor, it has always maintained close ties with China. However, the Middle Kingdom made it clear that Russia was not its ally but its partner.
Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang said on Tuesday that China was “very worried” about the conflict in Ukraine. And added, during a conference in Beijing: “We will continue to promote peace dialogue (…) and work with the international community to promote dialogue and consultation. »
But, according to the American Secretary of State, Antony Blinken, China is preparing to deliver weapons to Russia to wage its war in Ukraine. The information has since been denied. If they occur, these deliveries would mark a major break in the Chinese approach to the conflict.
“NATO does not scare us”
Vladimir Putin actually talked about the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) throughout his speech. He again accused the United States and NATO of having orchestrated the conflict to wipe Russia off the map.
According to the Russian president, “even before the start of the special military operation, kyiv was negotiating with the West for deliveries to Ukraine of air defense systems, combat aircraft and other heavy equipment.” He also denounced “concrete actions: the deployment of NATO or military contingents” on the Russian border. But in his speech, he did not say that he was not afraid of the intergovernmental organization. On the other hand, he said these words in April 2014, during a televised question-and-answer session in Moscow.
“France is afraid of confronting us”
If the Russian president did not directly name France in his speech, the country was of course targeted through the various attacks made against the West and NATO.
It was the former British Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, who suggested last November that Emmanuel Macron was “afraid of Russia”. Currently, several French political figures also think so. In question, the cautious attitude of the president to firmly commit to the side of Ukraine, unlike other Western countries. The French president also declared that we should not “humiliate Russia”: the phrase does not resonate with some people.
