Factcheck: ja, dit is een recente foto van een verschroeid lijk nabij Charkiv
Op sociale media doet een foto van een lijk op een anti-tankobstakel de ronde. Volgens het bijschrift zou het gaan om een Russische soldaat ‘die levend in brand werd gestoken’ in Oekraïne. Onderzoek leert dat het om een recente foto uit Charkiv gaat. Of de man werd gemarteld en levend werd verbrand, valt op basis van online onderzoek niet te achterhalen, zo zeggen experten.
Deze factcheck is uitgevoerd op basis van de beschikbare informatie op de datum van publicatie. Lees hier meer over hoe we werken.
Op 9 april post het Telegramkanaal Kees71 twee foto’s van wat een verbrand lichaam van een Russische soldaat lijkt te zijn (hier gearchiveerd). Omdat het om harde beelden gaat, hebben we ze wazig gemaakt voor we ze in dit artikel hebben opgenomen. Het bijschrift op Telegram luidt: ‘Op Oekraïense sociale netwerken circuleert deze foto en wordt er gelachen om het dode lichaam van een Russische soldaat. Als je echter beter kijkt, zul je merken dat de Russische soldaat werd vastgeketend aan een stalen ‘egel’ (anti-tankobstakel), vervolgens werd gemarteld en daarna, zoals blijkt uit de foto, toen hij nog leefde, in brand werd gestoken. Dit zijn ISIS-methoden!’
Ook andere socialemediagebruikers gebruiken de foto om een vergelijking te maken tussen Oekraïne en de terreurgroep Islamitische Staat (IS of ISIS). In onderstaande tweet, die we ook wazig maakten omdat de getoonde beelden bijzonder expliciet zijn, zien we een screenshot uit een onthoofdingsvideo van IS. Op de onderste twee foto’s zien we het verbrande lijk, daarnaast een screenshot uit een video van IS, waar een persoon levend verbrand wordt in een kooi.
Uit onderzoek blijkt dat de foto van het verschroeide lichaam op 9 april om 21:20 voor het eerst werd verspreid via het officiële Telegramkanaal van Danill Bezsonov. Hij staat aan het hoofd van de persdienst van de ‘volksrepubliek’ Donetsk (hier gearchiveerd), een separatistische, door Rusland gesteunde regio in het oosten van Oekraïne. In de boodschap bij de foto’s beschuldigt ook Bezsonov het Oekraïense leger van IS-praktijken.
1,9 miljoen mensen zagen de foto. Ook in tal van andere Telegramgroepen en op Twitter- en Facebookaccounts werden de foto’s verspreid (hier, hier en hier gearchiveerd).
Gaat het hier om een echte recente foto uit Oekraïne? En klopt het dat de man levend werd verbrand, zoals in de post van Bezsonov wordt beweerd? Of werd zijn lijk in brand gestoken?
Als de persoon op de foto levend werd verbrand, dan kan die marteling volgens de Conventies van Genève een oorlogsmisdaad zijn (artikel 50). Als het gaat over het verbranden van een lijk, dan kan dat wel een schending van het oorlogsrecht (artikel 17) zijn, maar geen oorlogsmisdaad.
Echt?
Op Twitter vinden we een foto van hetzelfde lichaam vanuit een ander standpunt (links). Ook in een video op Twitter, gefilmd vanuit een auto, zien we hetzelfde lichaam op het einde (0:20) (rechts).
Het Oekraïense bijschrift bij de foto is ‘Ontmoet de Russische soldaat “Valera” (zoals lokale inwoners hem noemen), hij opende het strandseizoen in Oekraïne bij Charkiv’.
We nemen contact op met de auteur van het Twitterbericht. Hij zegt: ‘Nee, ik heb deze foto niet zelf genomen: ik vond hem per toeval op een sociaalnetwerksite.’
De persoon die de video online plaatste, reageert niet op onze berichten. In het filmpje horen we mensen in de auto vloeken in het Russisch. Ze zeggen ‘zich te amuseren in Charkiv’ en roepen al lachend ‘knapperd’, wanneer ze het lijk passeren. Dat bepaalde Oekraïners op sociale media lachen met het beeld, klopt dus.
Als we de schaduwen op de drie beelden vergelijken, blijkt dat die alle drie op verschillende tijdstippen werden gecapteerd. De zon stond eenmaal in het zuiden (links, foto genomen rond de middag), eenmaal in het zuidoosten (midden, foto genomen in de voormiddag) en eenmaal in het zuidwesten (foto genomen in de namiddag).
Omdat er beelden bestaan van drie verschillende bronnen die niet op hetzelfde moment werden gemaakt, kunnen we stellen dat het lichaam er voor langere tijd aanwezig was en dat het door verschillende mensen is opgemerkt. We zien een echt beeld.
We tonen de beelden aan de forensische experten Wim Van de Voorde (KU Leuven) en Geert Van Parys (UGent). Beiden zeggen dat ze zeker zijn dat het om een echt lichaam gaat.
Locatie?
De beelden op Twitter verwijzen beide naar Charkiv, de tweede grootste stad van Oekraïne, waar sinds het begin van de oorlog hevig wordt gevochten tussen Russische en Oekraïense troepen. Klopt die plaatsbepaling?
Vrijwilligers van het onderzoekscollectief Geoconfirmed, dat oorlogsbeelden tracht te lokaliseren, vinden de plaats waar de foto werd genomen. Dat blijkt aan een kruising van de autosnelweg E40 aan een checkpoint net buiten Charkiv. Wanneer we visuele elementen in de achtergrond van de foto (boven) vergelijken met de beelden van Google Streetview (onder), dan komen de stam van een boom (groen kader), een gebouw (gele kaders) en een verkeerslicht (rode kaders) overeen.
Wanneer?
De oudste foto van het lijk die we online konden vinden, dateert van 9 april. De foto dateert dus van 9 april of eerder.
Op 10 maart plaatste de Britse openbare omroep BBC een videoreportage over de oorlog in Charkiv online.
Het beeld van die reportage op 2:33 lijkt op de plek waar beelden van het lijk werden gemaakt. We vergelijken de video op Twitter (boven) met satellietbeelden van Yandex (midden) en de reportage van de BBC (onder). Twee tankstations (1 en 2), een rij anti-tankobstakels (3) en de plek waar het lijk zich bevindt (4) komen overeen.
We zien echter dat in de BBC-reportage het lijk niet zichtbaar is (4). Het lijk was er dus nog niet toen de BBC er filmde in de week van 10 maart. De foto dateert dus zeker van voor 9 april en van na begin maart.
Het is dus ook niet zo dat dit gruwelbeeld buiten beeld werd gehouden door de BBC-reporter. De journalist was ter plekke, maar toen was er op het anti-tankobstakel nog geen lijk.
Context?
Zowel in de Twittervideo als in de BBC-reportage zijn lijken op andere plaatsen zichtbaar. De BBC-reporter zegt (vanaf 2:45) dat het terrein ‘vol ligt met dode Russen’. Twee lijken bij het tankstation komen in beeld en hij zegt dat er verderop nog vier lijken liggen. ‘Dit zijn Tsjetsjenen, ze hebben identiteitsbewijzen bij zich.’
Op 21 maart publiceerde de Britse tv-zender Sky een reportage waarin vijf Russische lijken te zien zijn. Die lijken zijn in een Z-formatie gelegd, een logo gebruikt door de Russische strijdkrachten. Ook van deze beelden werd de locatie achterhaald: visuele elementen uit de reportage van Sky (boven), komen overeen met Google Streetview (onder). Daardoor weten we dat deze lijken op iets meer dan een kilometer van de onderzochte foto liggen.
Zowel BBC als Sky werden begeleid door het Oekraïense leger. Zij hadden dit stuk land dus in handen toen er werd gefilmd. Bovendien lag er een tiental lijken van Russische soldaten. Dat de foto dus een dode Rus toont die onder handen is genomen door Oekraïense troepen, is aannemelijk.
In een video op YouTube stelt het Oekraïense leger dat ze ‘Russische orks (spotnaam voor Russische soldaten, nvdr.) in massagraven leggen en bedekken met aarde, zodat ze geen lokale inwoners afschrikken’. De onderzochte beelden uit Charkiv maken duidelijk dat dit niet altijd het geval is.
Het lichaam op het anti-tankobstakel is deels ontkleed en behoorlijk onherkenbaar, op een wonde op de rechterarm na. We vergelijken het beeld met de lijken die zichtbaar zijn bij de BBC en Sky, maar vinden geen lijk dat het lijk op het anti-tankobstakel kan zijn.
Levend verbrand?
Werd het lichaam levend verbrand of werd het pas na het overlijden verminkt? We leggen de beelden voor aan de forensische experten Wim Van de Voorde (KU Leuven) en Geert Van Parys (UGent). Alleen op basis van de foto’s en de video kunnen ze geen sluitende uitspraken doen. ‘Daarvoor is een echte lijkschouwing nodig’, aldus Van de Voorde. Of de persoon in kwestie al overleden was voor hij werd verbrand, kan onmogelijk worden vastgesteld via foto’s. Zijn collega Geert Van Parys bevestigt: ‘Zoiets kun je onmogelijk uitwendig zien. Alleen een intern onderzoek, bijvoorbeeld van de luchtwegen, kan daarover uitsluitsel geven.’
Bepaalde elementen op de foto roepen bij beide experts vragen op. Zo merken Van de Voorde en Van Parys op dat er zowel naast als onder het lichaam heel weinig asse op te merken is. Van de Voorde: ‘Aangezien stukken van de kledij weggebrand zijn, zouden we daar normaliter onder en naast het lichaam verkoolde resten van moeten zien. Dat is niet het geval.’ Dat element suggereert dat de persoon niet op de plaats van het anti-tankobstakel werd verbrand, maar er achteraf werd geplaatst.
De lichaamshouding roept bij Van de Voorde nog andere vragen op. ‘Een mens die levend zou verbrand zijn zou zich niet in zo’n vredige positie bevinden. Als je levend in brand zou worden gestoken, dan zou je protesteren en dat zou je ook merken aan de lichaamshouding. Hier ziet het lichaam er opvallend vredig uit. Misschien was de persoon in kwestie al buiten westen toen hij werd verbrand, maar dat is dus allemaal speculatie.’ Volgens het bijschrift werd ‘de Russische soldaat vastgeketend aan een […]anti-tank obstakel, vervolgens […] gemarteld en daarna […] in brand […] gestoken’ Die volgorde lijkt dus niet te kloppen.
Daarnaast is het lichaam ook niet volledig verkoold. Van de Voorde: ‘Wat we zien, lijkt op verschroeiing, een kortstondige inwerking van hevige hitte. Een lichaam dat voor langer dan tien minuten in aanraking komt met een brand zou de zogenaamde bokserspositie aannemen, waarbij de armen en benen naar binnen plooien.’ Dat plooien ontstaat wanneer spieren door de hitte samentrekken. Dat zegt ook Van Parys: ‘Er is geen verregaande verkoling van het lichaam merkbaar. Bij een volledige verkoling is het lichaam volledig zwartgeblakerd en is niets nog herkenbaar. Dat is op deze foto niet het geval.’ Ook opmerkelijk: de (veters van) de bottines van de soldaat zijn niet gesmolten of weggebrand, net als de handschoen aan de linkerhand en de mouw aan de rechterarm. Beide experten achten het mogelijk dat het lichaam bijvoorbeeld met een vlammenwerper in contact kwam.
De wonde die te zien is aan de rechterschouder van het lichaam heeft volgens Van Parys en Van de Voorde niets te maken met de brand. ‘Daarvoor denk ik eerder aan de inslag van een granaat,’ zegt Van de Voorde.
Ook de witte strepen op de dijen roepen vragen op. Van Parys en Van de Voorde merken op dat het zou kunnen dat het lichaam werd overgoten met een chemische stof.
Zou het lichaam een van de lijken kunnen zijn die we zien op de beelden van Sky of BBC? Dat de persoon al langere tijd overleden zou zijn, sluit Van de Voorde volledig uit: ‘Dan zou de buik opgeblazen zijn, net als het gezicht. Er zou vergroening optreden en er zou rottingsvocht te zien zijn. Daarnaast zou zo’n lichaam volledig slap zijn en nooit in die positie kunnen blijven liggen waarin het zich nu bevindt.’
De foto van een lijk op een anti-tankobstakel is echt en dateert van maart of begin april 2022 in de Oekraïense stad Charkiv. Volgens het bijschrift zou het gaan om een Russische soldaat ‘die levend in brand werd gestoken’. Dat we het lichaam zien van een Russische soldaat is aannemelijk door de context van het beeld. Of de man werd gemarteld valt echter op basis van online onderzoek niet te achterhalen, zeggen experten. Voor de stelling dat de man ‘levend in brand werd gestoken’ vonden we geen bewijs.
In het artikel vindt u links naar alle gebruikte bronnen. Bovendien werden voor deze factcheck de volgende mensen gecontacteerd:
Mailconversatie en telefonisch gesprek met Geert Van Parys op 27 en 28 april 2022.
Mailconversatie en telefonisch gesprek met Wim Van de Voorde op 27 en 29 april 2022.
Alle bronnen werden laatst geraadpleegd op 4 mei 2022.
Meer informatie over de factchecks vindt u op de website van Knack.
U vindt onze factchecks ook terug bij deCheckers, samen met betrouwbare factchecks van andere Vlaamse redacties.
Knack is erkend lid van het International Fact-Checking Network (IFCN) en European Fact-Checking Standards Network (EFCSN).
Krasse uitspraak, straf cijfer of dito feit in de actualiteit gezien?
Vul uw vraag in op de website van deCheckers met exacte bronvermelding van het citaat of stuur het naar factcheck@knack.be.
Knack maakt onderdeel uit van Roularta Media Group.
Translation:
Fact check: yes, this is a recent photo of a scorched corpse near Kharkiv
A photo of a dead body on an anti-tank obstacle is doing the rounds on social media. According to the caption, it concerns a Russian soldier 'who was set on fire alive' in Ukraine. Research shows that it is a recent photo from Kharkiv. Whether the man was tortured and burned alive cannot be determined based on online research, experts say.
This fact check was carried out based on the information available at the date of publication. Read more about how we work here.
On April 9, the Telegram channel Kees71 posted two photos of what appears to be a burned body of a Russian soldier (archived here). Because these are hard images, we blurred them before including them in this article. The caption on Telegram reads: 'On Ukrainian social networks, this photo is circulating and people are laughing about the dead body of a Russian soldier. However, if you look closer, you will notice that the Russian soldier was chained to a steel "hedgehog" (anti-tank obstacle), then tortured and then, as can be seen from the photo, set on fire while he was still alive. These are ISIS methods!”
Other social media users are also using the photo to draw a comparison between Ukraine and the terrorist group Islamic State (IS or ISIS). In the tweet below, which we also blurred because the images shown are particularly explicit, we see a screenshot from an IS beheading video. In the bottom two photos we see the burned corpse, next to it a screenshot from an IS video, where a person is burned alive in a cage.
Research shows that the photo of the scorched body was first distributed via Danill Bezsonov's official Telegram channel on April 9 at 9:20 PM. He heads the press service of the Donetsk "people's republic" (archived here), a separatist, Russian-backed region in eastern Ukraine. In the message accompanying the photos, Bezsonov also accuses the Ukrainian army of IS practices.
1.9 million people saw the photo. The photos were also distributed in numerous other Telegram groups and on Twitter and Facebook accounts (archived here, here and here).
Is this a real recent photo from Ukraine? And is it true that the man was burned alive, as Bezsonov's post claims? Or was his corpse set on fire?
If the person in the photo was burned alive, then that torture could be a war crime under the Geneva Conventions (Article 50). When it comes to burning a corpse, this may be a violation of the laws of war (Article 17), but not a war crime.
Real?
On Twitter we find a photo of the same body from a different point of view (left). Also in a video on Twitter, filmed from a car, we see the same body at the end (0:20) (right).
The Ukrainian caption for the photo is 'Meet the Russian soldier “Valera” (as locals call him), he opened the beach season in Ukraine near Kharkiv'.
We will contact the author of the Twitter message. He says: 'No, I didn't take this photo myself: I found it by chance on a social networking site.'
The person who posted the video online is not responding to our messages. In the video we hear people swearing in Russian in the car. They say they are 'having fun in Kharkiv' and laughingly shout 'handsome' as they pass the corpse. It is therefore true that certain Ukrainians on social media laugh at the image.
Comparing the shadows on the three images, it appears that all three were captured at different times. The sun was once in the south (left, photo taken around noon), once in the southeast (center, photo taken in the morning) and once in the southwest (photo taken in the afternoon).
Because there are images from three different sources that were not taken at the same time, we can say that the body was there for a long time and was noticed by different people. We see a real picture.
We show the images to forensic experts Wim Van de Voorde (KU Leuven) and Geert Van Parys (UGent). Both say they are sure it is a real body.
Location?
The images on Twitter both refer to Kharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, where fierce fighting has been going on between Russian and Ukrainian forces since the start of the war. Is that location correct?
Volunteers from the research collective Geoconfirmed, which tries to locate war images, find the place where the photo was taken. This becomes apparent at an intersection of the E40 highway at a checkpoint just outside Kharkiv. When we compare visual elements in the background of the photo (top) with the images from Google Street View (bottom), the trunk of a tree (green frame), a building (yellow frames) and a traffic light (red frames) match. .
When?
The oldest photo of the body we could find online dates from April 9. The photo therefore dates from April 9 or earlier.
On March 10, the British public broadcaster BBC posted a video report about the war in Kharkiv online.
The image of that report at 2:33 resembles the place where images of the corpse were taken. We compare the video on Twitter (top) with satellite images from Yandex (middle) and the BBC report (bottom). Two gas stations (1 and 2), a row of anti-tank obstacles (3) and the place where the body is located (4) match.
However, we see that in the BBC report the corpse is not visible (4). So the body was not yet there when the BBC filmed there in the week of March 10. The photo certainly dates from before April 9 and after the beginning of March.
So it is not the case that this horror image was kept out of the picture by the BBC reporter. The journalist was on the spot, but there was no body yet on the anti-tank obstacle.
Context?
Bodies are visible in other places in both the Twitter video and the BBC report. The BBC reporter says (from 2:45) that the site is 'full of dead Russians'. Two bodies at the gas station come into view and he says there are four more bodies further down the road. “These are Chechens, they have IDs with them.”
On March 21, the British TV channel Sky published a report showing five Russian corpses. Those bodies were laid out in a Z formation, a logo used by the Russian armed forces. The location of these images was also discovered: visual elements from Sky's report (above) correspond to Google Streetview (below). This is why we know that these bodies are located just over a kilometer from the examined photo.
Both BBC and Sky were escorted by the Ukrainian army. So they owned this piece of land when filming took place. In addition, there were a dozen bodies of Russian soldiers. It is therefore plausible that the photo shows a dead Russian who has been taken care of by Ukrainian troops.
In a video on YouTube, the Ukrainian army states that they are 'putting Russian orcs (derogatory name for Russian soldiers, ed.) in mass graves and covering them with earth so that they do not scare off local residents.' The examined images from Kharkiv make it clear that this is not always the case.
The body on the anti-tank obstacle is partly undressed and quite unrecognizable, except for a wound on the right arm. We compare the image with the corpses visible on the BBC and Sky, but find no corpse that could be the corpse on the anti-tank obstacle.
Burned alive?
Was the body burned alive or mutilated only after death? We present the images to forensic experts Wim Van de Voorde (KU Leuven) and Geert Van Parys (UGent). They cannot make any conclusive statements based on the photos and video alone. “This requires a real autopsy,” says Van de Voorde. Whether the person in question had already died before being burned is impossible to determine from photographs. His colleague Geert Van Parys confirms: 'It's impossible to see something like that externally. Only an internal examination, for example of the respiratory tract, can provide a definitive answer.'
Certain elements in the photo raise questions for both experts. For example, Van de Voorde and Van Parys note that there is very little ash to be noticed both next to and under the body. Van de Voorde: 'Since pieces of clothing have been burned away, we should normally see charred remains under and next to the body. That is not the case.' That element suggests that the person was not burned at the site of the anti-tank obstacle, but was placed there afterwards.
The body position raises other questions for Van de Voorde. “A person who had been burned alive would not be in such a peaceful position. If you were to be burned alive, you would protest and you would notice that in your posture. Here the body looks remarkably peaceful. Perhaps the person in question was already unconscious when he was burned, but that is all speculation.' According to the caption, 'the Russian soldier was chained to an […] anti-tank obstacle, then […] tortured and then […] ] set on fire [...] set' So that order does not seem to be correct.
In addition, the body is not completely charred. Van de Voorde: 'What we see resembles scorching, a short-term effect of intense heat. A body that comes into contact with a fire for more than ten minutes would adopt the so-called boxer's position, where the arms and legs fold inward. This folding occurs when muscles contract due to the heat. Van Parys also says this: 'There is no noticeable charring of the body. With complete charring, the body is completely blackened and nothing is recognizable. That is not the case in this photo.' Also remarkable: the (laces of) the soldier's boots have not melted or burned away, nor have the glove on the left hand and the sleeve on the right arm. Both experts consider it possible that the body came into contact with a flamethrower, for example.
According to Van Parys and Van de Voorde, the wound that can be seen on the right shoulder of the body has nothing to do with the fire. “I'm more likely to think of the impact of a grenade,” says Van de Voorde.
The white stripes on the thighs also raise questions. Van Parys and Van de Voorde note that it could be that the body was doused with a chemical substance.
Could the body be one of the corpses we see in the Sky or BBC footage? Van de Voorde completely rules out that the person had been dead for a long time: 'Then the abdomen would be bloated, just like the face. Greening would occur and rotting fluid would be visible. In addition, such a body would be completely limp and could never remain in the position it is in now.'
The photo of a dead body on an anti-tank obstacle is real and dates from March or early April 2022 in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv. According to the caption, it concerns a Russian soldier 'who was set on fire alive'. That we see the body of a Russian soldier is plausible due to the context of the image. However, it cannot be determined from online research whether the man was tortured, experts say. We found no evidence for the statement that the man was 'set on fire alive'.
In the article you will find links to all sources used. In addition, the following people were contacted for this fact check:
Email conversation and telephone conversation with Geert Van Parys on April 27 and 28, 2022.
Email conversation and telephone conversation with Wim Van de Voorde on April 27 and 29, 2022.
All sources were last consulted on May 4, 2022.
More information about the fact checks can be found on the Knack website.
You will also find our fact checks at deCheckers, together with reliable fact checks from other Flemish editors.
Knack is a recognized member of the International Fact-Checking Network (IFCN) and European Fact-Checking Standards Network (EFCSN).
Have you seen a bold statement, penalty or ditto fact in current events?
Complete your question on the deCheckers website with the exact source of the quote or send it to factcheck@knack.be.

Fotografije prikazuju švedski muzej aviona i američko privatno skladište
Fotografije prikazuju švedski muzej aviona i američko privatno skladište
Objavio četvrtak 8 lipnja 2023 u 11:53
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Sva prava zadržana.
Ana PRIETO / AFP Argentina
Slike koje prikazuju muzej aviona i jedno skladište godinama kruže internetom uz netočnu tvrdnju da dokazuju kako su "hrana i piće koje je kabala pažljivo čuvala otkriveni u podzemnim bazama." Pojavile su se ponovno u objavi na srpskom postavljenoj na Facebooku sredinom studenoga 2022. godine. Međutim, AFP-u je muzej u Göteborgu u Švedskoj potvrdio da su slike "tunela" zapravo snimljene u muzeju, dok smo fotografiju skladišta pronašli na stranici jedne američke tvrtke za skladištenje. Vjerovanje u takozvane tajne podzemne tunele dio je teorija zavjere koje već godinama kruže Sjedinjenim Državama, a koja je dobila novi zamah pojavom mita Qanon 2017. godine.
U objavi postavljenoj na Facebooku 19. studenoga 2022. i podijeljenoj preko 570 puta u pet dana, tvrdi se da je "14,2 MILIJARDE TONA najkvalitetnije hrane ikada" pronađeno "u podzemnim bazama koje bi mogle prehraniti cijeli svijet." Objava sadrži četiri slike tunela i jednu fotografiju nekog velikog magazina ili skladišnog prostora. Na slikama se vidi natpis na engleskom "D.U.M.B.s Deep Underground Military Bases" ("Duboke podzemne vojne baze") i logotip YouTubea.
Te slike su uz istu tvrdnju podijeljene i na drugim jezicima, na primjer na španjolskom u srpnju 2022. godine, kao i engleskom, portugalskom i nizozemskom u lipnju.
Prve četiri slike prikazuju zrakoplovni muzej u Švedskoj
AFP-ov servis na španjolskom proveo je obrnuto pretraživanje svake slike u objavi, koje zajedno trebaju poslužiti kao dokaz navodne vojne baze. Prve četiri slike se nalaze u video snimci postavljenoj na YouTube 2009. godine (od 3:48 do 4:01).
Snimka pod naslovom "Razotkrivene podzemne baze američke vlade" prikazuje mnoštvo slika uglavnom loše kvalitete, na kojima se vidi nešto što nalikuje na tunele, parkinge za kamione, kanalizaciju, sobe s računalima, brodogradilišta, satelitske fotografije neimenovanih lokacija. "Uz veliku osobnu opasnost, obožavatelji radijske emisije Hala Turnera uspješno su se infiltrirali i fotografirali ogromne podzemne vladine objekte," piše u opisu snimke.
Turner je ekstremno desničarski američki radijski voditelj za kojeg Južnjački pravni centar za siromašne (SPLC - Southern Poverty Law Center), američki istraživački centar za desničarski ekstremizam, kaže (arhivirano ovdje) da promovira ideologiju nadmoći bijele rase. Osuđen je 2010. godine (arhivirano ovdje) zbog prijetnje ubojstvom trojici sudaca, zbog čega mu je tri godine zabranjeno da emitira radijske programe. Između ostalog, objavio je članke u kojima je negirao Holokaust.
Međutim, slike u videu koje su podijeljene i u objavi na Facebooku nisu snimljene u Sjedinjenim Američkim Državama, već u Švedskoj, u muzeju otvorenom za publiku.
Obrnuto pretraživanje slika preko ruskog pretraživača Yandex dovela je do stranice na Wikipediji s fotografijom koja prikazuje podzemni prostor koji izgleda vrlo slično onome na slikama koje se dijele na Facebooku. Prema opisu, snimljene su u Aeroseumu: muzeju posvećenom povijesti švedskog vojnog zrakoplovstva koji se nalazi u Göteborgu.
Nekoliko fotografija Aeroseuma koje su dostupne na Google kartama prikazuje isto okruženje kao tri slike u spornoj objavi, uključujući dizajn krova, žute kabine i ulaz.
Iz Aeroseuma su 30. lipnja 2022. potvrdili za AFP da te četiri slike odgovaraju podzemnom hangaru muzeja i da su vjerojatno snimljene između 2001. i 2003. godine, kada u tom prostoru nije bilo izloženih aviona ili helikoptera.
Navedeni hangar nije "miljama pod zemljom", kao što se tvrdi u snimci na YouTubeu, već 30 metara (arhivirano ovdje). Završen je 1955. godine (arhivirano ovdje) i nikada nije funkcionirao kao skladište hrane i pića, rekli su iz Aeroseuma.
Na donjoj slici prikazano je privatno skladište u Americi
Obrnuto pretraživanje posljednje slike iz netočnog posta na Facebooku dovelo je do stranice skladišta tvrtke Springfield Underground u Missouriju u Sjedinjenim Američkim Državama. Slika je naslovna fotografija na njihovoj mrežnoj stranici, stranici na Facebooku i profilu na LinkedInu. Slika je u studenom 2010. postavljena i na Google kartama.
Ta tvrtka nudi usluge podzemnog skladištenja na niskim temperaturama, tako da su mnogi njeni klijenti prehrambene tvrtke, kao što su Kraft Foods i Dairy Farmers of America. Neke tvrtke iznajmljuju prostor za skladištenje datoteka, a i internet provider Bluebird Network LLC je svoj podatkovni centar instalirao u tom podzemnom skladištu.
Skladište koristi prostor nekadašnjeg kamenoloma krečnjaka otvorenog 1946. godine. "Mi nismo državni objekt, već višegeneracijska obiteljska tvrtka koja pod zemljom skladišti proizvode poput sira," piše na mrežnoj stranici tvrtke.
Kao i hangar Aeroseum, skladišni objekti se nalaze nešto više od 30 metara ispod zemlje.
Nejasno je odakle brojka od "14,2 milijarde tona hrane i pića". Američka vlada skladišti hranu, na primjer sir, ali u pokušaju da podrži industriju i kontrolira cijene, kao i za distribuciju preko banaka hrane.
Opsesija tajnim podzemnim tunelima i objektima
Navodno postojanje podzemnih objekata i tunela koje u zlonamjerne svrhe koristi nedefinirana "elita" tema je koja se ponavlja u brojnim teorijama zavjere, posebno onim koje potječu iz Sjedinjenih Država. Ideja je ponovo popularizirana pojavom Qanona 2017. godine u SAD-u. Ova teorija zavjere (arhivirano ovdje) je stekla brojne sljedbenike posljednjih godina, uključujući pristaše bivšeg predsjednika Donalda Trumpa, u Sjedinjenim Državama i izvan njih (arhivirano ovdje).
Aric Toler iz Bellingcata, stranice specijalizirane za provjeru i istragu putem otvorenih podataka i koji je pratio razvoj teorije zavjere Qanon (arhivirano ovdje), rekao je za AFP u srpnju 2022. da su "DUMBS" o kojima se govori u netočnoj objavi na Facebooku "opsesija" za teoretičare zavjere.
Zračna luka u Denveru odbacila je 2020. godineteorije zavjere oko zgrade (arhivirano ovdje) i njenih navodnih tajnih tunela. AFP je opovrgnuo i tvrdnju da fotografija prikazuje dijete spašeno iz tajnih tunela u Australiji.
Ideja o podzemnim vojnim tunelima stekla je popularnost još 1995. zbog Phila Schneidera, čovjeka koji je, između ostalog, tvrdio da je sudjelovao u izgradnji ovih objekata, u kojima su radili i izvanzemaljski entiteti.
Sva prava pridržana. Bilo koje korištenje sadržaja AFP-a na ovim stranicama podliježe uvjetima uporabe dostupnim na https://www.afp.com/en/terms-use. Pristupanjem i/ili korištenjem bilo kojeg AFP-ovog sadržaja dostupnog na ovim stranicama pristajete na prije spomenute uvjete korištenja. Bilo kakva uporaba AFP-ovog sadržaja je pod vašom isključivom i punom odgovornošću.
Translation:
The photos show a Swedish aircraft museum and an American private storage facility
The photos show a Swedish aircraft museum and an American private storage facility
Posted on Thursday, June 8, 2023 at 11:53 am
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. All rights reserved.
Ana PRIETO / AFP Argentina
Pictures showing an airplane museum and a warehouse have been circulating the Internet for years with the false claim that they prove "food and drink carefully guarded by the cabal have been discovered in underground bases." They appeared again in a post in Serbian posted on Facebook in mid-November 2022. However, a museum in Gothenburg, Sweden confirmed to AFP that the pictures of the "tunnel" were actually taken at the museum, while we found a photo of the warehouse on the site of an American storage company. Belief in so-called secret underground tunnels is part of the conspiracy theories that have been circulating in the United States for years, which gained new momentum with the emergence of the Qanon myth in 2017.
A post posted on Facebook on November 19, 2022, and shared over 570 times in five days, claimed that "14.2 BILLION TONS of the highest quality food ever" had been found "in underground bases that could feed the entire world." The post contains four pictures of the tunnel and one photo of a large warehouse or warehouse. The images show the caption in English "D.U.M.B.s Deep Underground Military Bases" and the YouTube logo.
Those images were shared with the same claim in other languages, for example Spanish in July 2022, as well as English, Portuguese and Dutch in June.
The first four pictures show the aviation museum in Sweden
AFP's service in Spanish conducted a reverse search of each image in the post, which together are intended to serve as evidence of the alleged military base. The first four images are in a video uploaded to YouTube in 2009 (from 3:48 to 4:01).
The video, titled "U.S. Government Underground Bases Exposed," shows a slew of mostly poor-quality images showing what appear to be tunnels, truck parking lots, sewers, computer rooms, shipyards, satellite photos of unnamed locations. "At great personal risk, fans of Hal Turner's radio show successfully infiltrated and photographed massive underground government facilities," the video's description reads.
Turner is a far-right American radio host who the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC), an American think tank on right-wing extremism, says (archived here) promotes the ideology of white supremacy. He was convicted in 2010 (archived here) of threatening to kill three judges, for which he was banned from broadcasting radio programs for three years. Among other things, he published articles in which he denied the Holocaust.
However, the images in the video shared and posted on Facebook were not taken in the United States, but in Sweden, at a museum open to the public.
A reverse image search through the Russian search engine Yandex led to a Wikipedia page with a photo showing an underground space that looks very similar to the images shared on Facebook. According to the description, they were taken at the Aeroseum: a museum dedicated to the history of Swedish military aviation located in Gothenburg.
Several photos of the Aeroseum available on Google Maps show the same setting as the three images in the disputed post, including the roof design, yellow booths and entrance.
On June 30, 2022, the Aeroseum confirmed to AFP that the four pictures correspond to the museum's underground hangar and that they were probably taken between 2001 and 2003, when there were no planes or helicopters on display in that area.
Said hangar is not "miles underground" as the YouTube video claims, but 30 meters (archived here). It was completed in 1955 (archived here) and never functioned as a food and beverage warehouse, the Aeroseum said.
The picture below shows a private warehouse in America
A reverse search of the last image from the incorrect Facebook post led to the site of the Springfield Underground Company warehouse in Missouri, United States of America. The image is the cover photo on their website, Facebook page and LinkedIn profile. In November 2010, the image was also uploaded to Google Maps.
That company offers underground cold storage services, so many of its clients are food companies, such as Kraft Foods and Dairy Farmers of America. Some companies rent space for file storage, and Internet provider Bluebird Network LLC installed its data center in this underground storage facility.
The warehouse uses the space of the former limestone quarry opened in 1946. "We are not a state facility, but a multigenerational family business that stores products like cheese underground," the company's website says.
Like the Aeroseum hangar, the storage facilities are located a little more than 30 meters underground.
It is unclear where the figure of "14.2 billion tons of food and drink" comes from. The US government stocks food, for example cheese, but in an attempt to support industry and control prices, as well as for distribution through food banks.
Obsession with secret underground tunnels and facilities
The alleged existence of underground facilities and tunnels used for nefarious purposes by an undefined "elite" is a recurring theme in many conspiracy theories, especially those originating in the United States. The idea was popularized again with the appearance of the Qanon in 2017 in the US. This conspiracy theory (archived here) has gained a large following in recent years, including supporters of former President Donald Trump, in the United States and abroad (archived here).
Aric Toler of Bellingcat, a site specializing in verification and investigation through open data and who has followed the development of the Qanon conspiracy theory (archived here), told AFP in July 2022 that the "DUMBS" referred to in the inaccurate Facebook post " obsession" for conspiracy theorists.
In 2020, Denver Airport dismissed conspiracy theories surrounding the building (archived here) and its alleged secret tunnels. AFP also denied the claim that the photo shows a child rescued from secret tunnels in Australia.
The idea of ​​underground military tunnels gained popularity back in 1995 due to Phil Schneider, a man who, among other things, claimed to have participated in the construction of these facilities, in which extraterrestrial entities also worked.

By accessing and/or using any AFP content available on these pages, you agree to the aforementioned terms of use. Any use of AFP Content is at your sole and full risk.

VIDEO: Nej, her siger Joe Biden ikke, at homoseksuelle fylder sig med stoffer og er en parodi på naturens orden
-
En amerikanske præsident der siger, at homoseksuelle fylder sig med stoffer. Skuespillere der medvirker i film, de aldrig har optrådt i. Og pornofilm med personer, som slet ikke har været med i sexakterne
-
Den nye generation af manipulerede film, der også kaldes deepfakes, er så tæt på virkeligheden, at du ikke længere kan se forskel
-
De er lavet af computere med kunstig intelligens og får personer til at gøre og sige ting, de aldrig har gjort eller sagt
-
Den teknologiske udvikling har i dag gjort det meget svært at gennemskue, om en video pivfalsk. Her er 5 tips til, hvad du skal holde øje med
Kunstig intelligens er i den seneste tid blevet et varmt emne i den offentlige debat. Alle kan nu tage lang og dybe snakke med en chatbot, virksomheder kan få intelligente computere til at lave en masse manuelt arbejde. I Hollywood spreder frygten sig blandt skuespillerne. De er bekymrede for, at der skal blive lavet nye film, hvor de medvirker, selv om de aldrig har stået foran kameraet. Og hvem kan overskue konsekvenserne, hvis en magtfuld politiker pludselig dukker op i en manipuleret video og truer med krig?
Mens det tidligere var ret nemt at se, om en video var falsk, har kunstig intelligens skabt en helt ny og alvorlig virkelighed. Det er blevet let at lave manipulerede videoer, hvor det er nærmest umuligt med det blotte øje at spotte, om der er tale om misinformation. Sådanne videoer kaldes deepfakes.
I videoen herunder fortæller redaktionen dig om udviklingen. Vi giver dig også 5 tips til, hvordan du måske selv kan spotte, om du er ved at blive taget ved næsen af en deepfake-video skabt med kunstig intelligens.
Og i videoen kan du også se og høre, hvordan en deepfake-video får den amerikanske præsident Joe Biden til at sige noget om homoseksuelle, han aldrig har sagt. Men det er ikke lige til at se, hvis man ikke lige ved det.
Translation:
VIDEO: No, here Joe Biden is not saying that homosexuals fill themselves with drugs and are a parody of the order of nature
-
An American president who says that homosexuals get high on drugs. Actors starring in movies they've never appeared in. And porn movies with people who haven't been in the sex acts at all
-
The new generation of manipulated films, also called deepfakes, are so close to reality that you can no longer tell the difference
-
They are made by computers with artificial intelligence and make people do and say things they have never done or said
-
Technological development has today made it very difficult to see if a video is fake. Here are 5 tips for what to look out for
Artificial intelligence has recently become a hot topic in the public debate. Everyone can now have long and deep conversations with a chatbot, companies can have intelligent computers do a lot of manual work. In Hollywood, fear is spreading among the actors. They are worried that new films will be made in which they take part, even though they have never been in front of the camera. And who can foresee the consequences if a powerful politician suddenly appears in a manipulated video and threatens war?
While in the past it was quite easy to tell if a video was fake, artificial intelligence has created a whole new and serious reality. It has become easy to make manipulated videos, where it is almost impossible to spot with the naked eye whether it is a matter of misinformation. Such videos are called deepfakes.
In the video below, the editors tell you about the development. We also give you 5 tips on how you might be able to spot yourself if you are about to be taken by the nose by a deepfake video created with artificial intelligence.
And in the video you can also see and hear how a deepfake video makes US President Joe Biden say something about homosexuals that he has never said. But it's not easy to see if you don't know exactly.

© AFP / RTL-Grafik
Den Ukrain-Konflikt bréngt béid Säiten dozou, Falschinformatiounen iwwert de Géigner ze verbreeden. Zënter Kuerzem zirkuléiert eng Foto vun enger Hochzäit mam “Nazi-Grouss” a mam ukrainesche Fändel a sozialen Netzwierker. Wéi d’AFP erausfonnt huet, ass déi Foto e Fake.
“Sou bestit ee sech an der Ukrain!”, behaapt dësen Tweet, deen zanter dem 4. September bal 200 Mol mat enger Foto gedeelt gouf. Op dëser Hochzäitsfoto sinn zwee Gäscht ze gesinn, déi am Hannergrond den ukrainesche Fändel a Giel a Blo héichhalen, an aacht vun den néng Persounen, déi present sinn, dorënner d’Brautpuer, hiewen den Aarm a weisen den Nazi-Grouss.
Op Twitter (op Englesch oder op Franséisch hei oder hei) , op Facebook (hei, hei) an op Telegram ass d’Bild zanter Ufank September viral gaangen a gouf zesumme mat Messagë gedeelt, déi op eng “ukrainesch” Hochzäit hindeiten. D’Foto war schonn am Joer 2020 op Reddit opgedaucht, mat engem Kommentar, deen dorop higewisen huet, dass dat “just e ‘Sonne-Grouss’-Spill” wär, oder nach a russeschen Internetforen.
A Wierklechkeet gouf d’Foto awer modifizéiert, fir en ukrainesche Fändel anzebauen: De Fändel op der Originalfoto, vun där de Groussdeel ze gesinn ass, besteet aus zwou schwaarzen a giele Sträifen, déi warscheinlech de Fändel vum russeschen Imperium symboliséieren, gouf digital beaarbecht, fir déi ukrainesch Faarwe Giel a Blo ze weisen.
D’Originalfoto gouf zu Novokuznetsk a Russland fotograféiert an ass a Publikatiounen ze fannen, déi op d’mannst aus dem Joer 2017 stamen, laang virun der russescher Invasioun an der Ukrain um Ufank vum Joer 2022.
Well eng ëmgedréint Billersich mat der Sichmaschinn TinEye erméiglecht et, séier d’Originalfoto ze fannen, an déi eelst Verëffentlechung, déi ze fannen ass, datéiert op de 17. Oktober 2017.
Se gouf zu dësem Zäitpunkt op der russescher Meme-Websäit “Yaklapal” a spéider op anere Plattforme publizéiert. D’AFP konnt de geneeën Ursprong vum Bild net ermëttelen.
Capture d'écran effectuée le 6 septembre 2022 du site Yaklapal.com ( AFP Factuel / )
Et gesäit een direkt, dass de Fändel aus enger schwaarzer Sträif uewen an enger gieler Sträif ënnen zesummegesat ass an net aus Blo a Giel, wéi den ukrainesche Fändel. Déi viral Foto, déi hei ze gesinn ass, gouf manipuléiert, fir Schwaarz duerch Blo z’ersetzen.
Och wann den ënneschten Deel op der Originalfoto net ze gesinn ass, well e vum Brautpuer an de Gäscht verdeckt gëtt, änelt de Fändel staark dem russesche Fändel aus der Zarenzäit, deen tëscht 1858 an 1883 Schwaarz, Gold a Wäiss war an nieft dem russeschen Nationalfändel a Wäiss, Blo a Rout existéiert huet.
Eng Foto, déi a Russland geschoss gouf, an net an der Ukrain
Zanter hirer Verëffentlechung am Joer 2017 gouf d’Foto e puer Mol verifizéiert, wéi 2018 op dëser ukrainescher Noriichtesäit an a Bäiträg a Foren (wéi hei an hei) mat Verweiser op zwee englesch– a russeschsproocheg Tweets, déi déi retuschéiert Foto schonn 2018 iwwerpréift haten.
An de verschiddene Linken ass ze liesen, dass d’Foto net “ukrainesch Neonazien” weist, mee zu “Novokuznetsk a Russland mam Zarefändel” opgeholl gouf.
Den Tweet, deen d’Foto vun 2018 verifizéiert, enthält eng Foto, déi d’Gebai, dat op der Foto, déi viral goung, ze gesinn ass, identifizéiert, souwéi e Link zu enger touristescher Websäit, déi op de “Lenin-Monument” verweist a säi Standuert an der Stad Novokuznetsk ugëtt.
D’Gebai, dat op der viraler Foto hannert dem Lenin-Monument ze gesinn ass, befënnt sech an der Stad Novokuznetsk: Déi genee Geolokaliséierung, déi vun der touristescher Websäit matgedeelt gëtt, erméiglecht et engem, déi genee Positioun op Google Street View an eng Foto op Google Maps ze gesinn.
Wann een d’Fotografie, déi ënnersicht gëtt, mat dëse Biller vergläicht, erkennt een de Sockel vum Lenin-Monument an d’Fassad vum Gebai am Hannergrond. D’Bild gouf zu Novokznetsk a Russland, méi genee an der Lenin-Strooss 38 fotograféiert.
Comparaison d'une capture d'écran de l'image Google Street View à l'adresse “38 Ulitsa Lenina, Novokouznetsk, Oblast de Kemerovo”, et de la photographie d'un mariage prise au même endroit, originale et non retouchée, comportant un drapeau impérial russe et où les personnes figurant sur la photo font des saluts nazis. ( AFP Factuel / )
Zanter der russescher Invasioun an der Ukrain zirkuléieren a sozialen Netzwierker falsch Behaaptungen, dorënner reegelméisseg d’Rhetorik vum Kreml, no där d’Ukrain der Nazi-Ideologie verfall wär.
D’AFP huet eng Rei vu Faktenchecken iwwer neonazistesch Ideologie an der Ukrain oder iwwer d’Kleedung vum Wolodymyr Selenskyj, déi angeeblech Nazisymboler enthale soll, verëffentlecht. D’Iwwerpréiwunge vun der AFP iwwer de Konflikt an der Ukrain sinn ënner dësem Link ze fannen.
Dësen Artikel vun der AFP gouf vun RTL op Lëtzebuergesch iwwersat.
Translation:
© AFP / RTL-Grafik
The Ukraine conflict causes both sides to spread false information about the opponent. Since recently, a photo of a wedding with the "Nazi grandee" and the Ukrainian flag has been circulating in social networks. As AFP found out, that photo is a fake.
"This is how one succeeds in Ukraine!" claims this tweet, which has been shared almost 200 times with a photo since September 4. In this wedding photo, two guests can be seen holding up the Ukrainian flag in yellow and blue in the background, and eight of the nine people present, including the bride and groom, raise their arms and show the Nazi flag.
On Twitter (in English or in French here or here), on Facebook (here, here) and on Telegram, the picture went viral since the beginning of September and was shared together with messages that hint at a "Ukrainian" wedding. The photo had already surfaced on Reddit in 2020, with a comment pointing out that it was "just a 'sun big' game", or in Russian internet forums.
In reality, however, the photo was modified to include a Ukrainian flag: The flag in the original photo, of which the major part can be seen, consists of two black and yellow stripes, which probably symbolize the flag of the Russian Empire, was digitally edited, to show the Ukrainian colors yellow and blue.
The original photo was taken in Novokuznetsk, Russia and can be found in publications dating back to at least 2017, long before the Russian invasion of Ukraine at the beginning of 2022.
Because a reverse image search with the search engine TinEye allows you to quickly find the original photo, and the oldest publication that can be found is dated October 17, 2017.
It was published at this time on the Russian meme website "Yaklapal" and later on other platforms. AFP could not investigate the exact origin of the picture.
Screenshot taken on September 6, 2022 of the site Yaklapal.com ( AFP Factuel / )
You can immediately see that the flag is composed of a black stripe at the top and a yellow stripe at the bottom and not of blue and yellow, like the Ukrainian flag. The viral photo that can be seen here has been manipulated to replace black with blue.
Although the lower part is not visible in the original photo, because it is covered by the bride and groom and the guests, the flag strongly resembles the Russian flag from the Tsarist era, which was black, gold and white between 1858 and 1883 and next to the Russian national flag and White, Blue and Red existed.
A photo that was shot in Russia, and not in Ukraine
Since its release in 2017, the photo has been verified several times, such as in 2018 on this Ukrainian news site and in posts and forums (such as here and here) with references to two English- and Russian-language tweets that had already verified the retouched photo in 2018 .
In the various links it can be read that the photo does not show "Ukrainian neo-Nazis", but was taken in "Novokuznetsk in Russia with the Tsar's flag".
The tweet verifying the 2018 photo included a photo identifying the building seen in the photo that went viral, as well as a link to a tourist website referring to the "Lenin Monument ” refers and indicates its location in the city of Novokuznetsk.
The building that can be seen in the viral photo behind the Lenin monument is located in the city of Novokuznetsk: the exact geolocation provided by the tourist website allows one to find the exact position on Google Street View and a View photo on Google Maps.
If you compare the photograph being examined with these images, you will recognize the plinth of the Lenin monument and the facade of the building in the background. The picture was taken in Novokznetsk, Russia, more precisely at 38 Lenin Street.
Comparison of a screenshot of the Google Street View image at the address "38 Ulitsa Lenina, Novokuznetsk, Kemerovo Oblast", and the photograph of a wedding taken at the same location, original and unretouched, featuring a Russian imperial flag and where the people appearing on the photo give the Nazi salute. (AFP fact / )
Since the Russian invasion of Ukraine, false claims have been circulating in social networks, including the regular rhetoric of the Kremlin, according to which Ukraine has succumbed to Nazi ideology.
The AFP has published a number of fact checks about neo-Nazi ideology in Ukraine or about Volodymyr Selenskyj's clothing, which allegedly contains Nazi symbols. The reviews of the AFP on the conflict in Ukraine can be found under this link.
This article from AFP was translated into Luxembourgish by RTL.

Mehr als die Hälfte der Weltbevölkerung ist in diesem Jahr zu Wahlen aufgerufen. Doch finden die Abstimmungen wie geplant statt? In einem Blogbeitrag wird behauptet, die Weltgesundheitsorganisation (WHO) hätte jetzt weltweit Regierungen dazu angewiesen, bevorstehende Wahlen wegen des Vogelgrippe-Virus abzusagen. Diese Behauptung verbreiten Facebook-User auch als Screenshot. Doch stimmt das?
Für eine solche Aufforderung lassen sich keine Belege finden. Der Blogbeitrag verbreitet unbelegte Behauptungen einer US-Webseite, die bereits zuvor mit der Verbreitung von Fehlinformationen aufgefallen ist.
Fakten
Dem Blog zufolge soll die WHO weltweit Regierungen angewiesen haben, «die bevorstehenden Wahlen abzusagen und sich auf die Einführung strenger Lockdowns» vorzubereiten. Außerdem habe sie auf ihrer Webseite mitgeteilt, «dass die Vogelgrippe die nächste Pandemie werden wird und tödlicher sein wird als Covid», heißt es.Der Blog verlinkt dazu auf eine WHO-Mitteilung: Am 5. Juni 2024 meldete die Weltgesundheitsorganisation den weltweit ersten Todesfall eines Menschen, der mit einer im Labor bestätigten Vogelgrippe-Virus des Typs H5N2 infiziert war. Mehrere Laboranalysen konnten den Virustyp bei einem 59-Jährigen aus Mexiko nachweisen. Bisher hatte nur der Typ H5N1 der Vogelgrippe zu Todesfällen geführt.
«Auf der Grundlage der verfügbaren Informationen schätzt die WHO das derzeitige Risiko für die Allgemeinbevölkerung, das von diesem Virus ausgeht, als gering ein», schreibt die WHO. Von einer geforderten Absage von Wahlen, einem Lockdown oder Vergleichen mit der Corona-Pandemie ist in der Mitteilung keine Rede.
Für die angebliche Forderung lassen sich auch sonst keine Hinweise finden: Suchen auf der WHO-Webseite sowie nach Medienberichten liefern keine Belege. Die WHO reagierte auf Anfrage der Deutschen Presse-Agentur bisher nicht. Ein Sprecher erklärte jedoch zuvor gegenüber der Nachrichtenagentur Reuters, dass die WHO den Regierungen keine Anordnung zur Absage von Wahlen gegeben habe und auch nicht das Mandat dazu habe.
USA: Menschen und Kühe infizieren sich mit Vogelgrippe-Typ H5N1
Neben dem kürzlich gemeldeten Todesfall am Subtyp H5N2 gab es zuletzt Meldungen über eine Ausbreitung der Vogelgrippe-Variante H5N1 unter Milchkühen in den USA. In der Folge waren Infektion auch bei Menschen nach Kontakt mit Kühen registriert worden. Die Ansteckungen seien vermutlich durch direkten Kontakt mit infizierten Kühen erfolgt, nicht von Mensch zu Mensch.
Das Vogelgrippe-Risiko in den USA werde für Menschen derzeit als gering eingeschätzt, hieß es von der US-Gesundheitsbehörde CDC. Menschen mit engem Kontakt zu infizierten Tieren seien aber einem größeren Infektionsrisiko ausgesetzt. Für Menschen in Deutschland besteht dem Infektiologen Leif Erik Sander von der Berliner Charité zufolge derzeit kein Grund zur Sorge. In Deutschland wurde der Erreger weder in Kühen noch in Milch nachgewiesen.
Die Vogelgrippe – auch Aviäre Influenza genannt – wird wie die Grippe beim Menschen durch Influenza-A-Viren hervorgerufen, allerdings durch andere Subtypen. Derzeit grassiert die größte je dokumentierte Vogelgrippe-Welle, die sich über fast die gesamte Erde erstreckt und auch Europa betrifft. Der Erreger befällt vor allem Vögel, wurde aber zudem bei Säugetieren gefunden, darunter Katzen, Bären und Robben. Menschliche Infektionen mit der aktuell weltweit kursierenden Variante wurden bisher nur vereinzelt registriert.
Rund um das Thema kursieren online aber bereits Falschinformationen: So hat sich die Deutsche Presse-Agentur (dpa) erst Ende Juni in einem Faktencheck mit einer erfundenen Geschichte über neue WHO-Vorschriften im Zusammenhang mit der Vogelgrippe beschäftigt.
Immer wieder Desinformation über die Weltgesundheitsorganisation
Die Weltgesundheitsorganisation steht regelmäßig im Zentrum von Verschwörungserzählungen. Ihr wird immer wieder vorgeworfen, in die Souveränität einzelner Länder einzugreifen. Mehrere dpa-Faktenchecks konnten dies widerlegen.
Bei dem aktuell verbreiteten Blogbeitrag handelt es sich indes um eine Übersetzung eines Textes von einer US-Webseite: Ursprung der Falschbehauptung ist ein Beitrag von «The People’s Voice». Diese US-Webseite hieß vor der Umbenennung «Newspunch» und ist für die Verbreitung von Desinformation bekannt. Die Deutsche Presse-Agentur hat mehrfach von der Webseite verbreitete Falschinformationen in Faktenchecks widerlegt. Auch über die WHO setzte die Seite zuvor falsche Behauptungen in die Welt.
(Stand: 19.7.2024)
Translation:
More than half of the world's population is called to vote this year. But will the votes take place as planned? A blog post claims the World Health Organization (WHO) has now ordered governments around the world to cancel upcoming elections because of the bird flu virus. Facebook users also spread this claim as a screenshot. But is that true?
No evidence can be found for such a request. The blog post spreads unsubstantiated claims from a US website that has previously been noticed for spreading misinformation.
Facts
According to the blog, the WHO is said to have ordered governments around the world to “cancel the upcoming elections and prepare to introduce strict lockdowns”. It also announced on its website that “bird flu will be the next pandemic and will be more deadly than Covid,” it says. The blog links to a WHO announcement: On June 5, 2024, the World Health Organization reported the world’s first death of a person who was infected with a laboratory-confirmed H5N2 bird flu virus. Several laboratory analyzes were able to detect the virus type in a 59-year-old from Mexico. So far, only the H5N1 type of bird flu has caused deaths.
“Based on the available information, the WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus to be low,” writes the WHO. The communication makes no mention of a requested cancellation of elections, a lockdown or comparisons with the corona pandemic.
There is no other evidence to support the alleged claim: searches on the WHO website and media reports provide no evidence. The WHO has not yet responded to a request from the German Press Agency. However, a spokesman previously told Reuters that the WHO had not ordered governments to cancel elections and did not have the mandate to do so.
USA: People and cows become infected with bird flu type H5N1
In addition to the recently reported death from the H5N2 subtype, there have recently been reports of the spread of the H5N1 bird flu variant among dairy cows in the USA. As a result, infections were also recorded in humans after contact with cows. The infections probably occurred through direct contact with infected cows, not from person to person.
The US health authority CDC said that the risk of bird flu for humans in the USA is currently low. However, people who have close contact with infected animals are at greater risk of infection. According to infectiologist Leif Erik Sander from the Berlin Charité, there is currently no reason for people in Germany to worry. In Germany, the pathogen has not been detected in cows or milk.
Bird flu - also called avian influenza - is caused by influenza A viruses, like human flu, but by different subtypes. The largest wave of bird flu ever documented is currently raging across almost the entire world and also affecting Europe. The pathogen primarily affects birds, but has also been found in mammals, including cats, bears and seals. Human infections with the variant currently circulating worldwide have so far only been recorded sporadically.
However, misinformation is already circulating online about the topic: the German Press Agency (dpa) only carried out a fact check at the end of June with a made-up story about new WHO regulations in connection with bird flu.
Always disinformation about the World Health Organization
The World Health Organization is regularly at the center of conspiracy narratives. It is repeatedly accused of interfering with the sovereignty of individual countries. Several dpa fact checks were able to refute this.
The blog post currently being circulated is a translation of a text from a US website: the origin of the false claim is an article by “The People’s Voice”. This US website was called “Newspunch” before it was renamed and is known for spreading disinformation. The German Press Agency has repeatedly refuted false information spread by the website in fact checks. The site also previously made false claims about the WHO.
(As of: July 19, 2024)

Minden jog fenntartva. A weboldalon található AFP-tartalmak bármilyen felhasználására a https://www.afp.com/en/terms-use oldalon elérhető felhasználási feltételek vonatkoznak. A weboldalon elérhető AFP-tartalmak elérésével és/vagy használatával Ön elfogadja a fent említett felhasználási feltételeket. Az AFP-tartalmak bármilyen felhasználása az Ön kizárólagos és teljes felelősségére történik.
"A Lengyel köz TV, időjárás jelentése..Ukrajna egyes régióit, már át is csatolta.." – írja az a magyar Facebook-bejegyzés, amelyet 2023. január 17-i publikálása óta már több tucatnyian osztottak meg. A hamis kép már több más nyelven is terjedni kezdett, többek között angolul, németül, franciául, szlovákul és csehül.
A manipulált képen egy televízió képernyőjét látni, amelyen látszólag egy időjárás-jelentés megy. Az időjárás-jelentésben Lengyelország és a környező országok térképe látható, de úgy, hogy Ukrajna nyugati régiói lengyel területkén szerepelnek. A képen a TVP1 lengyel közszolgálati televíziós csatorna logóját látni.
A hamis képet az RT orosz állami média szerbiai kiadása is lehozta, valamint több orosz nyelvű weboldal is, például a Topwar.ru. Utóbbi oldal szerint ez az állítólagos időjárás-térkép utalás Lengyelország esetleges területi követeléseire.
A szerb RT cikke a kép alatt cirill betűkkel írva azt állítja, hogy a kép forrása a Topwar.ru oldal. A Topwar.ru viszont a "Pool No3" nevű Telegram-csatornát jelöli meg forrásként. Utóbbi csatorna valóban megosztota a hamis képet, a bejegyzést január 17-e óta csaknem kétszázezren tekintették már meg. A “Pool No3” a képhez fűzött bejegyzésben azt írja, hogy "nem tudják ellenőrizni" a képet, amelyet egy "feliratkozó" küldött.
Egy másik orosz oldal azt állítja, hogy a kép forrása egy Dmitrij Szmirnov nevű orosz újságíró. Szmirnovnak van egy "Pool No3" nevű Telegram-csatornája. A hamis posztot megosztó csatornát is így hívják, de két külön Telegram-oldalról van szó. A képet megosztó csatorna leírása azt írja: "a főoldal segédoldala", de az nem egyértelmű, hogy a Telegram-oldal valóban Szmirnové vagy sem. Szmirnov nyilvános közösségi média fiókjain nem találni a képet vagy a képpel kapcsolatos további információkat.
Az AFP megpróbálkozott egy fordított képkereséssel is, valamint különböző angol és orosz kulcsszavas keresésekkel a Google és a Yandex keresőmotorokkal, azt remélve, hogy sikerül további információkat megtudni az állítólagos időjárás-előrejelzésről. A közösségi médiában terjedő egyetlen képen kívül azonban nem találtunk más releváns anyagot. A kép további vizsgálata megmutatta, hogy a fotót manipulálták. A TVP lengyel közszolgálati televíziós csoport, amely állítólag az időjárás-jelentést sugározta, egy közleményben erősítette meg, hogy a kép hamisítvány, és soha nem adtak le ilyen anyagot.
Ha közelebbről megnézzük az állítólagos lengyel időjárás-előrejelzést, gyorsan észrevehetjük, hogy számos olyan nyomot látni rajta, amik megkérdőjelezik a kép hitelességét. Először is: több város és ország neve helytelenül van írva a képen, ami nem tűnik valószínűnek a lengyel közszolgálati média fő csatornája, a TVP1 időjárás-előrejelzésénél.
A lengyel nyelv a latin ábécé kibővített változatát használja, amely diakritikus jeleket is tartalmaz. Az interneten megosztott képen szereplő nevek nem a helyes betűket használják. Helytelenül "Lwow" szerepel "Lwów" (Lviv) helyett, "Kijow" szerepel "Kijów" (Kijev) helyett, "Bialorus" szerepel "Białoruś" (Belorusz) helyett , és "Slowacja" szerepel "Słowacja" (Szlovákia) helyett.
Továbbá, ha megnézzük a TVP1 valódi időjárás-előrejelzését, kiderül, hogy az időjárás-előrejelzésük arculata még csak kicsit sem hasonlít a hamis képen látottakhoz. A TVP1 általában egy zöld dizájnt használ, valamint sötétkéket az éjszakai jelentésekhez, ezek közül egyik sem hasonlít a fenti hamis képre:
Egy másik jel arra nézve, hogy a kép hamisítvány, néhány város elhelyezkedése. Az AFP egy valódi térképet vetített rá a hamis képre, így láthatóvá vált, hogy Varsó a hamis képen a valós helyzetéhez képest körülbelül 100 kilométerrel északnyugatra, majdnem Łódź városa fölé került.
Az időjárási térképeknek természetesen nem kell nagyon pontosnak lenniük, de a közszolgálati műsorszolgáltató főcsatornájának időjárás-jelentésében az ilyesmi igen szokatlan lenne. Az ukrajnai Lviv városa is furcsa helyre került, 80-90 kilométerrel északkeletre tolva a valós helyzetéhez képest.
A Google-ön lengyelül rákeresve arra, hogy “időjárás térkép Ukrajna TVP1" több olyan lengyel tényellenőrzést is találni, amelyek a képet hamisítványnak nevezik. A Google-keresés ezenfelül egy olyan január 18-i cikket is kiad, ami a TVP honlapján jelent meg "Az orosz propaganda kitalált térképet terjeszt" címmel.
A cikk azt írja az interneten terjedő állítólagos időjárás-előrejelzésről, hogy a TVP soha nem sugárzott ilyen anyagot. A TVP cikke szerint a kép hamisítvány, és a TVP1 logóját csak rászerkesztették a fotóra. A cikk azt is megjegyzi, hogy a hamis képen látható nő valójában egy másik televíziós csatornánál, a "Trwam"-nál dolgozik, nem pedig a TVP-nél.
Lengyelül rákeresve a Google-ön a "Trwam időjárási térkép" kulcsszavakra több olyan lengyel cikket is találhatunk, amelyek cáfolják a hamis időjárás-jelentést. Az egyik ilyen cikk egy 2020-as videót is linkel, amelyen a hamis képen is szereplő nőt látni, a videóban a nő "Joanna Wysocka" néven mutatkozik be.
A nő a 2020-as videóban ugyanolyan ruhát visel, valamint a körömlakkja és a sminkje is ugyanolyan, mint a hamis képen. A háttér viszont más: a videón a Trwam televíziós csatorna időjárás-előrejelzése látható a felvételen.
Ha jobban megnézzük ezt a 2020-as videót, 1 perc 11 másodpercnél látható, hogy a videóban szereplő nőnek nemcsak a ruhája, a körmei és a sminkje egyezik meg a hamis képpel, de még a testtartása, a hajviselete és a ruháján látható redők is pontosan ugyanúgy néznek ki:
Ezért igen valószínűnek tűnik, hogy valaki kivágta a bemondó képét a videóból, megfordította, majd hozzáadta a hamis képhez. A Trwam utóbbi időjárás-előrejelzéseit megnézve nem látni olyat, hogy ukrán területek Lengyelország részeként szerepelnének.
Az AFP küldött kérdéseket a Trwam televíziós csatornának az üggyel kapcsolatban, de a cikk megjelenésének időpontjáig nem kaptunk választ. Az nem világos, hogy a műsorvezető még mindig a Trwamnak dolgozik-e. A legutóbbi videó, amelyen látszólag ő szerepel, 2022 márciusából származik, de ebben a videóban eltérő családnévvel mutatkozik be.
Azóta, hogy Oroszország 2022 februárjában megtámadta Ukrajnát, számos olyan alaptalan állítás kezdett terjedni a közösségi médiában, amik azt a narratívát próbálják népszerűsíteni, hogy Lengyelországnak területi követelései vannak Ukrajnával szemben, vagy hogy az ország ellenségesen tekint keleti szomszédjára.
2022 májusában például egy olyan 2014-es térkép kezdett el terjedni, ami Vlagyimir Zsirinovszkij, az orosz Állami Duma korábbi politikusának Ukrajna felosztására tett javaslatát illusztrálta. A kép azzal a hamis állítással terjedt az interneten 2022-ben, hogy lengyel terveket mutat Ukrajna feldarabolására.
Egy olyan alaptalan hamis állítás is terjedni kezdett az interneten, amely szerint NGO-kat bíztak meg azzal, hogy mérjék fel, mit szólnának az ukránok ahhoz, ha a nyugat-volhíniai és lvivi területeket (amelyek korábban Lengyelország részét képezték) "lengyel protektorátus" alá helyeznék.
Egy másik, az AFP által cáfolt hamis narratívát a kémkedésért elítélt volt jobbikos képviselő, Kovács Béla is aktívan terjesztette. A hamis történet azt állította, hogy népszavazást fognak tartani Kárpátalja függetlenné válásáról vagy Magyarországhoz történő csatolásáról.
Más félrevezető állítások az Ukrajna és Lengyelország közötti történelmi sérelmekre próbáltak fókuszálni, mint amilyen például Sztepan Bandera személye. Banderát sok ukrán nemzeti hősként tartja számon, de Lengyelországban és Oroszországban Bandera bűnözőnek és náci kollaboránsnak számít, aki többek között a volhíniai mészárlásért és a zsidó lakosság elleni bűncselekményekért felelős.
Bár igaz, hogy a mai Ukrajna egyes területei évszázadokon keresztül lengyel fennhatóság alatt álltak, a modern Lengyelország hozzáállása az ukrajnai háborúhoz azt mutatja, hogy jelenleg Varsó Ukrajna egyik legszorosabb nyugati szövetségese az Oroszország elleni harcban. Lengyelország az EU többi tagjával együtt már a háború kezdetén világossá tette, hogy elítéli Ukrajna szuverenitásának és területi integritásának megsértését. Morawiecki lengyel miniszterelnök rendszeresen az Ukrajnának szánt támogatások leghangosabb szószólója a nyugati vezetők között.

By accessing and/or using the AFP content available on the website, you accept the aforementioned terms of use. Any use of the AFP Content is at your sole and complete risk.
"Lengyel köz TV, weather report..some regions of Ukraine, has already been linked..." - says the Hungarian Facebook post, which has already been shared by dozens of people since its publication on January 17, 2023. The fake image has already started to spread in several other languages, including English, German, French, Slovak and Czech.
The manipulated image shows a television screen showing what appears to be a weather report. The weather report shows a map of Poland and the surrounding countries, but with the western regions of Ukraine listed as Polish territory. In the picture you can see the logo of the Polish public television channel TVP1.
The fake image was also carried by the Serbian edition of the Russian state media RT, as well as several Russian-language websites, such as Topwar.ru. According to the latter site, this alleged weather map is a reference to Poland's possible territorial claims.
The Serbian RT article, written in Cyrillic letters under the picture, claims that the source of the picture is Topwar.ru. Topwar.ru, on the other hand, identifies a Telegram channel called "Pool No3" as the source. The latter channel actually shared the fake image, the post has already been viewed by almost two hundred thousand people since January 17. "Pool No3" says in the post attached to the image that they "cannot verify" the image, which was sent by a "subscriber".
Another Russian site claims that the source of the image is a Russian journalist named Dmitry Smirnov. Smirnov has a Telegram channel called "Pool No3". The channel sharing the fake post is also called the same, but they are two separate Telegram pages. The description of the channel that shared the image says "an auxiliary page of the main page", but it is not clear whether the Telegram page is actually Smirnov's or not. No image or additional information about the image could be found on Smirnov's public social media accounts.
AFP also tried a reverse image search and various English and Russian keyword searches with Google and Yandex search engines, hoping to find more information about the alleged weather forecast. However, apart from a single image circulating on social media, we found no other relevant material. Further examination of the image revealed that the photo had been tampered with. Polish public television group TVP, which reportedly aired the weather report, confirmed in a statement that the image was a fake and that no such material had ever been broadcast.
If you take a closer look at the alleged Polish weather forecast, you will quickly notice that there are a number of clues that call into question the authenticity of the image. First of all: the names of several cities and countries are misspelled in the image, which does not seem likely for the weather forecast of TVP1, the main channel of Polish public service media.
The Polish language uses an extended version of the Latin alphabet, which also includes diacritical marks. The names in the picture shared on the Internet do not use the correct letters. Incorrectly, "Lwow" is substituted for "Lwów" (Lviv), "Kijow" is substituted for "Kijów" (Kiev), "Bialorus" is substituted for "Białoruś" (Belarus), and "Slowacja" is substituted for "Słowacja" (Slovakia).
Also, if you look at TVP1's real weather forecast, it turns out that the appearance of their weather forecast doesn't even remotely resemble what you see in the fake picture. TVP1 usually uses a green design as well as dark blue for night reports, neither of which look like the fake image above:
Another sign that the image is fake is the location of some cities. AFP projected a real map onto the fake image, showing that Warsaw was placed in the fake image about 100 kilometers northwest of its real position, almost above the city of Łódź.
Of course, weather maps don't have to be very accurate, but something like that would be very unusual in a weather report on a public broadcaster's main channel. The city of Lviv in Ukraine was also placed in a strange place, pushed 80-90 kilometers to the northeast compared to its real position.
Searching "weather map Ukraine TVP1" on Google in Polish, you can find several Polish fact-checkers who call the image a fake. The Google search also shows an article from January 18, which was published on TVP's website " Russian propaganda spreads fictional map"
The article says about the alleged weather forecast circulating on the Internet that TVP has never broadcast such material. According to the TVP article, the photo is a fake, and the TVP1 logo was just edited onto the photo. The article also notes that the woman in the fake picture actually works for another television channel, "Trwam", and not TVP.
Searching in Polish for the keywords "Trwam weather map" you can find several Polish articles refuting the fake weather report. One such article also links to a 2020 video showing the woman in the fake photo, in which she introduces herself as "Joanna Wysocka".
The woman in the 2020 video is wearing the same clothes, nail polish and makeup as in the fake photo. The background, however, is different: the video shows the weather forecast of the Trwam television channel.
If you take a closer look at this 2020 video, at 1 minute 11 seconds, you can see that not only does the woman in the video have her clothes, nails, and makeup match the fake image, but even her posture, hair style, and folds on her dress are exactly the same. they look the same:
Therefore, it seems very likely that someone cut the announcer's image from the video, flipped it, and then added it to the fake image. Looking at Trwam's latest weather forecasts, there is no indication that Ukrainian territories are part of Poland.
AFP sent questions to the Trwam television channel about the matter, but no response was received by the time of publication. It is unclear if the presenter is still working for Trwam. The most recent video apparently featuring him is from March 2022, but in this video he is introduced under a different family name.
Since Russia invaded Ukraine in February 2022, a number of unsubstantiated claims have started circulating on social media that attempt to promote the narrative that Poland has territorial claims against Ukraine or that the country views its eastern neighbor with hostility.
In May 2022, for example, a map from 2014 began to spread, which illustrated the proposal of Vladimir Zhirinovsky, a former politician of the Russian State Duma, to divide Ukraine. The image spread on the Internet in 2022 with the false claim that it showed Polish plans to dismember Ukraine.
A baseless false claim also began to spread on the Internet, according to which NGOs were commissioned to assess how Ukrainians would react to the transfer of the territories of Western Volhynia and Lviv (which used to be part of Poland) to a "Polish protectorate". would place
Another false narrative refuted by the AFP was also actively disseminated by former Jobbik representative Béla Kovács, who was convicted of espionage. The false story claimed that a referendum would be held on the independence of Subcarpathia or its annexation to Hungary.
Other misleading claims tried to focus on historical grievances between Ukraine and Poland, such as the person of Stepan Bandera. Bandera is considered a national hero by many Ukrainians, but in Poland and Russia Bandera is considered a criminal and Nazi collaborator, responsible for the Volhynia massacre and crimes against the Jewish population, among other things.
While it is true that some areas of today's Ukraine were under Polish rule for centuries, modern Poland's attitude to the war in Ukraine shows that Warsaw is currently one of Ukraine's closest Western allies in the fight against Russia. Poland, along with other EU members, made it clear at the beginning of the war that it condemned the violation of Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity. Polish Prime Minister Morawiecki is regularly the loudest advocate of aid to Ukraine among Western leaders.
