„Egyértelmű nem a háborúra, no war!”
- ez volt az idei Békemenet üzenete a kormánypárti eseményt szervező Civil Összefogás Fórum (CÖF) szerint. A március 15-i vonulást megelőző hetekben a szervezet hírportálján, a 2022plusz oldalon több cikkben is foglalkoztak a háborúval.
Ezekben a cikkben azonban gyakran kritika nélkül közvetítik Putyin háborús narratíváját és relativizálják az orosz fél felelősségét.
Például a Békemenet előtt egy nappal, március 14-én posztolt
véleménycikkben:
„Most Putyin tart görbe tükröt a nyugati világnak, s a helyzet az, hogy mindegy, mit gondolunk arról, jogosan teszi-e vagy sem. Nem segítünk vele az áldozatokon, és nem támasztjuk fel a halottakat. Elítélhetjük, persze. Bár ha mélyen a tükörbe nézünk, talán elsuttogjuk azt is, hogy erkölcsi alapunk elítélni csak akkor volna, ha valamennyi katonai agressziót elítéltünk volna, függetlenül az elkövető kilététől” - írja a cikk.
De mi is ez a 2022plusz?
A tavaly tavasszal indított
hírportálon a legkülönfélébb témákban jelennek meg írások, napi hírektől a véleménycikkekig, de „Állami terror 2006” rovatuk is van. A portál szerzői saját cikkeket is publikálnak, de sok esetben szemléznek más, többségében kormányközeli újságból vett írásokat is (Magyar Nemzet, Origo, Demokrata, Pesti Srácok stb.).
Az újság kiadója a Kövess minket 2022 Kft. A Kft. tulajdonosa a CÖKA, azaz a Civil Összefogás Közhasznú Alapítvány, a Civil Összefogás Fórum (CÖF) mögött álló szervezet. A nyíltan kormánypárti CÖF és CÖKA az elmúlt években
több száz millió forint állami támogatást kapott. A Kövess minket 2022 Kft. pedig nemcsak újságkiadással foglalkozik: a “STOP Gyurcsány, STOP Karácsony” plakátokat például
hivatalosan nem a Fidesz, hanem a Kövess minket 2022 Kft. terjesztette.
A CÖF alapítója, Csizmadia László már az oldal indulásakor, „Az őszinteség portálja” című cikkében
egyértelművé tette, hogy a 2022plusz sem szeretne szakítani a kormánypárti narratívával: „Portálunk és a mellette működtetett facebook oldalunk a zsidó-keresztény civilizáció hagyományain állva, a tízparancsolat intelmeire figyelemmel szeretné tájékoztatni kedves követőit. Feladatunknak tekintjük, hogy az ellenzéki oldalon jelentkező mohó hataloméhséget a megfelelő mederbe tereljük, tükröt állítva vezető politikusok elé.”
A CÖF és a háború
A 2022plusz a jelenleg Ukrajnában folyó háború kapcsán is a magyar kormány üzeneteit ismétli: elsősorban azt, hogy hogy a baloldal és Márki-Zay Péter ellenzéki miniszterelnök-jelölt fegyvereket és magyar katonákat küldene Ukrajnába. A
Lakmuszon azonban részletesen foglalkoztunk a kérdéssel, amiből látszik, hogy Márki-Zay valójában azt mondta, hogy a NATO-t követnék, amely inkább kimaradna a háborúból.
A hírportál Szijjártót Péter külügyminisztert is idézi, aki szerint
“Az Ukrajnából menekülők és az illegális migránsok között nem lehet párhuzamot vonni”. A Lakmuszon azt is
bemutattuk, miért leegyszerűsítő ez a narratíva.
Békemenet, Budapest, 2022. március 15. (Fotó: Halász Júlia, 444.hu)
A 2022plusz azonban nemcsak a magyar kormányzat, hanem sok esetben az orosz vezetés üzeneteit is kritika nélkül veszi át.
Március 11-én például a
Moszkvatér portál Jevgenyij Arnoldovics Sztanyiszlavov orosz nagykövettel készített interjúját szemlézték „
A különleges művelet nem eufemizmus, Ukrajna indított háborút” címen. A nagykövet ebben azt fejtegeti, hogy a jelenleg zajló konfliktus valójában nem más, mint Oroszország „önvédelme”, az oroszok „csak a népet védik, akik az elmúlt nyolc évben a kijevi rezsim zaklatásának és népirtásnak volt kitéve.”
Egy február végén publikált véleménycikkben a 2022plusz szerzője jelentette ki, hogy - a putyini narratívával összhangban - szerinte is
népirtás történt Donbaszban. Putyin a háborút megelőző hosszú televíziós beszédében mondta azt, hogy véget kell vetni a kelet-Ukrajnában zajló népirtásnak. A Lakmuszon már többször is foglalkoztunk a kérdéssel (
itt és
itt): tény, hogy 2014 óta jelentős konfliktusok dúlnak Ukrajna keleti részén, azonban ezt az
ENSZ Genocídium-egyezményének definíciója alapján nem minősül népirtásnak.
A 2022plusz a háború kirobbanása után több mint egy héttel azt is megírta, hogy „
Putyinban egyre jobban bíznak az oroszok”. A hírportál a
Magyar Nemzet és a
Mandiner cikkeit vette alapul, amelyekben megírták, hogy “hivatalos állami felmérések szerint az oroszok 70 százaléka helyesnek tartja, hogy Moszkva csapatokat küldött Ukrajnába”, bár azt is megjegyzik, hogy “ezeknek a felméréseknek nem kell feltétlenül hinni, mert manipuláltak lehetnek”.
Álhírnek is bedőltek
A magyar kormány és az orosz vezetés üzeneteinek közvetítése mellett a 2022plusz híportál több, a
nyugati médiát kritizáló cikket is közölt - ezek közt pedig hamis hírről is beszámoltak. „
Így hazudik a CNN, csak a szokásos…” című cikkükben azt írják, hogy CNN-es Twitter-fiókok kétszer is beszámoltak ugyanannak az amerikai férfinak a haláláról, de eltérő körülmények között: az egyik fiók szerint Afganisztánban, a másik szerint pedig Ukrajnában halt meg. A hír forrásaként többek közt Bayer Zsolt kormánypárti publicista
blogját jelölték meg.
A hamis állítást tartalmazó Facebook-poszt, a piros x-et az AFP adta a képhez.
A képernyőkép 2022. február 28-án készült.
Azonban mind a CÖF hírportálja, mind Bayer Zsolt egy hamis hírnek dőlt be: ahogy az AFP tényellenőrzése alapján a Lakmuszon is
megírtuk, az idézett Twitter-fiókok nem a CNN-hez tartoznak, a Twitter pedig fel is függesztette őket. A képen látható férfi egy videójáték-streamer, aki jelenleg is aktív az interneten.
E-mailben kérdeztük a Kövess minket 2022 Kft.-t, hogy milyen szerkesztői megfontolásból döntöttek a fenti cikkek publikálása mellett. Ha kapunk választ, frissítjük a cikket.
Címlapi kép: Halász Júlia, 444.hu
Translation:
"Clear no to war, no war!"
- this was the message of this year's Peace Procession, according to the Civil Unity Forum (CÖF), which organized the government event. In the weeks before the march on March 15, the organization's news portal, the 2022plus page, covered the war in several articles.
However, in these articles they often relay Putin's war narrative without criticism and relativize the responsibility of the Russian side.
For example, he posted on March 14, one day before the Peace March
in an opinion piece:
"Now Putin is holding up a crooked mirror to the Western world, and the situation is that it doesn't matter what we think about whether he is doing it rightly or not. We do not help victims with it, and we do not raise the dead. We can condemn it, of course. Although if we look deeply into the mirror, we might also whisper that we would only have a moral basis to condemn if we had condemned all military aggression, regardless of the identity of the perpetrator," the article says.
But what is this 2022plus?
It was launched last spring
news portal features articles on a wide variety of topics, from daily news to opinion pieces, but they also have a "State Terror 2006" column. The authors of the portal also publish their own articles, but in many cases they also review articles from other, mostly government-related newspapers (Magyar Nemzet, Origo, Demokrata, Pesti Srácok, etc.).
The publisher of the newspaper is Kövess nimes 2022 Kft. The owner of the Kft. is CÖKA, i.e. Civil Összefogás Közhaznú Alapítvány, the organization behind the Civil Összefogás Fórum (CÖF). The openly pro-government CÖF and CÖKA have been in recent years
received hundreds of millions of forints in state aid. Follow us 2022 Kft. is not only involved in newspaper publishing: the "STOP Gyurcsány, STOP Christmas" posters, for example
it was not officially distributed by Fidesz, but by Follow us 2022 Kft.
The founder of CÖF, László Csizmadia, already at the start of the site, in his article entitled "Portal of Honesty"
made it clear that 2022plus does not want to break with the government's narrative either: "Our portal and the Facebook page operated alongside it are based on the traditions of Judeo-Christian civilization and want to inform their dear followers in accordance with the ten commandments. We see it as our task to channel the greedy hunger for power on the opposition side into the right direction, holding up a mirror to leading politicians."
The CÖF and the war
2022plus also repeats the Hungarian government's messages regarding the current war in Ukraine: first of all, that the left and opposition prime minister candidate Péter Márki-Zay would send weapons and Hungarian soldiers to Ukraine. THE
However, we dealt with the issue in detail on the litmus test, which shows that Márki-Zay actually said that they would follow NATO, which would rather stay out of the war.
The news portal also quotes Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártót, who says that
"You cannot draw parallels between those fleeing Ukraine and illegal migrants". On Litmus, too
we have shown why this narrative is simplistic.
Peace March, Budapest, March 15, 2022 (Photo: Júlia Halász, 444.hu)
However, 2022plus accepts the messages not only of the Hungarian government, but also of the Russian leadership in many cases without criticism.
On March 11, for example,
Moskvatér portal watched the interview with the Russian ambassador Yevgeny Arnoldovich Stanislavov "
The special operation is not a euphemism, Ukraine started a war. In this, the ambassador explains that the current conflict is actually nothing more than Russia's "self-defense", the Russians are "only protecting the people who have been subjected to harassment and genocide by the Kiev regime for the past eight years."
In an opinion article published at the end of February, the author of 2022plus stated that - in line with Putin's narrative - he also
genocide took place in Donbass. In a long televised speech before the war, Putin said that the genocide in eastern Ukraine must end. At Litmus, we have dealt with the question several times (
here and
here): it is a fact that significant conflicts have been raging in the eastern part of Ukraine since 2014, but this is it
Based on the definition of the UN Genocide Convention, it does not qualify as genocide.
More than a week after the outbreak of the war, 2022plus also wrote that “
Russians trust Putin more and more". The news portal a
Hungarian Nation and the
It was based on Mandiner's articles, in which they wrote that "according to official state surveys, 70 percent of Russians believe that it is correct that Moscow sent troops to Ukraine", although they also note that "these surveys should not necessarily be believed, because they may be manipulated".
They also fell for fake news
In addition to broadcasting the messages of the Hungarian government and the Russian leadership, the 2022plus news portal does more, a
also published an article criticizing the Western media - and among these, fake news was also reported. "
This is how CNN lies, just the usual…” they write that CNN Twitter accounts reported the death of the same American man twice, but under different circumstances: according to one account, he died in Afghanistan, and according to the other, he died in Ukraine . The source of the news is, among others, government publicist Zsolt Bayer
your blog has been tagged.
The Facebook post containing the false claim, the red x, was added to the image by AFP.
The screenshot was taken on February 28, 2022.
However, both CÖF's news portal and Zsolt Bayer fell for a fake news: just as, based on AFP's fact-checking, also on Litmus
we wrote, the quoted Twitter accounts do not belong to CNN, and Twitter has suspended them. The man in the picture is a video game streamer who is currently active online.
We asked Follow Us 2022 Kft. by e-mail what editorial considerations they used to decide to publish the above articles. If we receive an answer, we will update the article.
Cover photo: Júlia Halász, 444.hu

Nei, denne videoen er ikke ny
Påstand
Israelere tok over Ibrahim-moskéen på søndag [1. oktober 2023].
Konklusjon
Videoen er ekte, men er ikke tatt opp under den pågående krigen. Den viser ikke en musikkfestival, men i stedet feiring av jødisk selichot. Bruken av moskeen er en del av en delingsavtale mellom jøder og muslimer, som begge anser området for å være hellig.
De seneste dagene har mange delt en video av jøder som danser i en moské i Hebron på Vestbredden, som ifølge FN er et israelsk-okkupert palestinsk område.
«Israelere tok over Ibrahim-moskeen på søndag», skrives det. Muslimer skal ha blitt nektet adgang, og bosettere skal ha avholdt en musikkfestival. Dette skal altså ha skjedd samtidig som palestinske barn og sivile dør på Gaza.
Selve videoen er ekte, men ved å endre kontekst fremstår situasjonen annerledes.
Hellig for både jøder og muslimer
For det første er ikke Ibrahim-moskeen (også kalt Makpelah-hulen og Patriarkenes hule) hellig og helt sentral bare for muslimer. Også jøder anser den svært hellig. I Bibelen og Toraen forklares det at det var her profeten Abraham ble begravet. Det samme tror muslimer. Og ingen profet er like viktig for alle tre religioner som Abraham, derav de abrahamittiske religioner.
Da staten Israel ble opprettet i 1948 ble stedet kontrollert av Jordan, som nektet jøder avgang, ifølge Store Norske Leksikon. Først da området kom under israelsk kontroll, etter seksdagerskrigen i 1967, kunne en jødisk rabbiner igjen besøke bygningen.
Både jøder og muslimer mener at området tilhører dem, noe som har ført til flere voldelige sammenstøt gjennom årene. Både jøder og muslimer har mistet livet i disse sammenstøtene. Mest kjent er kanskje Hebron-massakren 25. februar 1994, da 29 palestinere ble drept i moskeen i et angrep utført av den jødiske ekstremisten Baruch Goldstein. Hele området er derfor svært strengt bevoktet.
Stedet brukes i dag av begge religioner, som har hver sin seksjon. Ti dager i året åpner disse for den andre religionen, slik at både jøder og muslimer har tilgang til hele komplekset noen bestemte dager hvert år.
Video fra 2022
Det er i forbindelse med en av disse ti dagene videoen er tatt. 2. oktober 2022 var hovedhallen reservert jødisk feiring av selichot. Hele seansen kan du se her, selve opptaket fra en annen vinkel her.
Også i oktober i år ble moskeen stengt for muslimer, ifølge det tyrkiske nyhetsbyrået Anadolu.
– De israelske okkupasjonsmyndighetene stengte Ibrahimi-moskeen mandag og tirsdag på grunn av Sukkot, sa Ghassan Al-Rajabi, direktøren for Ibrahimi-moskeen, til nyhetsbyrået 2. oktober i år.
Ifølge Al-Rajabi ville alle deler av moskeen bli åpnet for israelske bosettere, og la til at Israel stenger moskeen i 10 dager hvert år for muslimer i anledning ulike jødiske høytider.
Han sa at slike handlinger er en del av «rammeverket for den fortsatte romlige og tidsmessige delingen» av Ibrahimi-moskeen.
Videoen er altså ekte, men presentert i en annen kontekst. Det var ikke en musikkfestival, videoen er ikke tatt opp under den pågående krigen, og bruken av moskéen er en del av en delingsavtale mellom jøder og muslimer.
Translation:
No, this video is not new
Assertion
Israelis took over the Ibrahim Mosque on Sunday [1. October 2023].
Conclusion
The video is real, but was not recorded during the ongoing war. It does not show a music festival, but instead the celebration of Jewish selichot. The use of the mosque is part of a partition agreement between Jews and Muslims, who both consider the area to be sacred.
In recent days, many have shared a video of Jews dancing in a mosque in Hebron in the West Bank, which according to the UN is an Israeli-occupied Palestinian area.
"Israelis took over the Ibrahim Mosque on Sunday," it says. Muslims are said to have been refused entry, and settlers are said to have held a music festival. This must have happened at the same time as Palestinian children and civilians are dying in Gaza.
The video itself is real, but changing the context makes the situation appear different.
Holy to both Jews and Muslims
First, the Mosque of Ibrahim (also called the Cave of Makpelah and the Cave of the Patriarchs) is not sacred and central only to Muslims. Jews also consider it very holy. In the Bible and the Torah, it is explained that this is where the prophet Abraham was buried. Muslims believe the same. And no prophet is as important to all three religions as Abraham, hence the Abrahamic religions.
When the state of Israel was established in 1948, the place was controlled by Jordan, which refused Jews to leave, according to Store Norske Leksikon. Only when the area came under Israeli control, after the Six-Day War in 1967, could a Jewish rabbi visit the building again.
Both Jews and Muslims believe that the area belongs to them, which has led to several violent clashes over the years. Both Jews and Muslims have lost their lives in these clashes. Perhaps the most famous is the Hebron massacre on 25 February 1994, when 29 Palestinians were killed in the mosque in an attack carried out by the Jewish extremist Baruch Goldstein. The entire area is therefore very strictly guarded.
The place is used today by both religions, each of which has its own section. Ten days a year these are open to the other religion, so that both Jews and Muslims have access to the entire complex on certain days each year.
Video from 2022
It is in connection with one of these ten days that the video was taken. On October 2, 2022, the main hall was reserved for the Jewish celebration of selichot. You can see the entire session here, the recording itself from another angle here.
Also in October this year, the mosque was closed to Muslims, according to the Turkish news agency Anadolu.
- The Israeli occupation authorities closed the Ibrahimi Mosque on Monday and Tuesday due to Sukkot, Ghassan Al-Rajabi, the director of the Ibrahimi Mosque, told the news agency on October 2 this year.
According to Al-Rajabi, all parts of the mosque would be opened to Israeli settlers, adding that Israel closes the mosque for 10 days each year to Muslims on the occasion of various Jewish holidays.
He said such actions are part of the "framework for the continued spatial and temporal division" of the Ibrahimi Mosque.
The video is therefore real, but presented in a different context. It was not a music festival, the video was not shot during the ongoing war, and the use of the mosque is part of a partition agreement between Jews and Muslims.

content:
A Lakmuszon az elmúlt egy évben igyekeztünk konkrét példákon bemutatni a különböző manipulációs technikákat, és praktikus segítséget nyújtani ezek leleplezéséhez.
Írtunk már arról, hogyan derítheted ki, az eléd kerülő fotó vagy videó hiteles forrásból származik-e, esetleg módosítottak-e rajta illetéktelen kezek.
Ebben a cikkben pedig arra mutatunk technikákat, hogyan ellenőrizhető, hogy egy felvételen tényleg az látható-e, amit állítanak róla.
Vegyünk például egy a rövid videót, amit a napokban, egészen pontosan január 16-án osztott meg a Telegramon egy Oroszok az igazság oldalán nevű, 2022 áprilisában létrehozott, mára közel 4 ezer felhasználó által követett Kreml-barát csatorna.
Forrás: Telegram/Oroszok az igazság oldalán
Egy átlagos parti egy amerikai iskolában, inkább egy tomboló őrültekből álló összejövetel
- állítja a videóról a bejegyzés szerzője, de mivel egy vállaltan oroszbarát Telegram-csatornán járunk, amit ráadásul már korábban is hamis információ terjesztésén kaptunk, nem hittünk neki elsőre, inkább a felvétel eredeti feltöltőjének keresésébe kezdtünk.
A gyanú beigazolódott.
Az eredetileg a TikTokra feltöltött videón természetesen nem egy átlagos amerikai sulibuli látható. A felvétel valójában a Mindforce nevű hardcore/thrash metál banda koncertjén készült, egy floridai kulturális központban.
Lépésről lépésre végigvesszük, hogyan kerestük meg a videó eredetijét.
A videó pontos forrásának beazonosításához elsőként arra kellett válasz keresnünk, hol, milyen eseményen készülhetett a felvétel. Az alkalom egyértelműen valamilyen rockkoncert lehetett, a zenéből és a bulizó tömeg öltözékéből is erre következtethetünk.
A felvétel egy pontján látható, hogy az egyik résztvevő “Age of Apocalypse” feliratú sapkát visel, ami akár a fellépő banda neve is lehetne.
Forrás: Telegram/Oroszok az igazság oldalán
Ezért lefuttattunk egy Google keresést “Age of Apocalypse concert” keresőszavakra, kifejezetten a neten elérhető videók között, hátha valamelyiken feltűnik a vizsgált videón látható környezet.
Így is történt, a keresés eredményeként kiadott videók közül sorban a hatodiknál.
A videót ugyan az Age of Apocalypse egy következő koncertjét hirdető weboldalba ágyazva találta meg a keresőmotor. A találati eredmény azonban nem az Age of Apocalypse, hanem egy másik zenekar, a Mindforce koncertjét mutatja, 2022 januárjában a FYA Fest nevű rendezvényen, a Bryan Glazer Family JCC (Zsidó Kulturális Központ) épületében.
A helyszín pedig számos részlet (például a mennyezet, a világítás, a padlószőnyeg színe és a színpad szegélye) alapján egyértelműen megegyezik az oroszbarát Telegram-csatornán közzétett videón láthatóval.
Az FYA a rendezvény hivatalos Instagram-oldala alapján egy metálzenei minifesztivál a Florida állambeli Tampában, amit idén immár kilencedik alkalommal rendeztek meg, 2023. január 7-8. között, a tavalyihoz hasonlóan ismét a Bryan Glazer JCC-ben. (A line-up szerint idén is volt a fesztiválon Mindforce koncert, és fellépett az Age of Apocalypse is.)
A helyszín tehát megvan, azt viszont ennyiből még mindig nem tudhatjuk biztosan, hogy a vizsgált videó erről a rendezvényről készült-e.
Ennek kiderítéséhez az InVid elnevezésű verifikációs programot használtuk. A böngésző kiegészítő itt tölthető le (Chrome-ra és Firefoxra). A kiegészítőt letöltése után az “Open Toolbox”-ra kattintva érhető el a kezelőfelület.
A “Video” fülön a “Keyframes” opcióra kattintva érhetjük el azt az eszközt, amely segít a videót képkockákra bontani.
Az InVid nem minden esetben tudja kezelni a videókra mutató linkeket, a Telegramra feltöltött videó esetében sem működött ez a funkció. A Video Downloader PLUS nevű Chrome bővítmény segítségével ezért előbb lementettük, majd feltöltöttük az InVid felületére a szóban forgó felvételt, és a “Submit” gombra kattintunk. Az eredmény:
Egy kis várakozás után a program több képkockára bontja a videót. Ha rákattintunk az egyes képekre, a Google automatikusan fordított képkeresést végez rajtuk: megmutatja, hogy az adott kép (vagy ahhoz hasonló) fellelhető-e valahol az interneten. Ha az első próbálkozások nem hoznak eredményt, érdemes más, és minél több megkülönböztető jegyet tartalmazó képkockával is próbálkozni. Mi is csak második próbálkozásra, az ominózus baseball sapkás képkockára kattintva kaptunk használható keresési találatokat.
A Google a TikTok egyik oldalán rábukkant a keresett képre, és így a keresett videóra is, az #fya9 tag alatt található videók között.
#fya9
A videót @nessyfessy nevű felhasználó készítette, méghozzá állítása szerint a már említett Mindforce nevű hardcore zenekar 2023. január 8-i koncertjéről, a 9. FYA fesztivál második napjáról. (A videót viszont csak január 10-én töltötték fel.)
@nessyfessy MINDFORCE - FYA 2023 ☀️ #mindforce #hardcore #wordsfail #fyafest #fya #fya9 #tampa #florida #mindforcehc ♬ original sound - inesa
Az Oroszok az igazság oldalán Telegram-csatorna tehát hamisan állította a vizsgált videóról, hogy amit látunk rajta, az “egy átlagos parti egy amerikai iskolában.”
A felvétel valójában egy metálkoncerten készült, amit nem iskolai keretek között szerveztek, és nem is csak diákok vehettek részt rajta.
Hasonló módszer alkalmazható bármilyen videó esetén, amelynek szeretnénk ellenőrizni a forrását. Az InVid eszköz használatáról az AFP készített egy videót is, amely a Lakmusz oldalán a cikkeink alá görgetve, az “Eszközök”-nél érhető el. Emellett egyéb videókat is közzétettünk (például a Twitteres keresésről és a fényképek, videók metaadatainak ellenőrzéséről), amelyek segíthetik az “otthoni” tényellenőrzést is.
Ha ehhez hasonló gyanús tartalommal találkoztál az interneten, de elakadtál az ellenőrzésében, vagy épp ellenkezőleg: sikerült, és az eredményt megosztanád velünk, várjuk leveledet a szerk@lakmusz.hu e-mail címre.
Translation:
Over the past year, at Litmus, we have tried to present the various manipulation techniques with concrete examples and to provide practical help in uncovering them.
We have already written about how you can find out whether the photo or video you see comes from an authentic source, or whether it has been modified by unauthorized hands.
In this article, we show techniques on how to check whether a recording really shows what it says it does.
Take, for example, a short video that was shared on Telegram a few days ago, on January 16 to be exact, by a pro-Kremlin channel called Russians on the Side of Truth, created in April 2022 and now followed by nearly 4,000 users.
Source: Telegram/Russians on the side of truth
An average party at an American school, more like a gathering of raging madmen
- claims the author of the post about the video, but since we are on an avowedly pro-Russian Telegram channel, which, moreover, we have already received for spreading false information, we did not believe him at first, and instead started looking for the original uploader of the recording.
The suspicion was confirmed.
The video, which was originally uploaded to TikTok, certainly does not show an ordinary American school party. The recording was actually made at a concert by the hardcore/thrash metal band Mindforce at a cultural center in Florida.
We will go through step by step how we found the original of the video.
In order to identify the exact source of the video, we first had to find an answer to where and at what event the recording could have been made. The occasion was clearly some kind of rock concert, as we can infer from the music and the attire of the partying crowd.
At one point in the recording, one of the participants can be seen wearing a hat with the inscription "Age of Apocalypse", which could even be the name of the performing band.
Source: Telegram/Russians on the side of truth
That's why we ran a Google search for the search terms "Age of Apocalypse concert", specifically among the videos available on the Internet, to see if the environment seen in the video under investigation appears in one of them.
And so it happened, with the sixth video in a row released as a result of the search.
The search engine found the video embedded in a website advertising an upcoming concert by Age of Apocalypse. However, the search result does not show Age of Apocalypse, but another band, Mindforce, in concert in January 2022 at an event called FYA Fest at the Bryan Glazer Family JCC (Jewish Cultural Center).
And based on many details (such as the ceiling, the lighting, the color of the floor mat and the edge of the stage), the location clearly matches the one shown in the video posted on the pro-Russian Telegram channel.
According to the event's official Instagram page, FYA is a metal music mini-festival in Tampa, Florida, which was held for the ninth time this year, January 7-8, 2023. between, like last year again at the Bryan Glazer JCC. (According to the line-up, there was also a Mindforce concert at the festival this year, and Age of Apocalypse also performed.)
So we have the location, but from this we still cannot know for sure whether the examined video was made from this event.
To find out, we used the verification program called InVid. The browser add-on can be downloaded here (for Chrome and Firefox). After downloading the add-on, the user interface can be accessed by clicking on "Open Toolbox".
On the "Video" tab, click on the "Keyframes" option to access the tool that helps you divide the video into frames.
InVid cannot handle links to videos in all cases, this function did not work in the case of a video uploaded to Telegram either. With the help of the Chrome extension called Video Downloader PLUS, we first saved and then uploaded the recording in question to the InVid interface and clicked on the "Submit" button. The result:
After a short wait, the program will split the video into several frames. If you click on the individual images, Google automatically performs a reverse image search on them: it shows whether the given image (or something similar) can be found somewhere on the Internet. If the first attempts do not bring results, it is worth trying other frames with as many distinguishing marks as possible. We also got usable search results by clicking on the ominous baseball cap frame only on the second attempt.
Google found the image you were looking for on one of TikTok's pages, and thus the video you were looking for, among the videos under the tag #fya9.
#fya9
The video was made by a user named @nessyfessy, and according to him, it is about the concert of the aforementioned hardcore band Mindforce on January 8, 2023, the second day of the 9th FYA festival. (However, the video was only uploaded on January 10.)
@nessyfessy MINDFORCE - FYA 2023 ☀️ #mindforce #hardcore #wordsfail #fyafest #fya #fya9 #tampa #florida #mindforcehc ♬ original sound - inesa
The Russians on the side of truth Telegram channel therefore falsely claimed about the video under investigation that what we see on it is "an average party at an American school."
The recording was actually made at a metal concert, which was not organized as part of a school, and not only students could participate in it.
A similar method can be used for any video whose source we want to verify. AFP also made a video about the use of the InVid tool, which can be found on the Litmus website by scrolling under our articles under "Tools". In addition, we have also published other videos (for example, on Twitter search and checking the metadata of photos and videos), which can also help with "home" fact-checking.
If you came across suspicious content like this on the Internet, but got stuck in checking it, or on the contrary: you succeeded and would like to share the result with us, we are waiting for your letter to the e-mail address szerk@lakmusz.hu.

content:
In Sozialen Netzwerken wird immer wieder behauptet, Geflüchtete erhielten mehr Leistungen aus dem Sozialsystem als Deutsche. Seit Anfang Mai macht ein neues Video auf Tiktok und Twitter die Runde: 10.000 Euro soll ab September jedes in Deutschland geborene Kind von Geflüchteten geschenkt bekommen. Das ist frei erfunden.
Der Urheber des Videos, ein Tiktok-Account namens „Fettbär“, verbreitet immer wieder Beiträge, die nur schwer oder, wie in diesem Fall, gar nicht als Satire erkennbar sind. Auffällig ist: Sie richten sich häufig gegen Geflüchtete.
Wir haben beim Bundesministerium für Arbeit und Soziales nachgefragt, ob es Pläne gab oder gibt, Kindern von Geflüchteten eine solche Startprämie in Höhe von 10.000 Euro zur Verfügung zu stellen. Das sei nicht der Fall, antwortete eine Sprecherin des Ministeriums.
Dazu kommt: Bei einer so hohen Sonderzahlung an Geflüchtete ist davon auszugehen, dass Medien darüber berichten würden. Das geschah nicht: Suchmaschinen liefern keine aktuellen Ergebnisse, in denen so hohe Zahlungen für Geflüchtete angekündigt wurden.
CDU-Generalsekretär hatte kürzlich ähnliche Idee geäußert
Einige Medien berichteten aber über einen anderen Vorschlag der CDU: In einem Interview mit der Rheinischen Post sagte CDU-Generalsekretär Mario Czaja Ende April, aus den Reihen seiner Partei käme der Vorschlag, für jedes neugeborene Kind in Deutschland ein Startkapital von 10.000 Euro vom Staat einzuführen. Das Geld solle nicht direkt ausbezahlt werden, sondern sei „ab dem 18. Lebensjahr für ein Studium, eine Gründung gedacht“. Laut Czaja sollten damit die Zukunftschancen von Kindern aus armen Haushalten verbessert werden.
Ob dies auch für Geflüchtete gelten sollte, ging aus dem Interview nicht hervor. Wir haben Czaja eine Anfrage dazu per E-Mail geschickt, erhielten jedoch bis zur Veröffentlichung keine Antwort. Konkrete Pläne, diese Idee tatsächlich umzusetzen, gibt es jedoch nicht, geschweige denn einen fixen Starttermin im September.
Redigatur: Sarah Thust, Gabriele Scherndl
Translation:
It is repeatedly claimed on social networks that refugees receive more benefits from the social system than Germans. A new video has been making the rounds on Tiktok and Twitter since the beginning of May: starting in September, every refugee child born in Germany will receive 10,000 euros as a gift. This is fictional.
The creator of the video, a Tiktok account called “Fettbär”, repeatedly distributes posts that are difficult or, as in this case, impossible to recognize as satire. What is striking is that they are often directed against refugees.
We asked the Federal Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs whether there were or are plans to provide children of refugees with such a starting bonus of 10,000 euros. That is not the case, replied a spokeswoman for the ministry.
In addition, with such a high special payment to refugees, it can be assumed that the media would report on it. That didn't happen: search engines do not provide any current results in which such high payments for refugees were announced.
The CDU general secretary recently expressed a similar idea
However, some media reported on another proposal from the CDU: In an interview with the Rheinische Post at the end of April, CDU General Secretary Mario Czaja said that the proposal came from within his party's ranks to introduce starting capital of 10,000 euros from the state for every newborn child in Germany . The money should not be paid out directly, but is intended “for studying or starting a business from the age of 18 onwards”. According to Czaja, this should improve the future prospects of children from poor households.
It was not clear from the interview whether this should also apply to refugees. We emailed Czaja with a query about this but did not receive a response by the time of publication. However, there are no concrete plans to actually implement this idea, let alone a fixed start date in September.
Editing: Sarah Thust, Gabriele Scherndl

content:
Bewertung
Das erwähnte Gesetz wurde bereits vor einem Jahr – vor dem Krieg – vom Parlament verabschiedet und von Präsident Selenskyj unterzeichnet. Organhandel war schon vor der Gesetzesänderung in der Ukraine verboten und ist es weiterhin.
Fakten
Der Mann in dem gezeigten Video verweist auf einen Artikel zu seinen Behauptungen, der auch im Video eingeblendet wird. Erschienen ist er auf dem ukrainischen Nachrichtenportal LB.ua – allerdings vor einem Jahr.
Das Portal veröffentlichte den Artikel Anfang Januar 2022 und beschreibt darin ein Gesetz, das im ukrainischen Parlament im Dezember 2021 verabschiedet und kurz danach von Präsident Wolodymyr Selenskyj unterzeichnet wurde. Der ganze Vorgang passierte also vor dem russischen Angriff auf die Ukraine im Februar 2022. Er steht nicht damit in Verbindung.
Das damals verabschiedete Gesetz Nr. 1967-IX änderte bestehende Gesetze, die Organtransplantationen bei Menschen regelten. Auf Englisch hat auch die staatliche ukrainische Nachrichtenagentur Ukrinform darüber berichtet.
Der Handel mit Organen oder Gewebeteilen und Werbung dafür werden in Artikel 20 des veränderten Transplantationsgesetzes geregelt – beides war bereits vor der Novelle verboten und ist es weiterhin.
Nach Angaben des ukrainischen Präsidialamts legt das neue Gesetz fest, dass der Staat Organtransplantationen zahlt. Außerdem sieht das Gesetz ein neues Punktesystem vor, das anhand bestimmter Kriterien mitbestimmen soll, welcher Empfänger ein Spenderorgan erhält.
Falschinformationen zu Transplantationen im Zusammenhang mit dem Ukraine-Krieg waren bereits zuvor im Umlauf. Es gibt bisher keine Belege dafür, dass Tote und Verwundete dafür ausgenutzt werden. In einem Faktencheck kam dpa zu dem Schluss, dass die Behauptung, das Internationale Komitee des Roten Kreuzes habe in der Ukraine Kinder mit «gesunden Organen» katalogisiert, falsch ist. Der kanadische Geheimdienst warnte bereits Anfang April 2022 vor russischen Desinformationen über vermeintlichen Organhandel.
(Stand: 9.1.2023)
Translation:
Evaluation
The aforementioned law was passed by parliament a year ago - before the war - and signed by President Zelensky. Organ trafficking was already banned in Ukraine before the law change and remains so.
Facts
The man in the video shown refers to an article about his claims, which is also shown in the video. It appeared on the Ukrainian news portal LB.ua - but a year ago.
The portal published the article in early January 2022 and describes a law that was passed in the Ukrainian parliament in December 2021 and signed by President Volodymyr Zelensky shortly afterwards. So the whole thing happened before the Russian attack on Ukraine in February 2022. It is not related to it.
Law No. 1967-IX passed at that time amended existing laws regulating human organ transplants. The Ukrainian state news agency Ukrinform also reported on it in English.
The trade in organs or tissue parts and advertising thereof are regulated in Article 20 of the amended Transplantation Act - both were already prohibited before the amendment and continue to be so.
According to the Ukrainian presidential office, the new law stipulates that the state will pay for organ transplants. The law also provides for a new points system that is intended to determine which recipient receives a donor organ based on certain criteria.
False information about transplants related to the Ukraine war has previously circulated. There is so far no evidence that the dead and wounded are being exploited for this purpose. In a fact check, dpa concluded that the claim that the International Committee of the Red Cross had cataloged children in Ukraine with “healthy organs” was false. The Canadian secret service warned at the beginning of April 2022 about Russian disinformation about alleged organ trafficking.
(As of: January 9, 2023)

content:
Teiginiai
Verdiktas
Melas. Nėra jokių įrodymų, kad vaikų mirtys susijusios su COVID-19 vakcinomis.
Melo detektoriaus komentaras
Sapereaude.lt publikacijoje teigiama, kad „2022 m., buvo staigus vaikų mirčių perviršis. Šiais metais 1–14 metų amžiaus grupėje mirė 16 proc. daugiau žmonių nei tikėtasi“, o tai įvyko dėl COVID-19 skiepų, nes „mRNA skiepai yra pavojingiausias kada nors visuomenei primestas medicinos prietaisas.“ [citatų kalba netaisyta, – aut. past.]. Ši informacija remiasi asmens, vardu Ed Dowd, pasisakymais platformose „X“ ir „Rumble“.
Visų pirma, melagingi teiginiai, kad JK daugėja mirčių, kurios neva susijusios su COVID-19 vakcinomis, plinta jau keletą metų. 2022 m. vaikų mirčių statistika buvo manipuliuojama, teigiant, kad paskiepyti vaikai 52 k. dažniau miršta nei neskiepyti, nors tam nebuvo jokių įrodymų (čia). 2024 m. taip pat buvo melagingai teigiama, kad šalyje didėja mirčių perviršis, o tai esą susiję su COVID-19 vakcinomis. Tačiau tokia informacija buvo paneigta specialistų (čia ir čia).
Patikimose mokslinėse publikacijose pasirodo analizių, kuriose ieškoma ryšio tarp vakcinų ir didėjančio mirčių skaičiaus, tačiau tokių įrodymų nėra. Pavyzdžiui, prestižiniame BMJ akademiniame žurnale 2023 kovo mėn. pasirodžiusioje publikacijoje „Covid-19: Study reports no significant increase in deaths after vaccination but raises questions over AstraZeneca’s vaccine“ nenustatytas ryšys tarp skiepų ir mirčių (čia).
Tiesa, kad JK daugėja vaikų mirčių. Skaičiuojama, kad 100000 vaikų tekdavo 31.8 mirtys (2019 m. buvo 29.3 mirtys). Tačiau specialistai pastebi, kad mirtys dažniausiai fiksuojamos varginguose rajonuose. Šios mirtys nėra siejamos su vakcinomis. Specialistai ragina mažinti skurdą ir daugiau dėmesio skirti vaikų sveikatai (čia).
Svarbu atkreipti dėmesį ir į tai, kad straipsnyje cituojamas asmuo – E. Dowd – ne mokslininkas ar medikas, o verslininkas investuotojas, niekada nedirbęs sveikatos ar mokslo sektoriuose (čia).
- Šaltiniai
- COVID-19 vaccines are not increasing child mortality in England
- Fact Check: Misleading data used to claim COVID vaccines do more harm than good
- Fact Check: No evidence to link UK excess deaths to COVID-19 vaccines
- Covid-19: Study reports no significant increase in deaths after vaccination but raises questions over AstraZeneca’s vaccine
- Child death rates on the rise in England
- Ed Dowd
Translation:
Statements
Verdict
A lie. There is no evidence that childhood deaths are linked to COVID-19 vaccines.
Lie detector comment
The Sapereaude.lt publication states that "in 2022, there was a sudden excess of child deaths. This year, 16 percent died in the 1-14 age group. more people than expected,” which is due to the COVID-19 vaccine, because “mRNA vaccines are the most dangerous medical device ever forced upon society.” [citation language not corrected, op. past.]. This information is based on what someone named Ed Dowd said on X and Rumble.
First of all, false claims of an increase in deaths in the UK allegedly linked to COVID-19 vaccines have been circulating for several years. in 2022 statistics of child deaths were manipulated, claiming that 52 k. more likely to die than unvaccinated, although there was no evidence for this (here). in 2024 it also falsely claimed that excess deaths were increasing in the country, allegedly related to COVID-19 vaccines. However, such information was denied by specialists (here and here).
Analyzes appear in reputable scientific publications looking for a link between vaccines and increased deaths, but there is no such evidence. For example, in the prestigious academic journal BMJ in March 2023. the published publication "Covid-19: Study reports no significant increase in deaths after vaccination but raises questions over AstraZeneca's vaccine" does not establish a link between vaccinations and deaths (here).
It is true that child deaths are on the rise in the UK. It is estimated that there were 31.8 deaths per 100,000 children (29.3 deaths in 2019). However, experts note that deaths are mostly recorded in poor neighborhoods. These deaths are not linked to vaccines. Experts call for reducing poverty and paying more attention to children's health (here).
It is also important to pay attention to the fact that the person quoted in the article - E. Dowd - is not a scientist or a doctor, but a businessman investor who has never worked in the health or science sectors (here).
- Sources
- COVID-19 vaccines are not increasing child mortality in England
- Fact Check: Misleading data used to claim COVID vaccines do more harm than good
- Fact Check: No evidence to link UK excess deaths to COVID-19 vaccines
- Covid-19: Study reports no significant increase in deaths after vaccination but raises questions over AstraZeneca's vaccine
- Child death rates on the rise in England
- Ed Dowd

content:
Factcheck: nee, deze beelden bewijzen niet dat er ‘plastic rijst’ gemaakt wordt
Op sociale media circuleren twee video’s uit fabrieken die volgens socialemediagebruikers ‘plastic rijst’ zouden produceren. Dat klopt niet. In één video zien we het productieproces van kunststofkorrels die als tussenproduct gebruikt worden in industriële toepassingen. In een andere video zien we de productie van zogenaamde versterkte rijst.
Deze factcheck is uitgevoerd op basis van de beschikbare informatie op de datum van publicatie. Lees hier meer over hoe we werken.
Op sociale media circuleren twee video’s. In de eerste video zien we twee personen stukken doorzichtige folie in een machine steken. Aan de andere kant van de machine komen witte korrels tevoorschijn. De video heeft als onderschrift: ‘Het maken van plastic rijst. Wees voorzichtig vooraleer je koopt.’ In een reactie op een van de X-posts reageert iemand dat het om rijstpapier gaat.
In de tweede video zien we een andere machine. Daaruit komt een wit soort pulp. Een van de twee mannen die de machine bedient, voegt daar een vloeistof aan toe. Vervolgens komen er witte slierten uit de machine die op noedels lijken. In een ander beeld zien we ook witte korrels tevoorschijn komen. Wanneer er ingezoomd wordt op de korrels, wordt duidelijk dat ze op rijst lijken.
De verspreiders zien in de beelden bewijs voor de productie van ‘plastic rijst’. De rijst zou van plastic gemaakt worden en zou voor menselijke consumptie bedoeld zijn.
De video’s en screenshots van die beelden worden massaal gedeeld op sociale media. Zo waren de beelden terug te vinden op zowel X (hier, hier, hier, en hier) als TikTok (hier, hier, hier en hier). Ook Nederlandstalige socialemediagebruikers deelden de video’s. Zo postte een X-gebruiker de tweede video met als Nederlandstalig bijschrift: ‘Nep rijst van plastic.’
Maar tonen de video’s nu het maken van rijst? En indien ja, is die rijst gemaakt van plastic?
‘Neprijst’
De bewering dat fabrikanten plastic in hun rijst verwerken of rijst volledig uit plastic maken, circuleert al ruim tien jaar. Volgens een factcheck van het Nederlandse NU.nl zouden de eerste berichten over in Chinese rijst verwerkt plastic al in 2011 verschenen zijn. NU.nl verwijst daarvoor naar een artikel van The Korea Times dat bericht had over de massale productie van neprijst. Het artikel van The Korea Times levert weliswaar geen concreet bewijs voor die bewering.
Sindsdien steekt het verhaal geregeld de kop op. Zo stond de theorie volgens NU.nl in 2016 weer even in de belangstelling nadat in Nigeria een lading ‘neprijst’ in beslag was genomen. Na onderzoek bleek de rijst te zijn besmet met bacteriën, maar geen plastic te bevatten. Dat bericht ook BBC News.
Plastic korrels
In de eerste video zien we in de rechterbovenhoek het woord ‘hats’ staan, met een hoed ernaast. Via andere posts van de video’s komen we bij het X-account @HATSTRUTH terecht. Wanneer we de handle @HATSTRUTH ingeven op Google komen we bij een Telegramkanaal met dezelfde naam terecht. Daar werd de video op 31 oktober gedeeld. De video werd opnieuw gedeeld op 22 december.
We geven een screenshot van de video in Google Lens om de herkomst ervan te achterhalen. Zo komen we terecht bij een factcheck van de Indische nieuwssite News Mobile. Volgens hen zijn de beweringen over ‘plastic rijst’ die over de video gedaan worden onwaar.
News Mobile verwijst naar een uitgebreidere versie van de video die op YouTube is gepubliceerd in 2017. Ook daarin staat een verwijzing naar ‘plastic rijst’. Volgens News Mobile gaat het weliswaar niet om een fabriek van plastic rijst, maar een fabriek van korrels uit kunststof.
Op een bepaald moment komt een zak met de letters ‘EVA’ in beeld (0:48). EVA kan staan voor ethyleen vinyl acetaat, een kunststof die gebruikt wordt voor rubberachtige toepassingen. News Mobile herkent op de zak de naam Hanwha Total Petrochemical Co-operation Limited. Dat blijkt een chemiebedrijf uit Zuid-Korea te zijn dat EVA-korrels produceert.
Op de website van het bedrijf vinden we de korrels die het produceert terug. De korrels worden gebruikt voor het schuim in sneakers, lijm voor fotografiefilm, inkapselingsmiddelen voor zonnebatterijen en als extrusiecoating voor machines. De korrels zijn dus het eindproduct van de fabriek, maar slechts een tussenproduct voor andere toepassingen en worden niet als ‘rijstkorrels’ verkocht.
Nutritioneel versterkte rijst
Het logo van @HATSTRUTH staat ook op sommige versies van de tweede video. Op het Telegramkanaal met die naam vinden we ook die video terug. Het kanaal deelde de video op 6 april.
Maar in de linkerbovenhoek zien we ook een andere naam met logo staan: Sunpring. We geven die naam in op Google en komen terecht op de website van een bedrijf met dezelfde naam dat machines maakt om ‘versterkte’ artificiële rijst te produceren.
Op de site van het bedrijf lezen we dat artificiële rijst een soort rijstvervanger is, die eruit ziet als rijst, maar een pak voedzamer is. Dat komt doordat de producent tijdens het productieproces tal van voedingsstoffen kan toevoegen, zoals vitamine A, vitamine B12, vitamine B1, ijzer, zink en foliumzuur. Volgens het bedrijf zou die artificiële rijst vijf tot tien keer zo voedzaam zijn als gewone rijst.
Dat lezen we ook in een artikel van de Indische krant The Hindu. In het artikel lezen wel dat er in India een project aan de gang is om versterkte rijst te verdelen over het land omdat het een gezondere optie is dan gewone rijst.
Volgens het Food Fortification Initiative (FFI) is 9 procent van de industrieel geproduceerde rijst ondertussen al versterkt. In 2022 was dit nog maar 4,1 procent en voor 2021 slechts 1,2 procent. Uit een kaart van FFI leiden we af dat versterkte rijst vooral gebruikt wordt in Zuid-Amerika, West-Afrika, het Arabisch schiereiland, India, China en Zuidoost Azië.
Conclusie
– Op sociale media circuleren twee video’s uit fabrieken die volgens socialemediagebruikers ‘plastic rijst’ zouden produceren voor menselijke consumptie.
– In één video is de productie van kunststofkorrels te zien. Die korrels worden in industriële toepassingen gebruikt.
– In een andere video zien we de productie van nutritioneel versterkte rijst. Aan die rijst zijn mineralen en vitamines toegevoegd om hem een hogere voedingswaarde te geven.
– De beelden tonen dus geen productie van zogenaamde plastic rijst. We beoordelen die stelling dan ook als onwaar.
Bronnen
Alle bronnen werden laatst geraadpleegd op 29 december 2023.
Meer informatie over de factchecks vindt u op de website van Knack.
U vindt onze factchecks ook terug bij deCheckers, samen met betrouwbare factchecks van andere Vlaamse redacties.
Knack is erkend lid van het International Fact-Checking Network (IFCN) en European Fact-Checking Standards Network (EFCSN).
Krasse uitspraak, straf cijfer of dito feit in de actualiteit gezien?
Vul uw vraag in op de website van deCheckers met exacte bronvermelding van het citaat of stuur het naar factcheck@knack.be.
Knack maakt onderdeel uit van Roularta Media Group.
Translation:
Fact check: no, these images do not prove that 'plastic rice' is being made
Two videos are circulating on social media from factories that, according to social media users, produce 'plastic rice'. That's not right. In one video we see the production process of plastic granules that are used as an intermediate product in industrial applications. In another video we see the production of so-called fortified rice.
This fact check was carried out based on the information available at the date of publication. Read more about how we work here.
Two videos are circulating on social media. In the first video we see two people inserting pieces of transparent foil into a machine. White granules emerge from the other side of the machine. The video is captioned: 'Making plastic rice. Be careful before you buy.' In a response to one of the X-posts, someone responded that it was rice paper.
In the second video we see another machine. This produces a white pulp. One of the two men operating the machine adds a liquid. Then white strings that look like noodles come out of the machine. In another image we also see white grains emerging. When zooming in on the grains, it becomes clear that they resemble rice.
The distributors see evidence in the images for the production of 'plastic rice'. The rice would be made of plastic and intended for human consumption.
The videos and screenshots of those images are shared en masse on social media. The images could be found on both X (here, here, here, and here) and TikTok (here, here, here and here). Dutch-speaking social media users also shared the videos. For example, an X user posted the second video with the Dutch caption: 'Fake rice made of plastic.'
But do the videos show the making of rice? And if so, is that rice made of plastic?
'Fake rice'
The claim that manufacturers include plastic in their rice or make rice entirely from plastic has been circulating for more than a decade. According to a fact check by the Dutch NU.nl, the first reports about plastic used in Chinese rice appeared as early as 2011. NU.nl refers to an article by The Korea Times that reported on the massive production of fake rice. Admittedly, The Korea Times article does not provide any concrete evidence for that claim.
Since then the story has cropped up regularly. For example, according to NU.nl, the theory was in the spotlight again in 2016 after a shipment of 'fake rice' was seized in Nigeria. After examination, the rice turned out to be contaminated with bacteria, but did not contain plastic. BBC News also reports this.
Plastic granules
In the first video we see the word 'hats' in the top right corner, with a hat next to it. Through other posts of the videos we end up at the X account @HATSTRUTH. When we enter the handle @HATSTRUTH into Google, we end up at a Telegram channel with the same name. The video was shared there on October 31. The video was shared again on December 22.
We provide a screenshot of the video in Google Lens to determine its origin. This brings us to a fact check of the Indian news site News Mobile. According to them, the claims about 'plastic rice' made about the video are untrue.
News Mobile points to an extended version of the video published on YouTube in 2017. It also contains a reference to 'plastic rice'. According to News Mobile, it is not a plastic rice factory, but a plastic granule factory.
At one point a bag with the letters 'EVA' comes into view (0:48). EVA can stand for ethylene vinyl acetate, a plastic used for rubber-like applications. News Mobile recognizes the name Hanwha Total Petrochemical Co-operation Limited on the bag. This turns out to be a chemical company from South Korea that produces EVA granules.
We can find the granules it produces on the company's website. The granules are used for the foam in sneakers, adhesives for photography film, encapsulants for solar batteries and as an extrusion coating for machines. The grains are therefore the end product of the factory, but only an intermediate product for other applications and are not sold as 'rice grains'.
Nutritionally fortified rice
The @HATSTRUTH logo is also on some versions of the second video. We also find that video on the Telegram channel with that name. The channel shared the video on April 6.
But in the top left corner we also see another name with logo: Sunpring. We enter that name into Google and end up on the website of a company with the same name that makes machines to produce 'fortified' artificial rice.
On the company's site we read that artificial rice is a kind of rice substitute that looks like rice, but is much more nutritious. This is because the manufacturer can add numerous nutrients during the production process, such as vitamin A, vitamin B12, vitamin B1, iron, zinc and folic acid. According to the company, this artificial rice is five to ten times as nutritious as regular rice.
We also read this in an article by the Indian newspaper The Hindu. The article states that a project is underway in India to distribute fortified rice across the country because it is a healthier option than regular rice.
According to the Food Fortification Initiative (FFI), 9 percent of industrially produced rice has already been fortified. In 2022 this was only 4.1 percent and for 2021 only 1.2 percent. From a map of FFI we deduce that fortified rice is mainly used in South America, West Africa, the Arabian Peninsula, India, China and Southeast Asia.
Conclusion
– Two videos are circulating on social media from factories that, according to social media users, produce 'plastic rice' for human consumption.
– One video shows the production of plastic granules. These granules are used in industrial applications.
– In another video we see the production of nutritionally fortified rice. Minerals and vitamins have been added to the rice to give it a higher nutritional value.
– The images therefore do not show the production of so-called plastic rice. We therefore assess that statement as false.
Sources
All sources were last consulted on December 29, 2023.

AFP
16.01.2024
This video of a man dancing has been altered to make the face look like Zelensky
A 2020 video of a man in a red leotard doing an oriental dance has been altered to show the face of Volodymyr Zelensky instead of the original dancer. The video clip was shared thousands of times on social media in various languages, including Hungarian, with comments mocking the Ukrainian president. However, the original video was posted by a young Russian dancer on his own social media profile. The original dancer's face was digitally manipulated.

However, the original video was posted by a young Russian dancer on his own social media profile. The original dancer's face was digitally manipulated.

The legalisation of marriage and adoption for same-sex couples in Greece, which was approved by parliament on February 15, 2024, sparked a heated debate in Greek society and drew strident criticism from the Orthodox Church and others. In late January some social media users shared a photo showing a milk carton from the dairy company DELTA showing a man and a child. The users claimed that the company had “removed the mother figure” from the design, insinuating that it was to prepare the public for same-sex couples becoming parents. However, the particular carton displayed in the post is only one out of five that DELTA introduced in January 2024 and the others do feature a female figure. The company told AFP that the idea behind the new cartons was to depict “different moments of the day with a Greek family” and that the designs had been prepared months before the government proposed the legislation on same-sex marriage and adoption.
In January 2024, Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis announced a bill aimed at legalising marriage and adoption for same-sex couples. On February 15, Greece’s parliament adopted the landmark reform, making the country the 37th in the world – and the first Orthodox Christian one – to legalise adoption by same-sex families. This is a significant step for the country, as previously, the state did not recognize parental rights for non-biological parents (archived link here).
Some socially conservative politicians and representatives of the Orthodox Church expressed strong opposition to the legislation and AFP previously fact-checked other misinformation surrounding the vote.
In this context, a photo began circulating on the Internet in late January with the claim that the Greek dairy company DELTA had removed the image of a mother from its milk cartons, implying that DELTA wanted to promote alternative family models. The photo shows two DELTA milk cartons: one portraying what appears to be a family with a mother, father and two children, labelled “previous carton” in red letters, while another depicts a man and a girl (presumably father and daughter) and is labelled “new package” in red letters.
“NO gentlemen of ‘DELTA’…When you remove the MOTHER from the carton of ‘FAMILY’ milk…I, quite simply, keep the MOTHER and REMOVE YOU FROM MY FAMILY!”, reads a January 31, 2024 post on Facebook with the photo, shared around 1,900 times.
Users in the comments expressed disgust at the packaging, and some said they would no longer buy DELTA products: “Boycott everything they ‘serve’ us by force. We are Greeks and family is above everything!”, one user wrote.
The photo was also shared here while posts with similar claims were shared on Facebook here and here, on X (here, here and here) and Instagram (here and here). The same claim was also repeated on some Greek websites (here and here).
The image was also shared on X by far-right politician Kyriakos Velopoulos, president of the Hellenic Solution party. Hellenic Solution has 12 MPs and was categorically opposed to the government’s bill. In the past, AFP has verified other false claims spread or supported by Velopoulos (here and here).
However, AFP’s investigation found that the claim is misleading because it only refers to one of DELTA’s new cartons, whereas there are four others in the same series, which do include what looks like a mother figure. Moreover, the company told AFP it had begun the redesign of the packaging months before the public debate on same-sex marriage and adoption was sparked by the government’s plans.
Cartons show ‘different moments of a Greek family’
A Google search with the keywords “milk” and “DELTA” led us to the official site of the brand (archived here), where we confirmed that the new DELTA milk carton shown in the social media posts does indeed exist and it is one of the five featured in the milk range “mmmMILK”.
The new milk cartons were released in January 2024, a spokesperson from DELTA told AFP in an email on February 12.
The designs on the other four packages in the new range depict different family members and each appears to include a mother figure: they comprise a heterosexual couple, a heterosexual couple with two children (twice), and a heterosexual couple with one child.
“The new mmmMILK packaging includes photos depicting different moments of a Greek family during the day. You can see them in the relevant photo as well as on DELTA’s official website (https://www.delta.gr/) in our products section,” (archived here) the spokesperson told AFP.
However, the process “from the moment of redesigning the packaging to the moment it is available for sale, takes a long time, four to five months, so it cannot be related to… current issues,” the DELTA spokesperson said, alluding to the recent controversy over same-sex marriage and adoption.
The company also sent us a photo of the entire new range of packaging, showing that the mother figure has not been removed from the design on the other cartons.
We found most of the new designs in supermarkets in Athens. The photos below were taken in supermarkets from three different chains around the city.
Debate over same-sex marriage and adoption
As AFP previously reported, the Orthodox Church’s governing body, the Holy Synod, said the legalisation of same-sex marriage and adoption “condemns future children to grow up without a father or mother in an environment of confusion” and will encourage “the exploitation of vulnerable women” as surrogate mothers (archived link here).
On February 11, 2024, some 4,000 people responded to a call by Orthodox religious groups to protest against the government’s bill (archived link here), according to the police.
Two large nationwide surveys (archived here) conducted in 2023 by the aboutpeople polling firm (archived here) on behalf of the Eteron-Institute for Research and Social Change (archived here) revealed significant support among respondents for same-sex marriage, but also clear opposition to adoption by same-sex couples.
After Greece’s parliament approved the bill, dozens of people waving rainbow flags celebrated in front of the parliament building in central Athens. LGBTQ associations praised the vote as a historic milestone. The Greek prime minister, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, wrote on X that “this is a milestone for human rights, reflecting today’s Greece – a progressive and democratic country, passionately committed to European values”.
AFP has previously verified false or misleading claims about the LGBTQ community (here and here).

Nakstad-sitat brukes som argument mot vaksine
En uttalelse fra assisterende helsedirektør Espen Rostrup Nakstad er tatt ut av sammenheng og deles nå på sosiale medier. Hva var det egentlig han mente?
Sitatet er spredt i ulike grupper på Facebook, blant annet i de offentlige gruppene «Nei til vaksinepass og vaksinepress», «Varslerhuset Norge AS» og «Are & Kiri - Mot strømmen».
På bildet av Nakstad står sitatet:
Og det er jo ikke sånn at kontinentene som har hatt minst vaksiner har vært hardest rammet av pandemien, det er kanskje motsatt. Det er også kanskje noe å lære av, at det er lett å stole på vaksine som veien ut, men det er kanskje ikke det eneste virkemiddelet alltid. Vi ser at Europa, for eksempel, til tross for en veldig vaksinert befolkning er det kontinentet som nå har aller mest smitte.
Sju minutter langt intervju
Sitatet er hentet fra et intervju med Nakstad på TV 2 Nyhetskanalen 19. januar litt over klokken 07.00. Hele intervjuet varer i over sju minutter. Men det er siste del av et av Nakstads svar folk har merket seg.
Fylkespolitiker i Rogaland, Susanne Heart (MDG), har delt 25 sekunder opptak fra intervjuet. Innlegget hennes har over 360 delinger. Et tilsvarende videoklipp er også delt på Facebook-siden «Politikeren». Der har videoen fått over 5000 visninger.
Det er mange som har kommentert sitatet som er delt på Facebook. En skriver blant annet: «Det må ha kostet ham hardt å si dette... Men bra det kommer ut».
En annen: «Å innrømme sine feil er ikke lett for en del mennesker !!». Og en tredje skriver: «Han har begynt å ro??? Burde se å skaffe seg en god påhengsmotor, og det snarest!».
Noen er også sinte:
– Ikke et argument mot vaksine
Nakstad skriver i en e-post til Faktisk.no at sitatet fra live-intervjuet på ingen måte er et argument mot vaksiner. Imidlertid er det en forklaring på hvorfor skjevfordelingen av vaksiner i verden ikke ser ut til å ha rammet utviklingsland like mye som fryktet.
Han skriver at den viktigste årsaken ser ut til å være alderssammensetningen, siden unge mennesker blir mindre syke, sammenlignet med eldre.
– Gjennomsnittsalderen på det afrikanske kontinentet er 19,7 år mens den i Europa er nærmere 40 år. Det har stor betydning for hvor stor andel av befolkningen som blir alvorlig syke, understreker Nakstad.
– Befolkningen i utviklingsland har også betydelig lavere mobilitet. De reiser ikke like ofte med fly, tog, buss og ferge til ferier eller jobbmøter som europeere gjør.
Nakstad trekker også frem at klimaet er forskjellig.
– I verdensdeler med kalde vintrer stiger smitten mye som følge av økt kontakthyppighet innendørs. Det er mye av årsaken til at influensabølger typisk treffer Europa i januar og februar hvert år.
Publiserte hele intervjuet
Etter at Faktisk.no tok kontakt med TV 2 om intervjuet med Nakstad, har TV-kanalen publisert intervjuet i sin helhet. Det kan du se her.
Det er fem minutter ut i intervjuet at nyhetsankeret spør:
Helt til slutt Nakstad, litt sånn status på vaksinering, også i verden. Hvordan ligger man an for eksempel i afrikanske land nå som jo var en utfordring med tanke på at omikron etablerte seg, eller kom derfra?
Da svarer Nakstad:
Du kan si at det er interessant dette med vaksinedekning. Den er høy i de rike landene i verden. Men også mellominntektsland nærmer seg 50 prosent vaksinedekning nå. Og så har du de fattigste landene som ligger rundt ti prosent.
Men vi kommer nok i en situasjon halvveis ut i 2022 hvor de fleste mennesker i verden som ønsker vaksine, er tilbudt vaksine. Og så ser det ut som, for eksempel i Sør-Afrika, at gjennomgått sykdom tidligere i hvert fall har en effekt på smittetallene.
Og det er jo ikke sånn at de kontinentene som har hatt minst vaksine, har vært hardest rammet av pandemien. Det er kanskje motsatt – og det er kanskje også noe å lære av – at det er lett å stole på vaksine som vei ut. Men det er kanskje ikke det eneste virkemiddelet alltid. Vi ser at Europa for eksempel, med en veldig vaksinert befolkning, er det kontinentet som har aller mest smitte.
Overdreven tro på vaksinen alene
Nakstad utdyper i e-posten til Faktisk.no at sykeligheten og dødeligheten i Europa ville vært langt høyere uten vaksinering.
– Men troen på at vaksine alene er nok til å beholde kontroll på pandemien, var overdrevent stor i Europa høsten 2021. Vaksinene bidro til å redusere R-tallet fra anslagsvis 5–10 til verdier ned mot 1,3 i Norge, skriver han.
– Men så lenge smittetallet er over 1, vil pandemien vokse, og vi fikk utover høsten rekordmange innleggelser med deltavarianten i norske sykehus. Derfor ble det etter hvert behov for å gjeninnføre smitteverntiltak i Norge utover senhøsten.
Nakstad skriver også at vaksinen har vist seg å beskytte godt mot alvorlig sykdom, men dårligere mot smitteoverføring med de nye muterte virusvariantene.
– Det betyr ikke at vaksinene ikke er effektive til å begrense smittespredning, men de kan åpenbart ikke gjøre hele jobben alene, opplyser han.
– Derfor har de fleste land fortsatt råd om å være hjemme ved sykdom, teste seg ved symptomer og bruke munnbind ved trengsel. Slike tiltak har sammen med vaksineeffekten bidratt til at deltavarianten snart er nedkjempet i Europa.
Oppfordrer til å ta vaksine
Ifølge Nakstad er det flere grunner til å ta vaksine nå, selv om mange allerede er smittet.
– Det er vanskelig å beskytte seg mot å bli smittet i Norge nå. Men hvis du er vaksinert, er du godt beskyttet mot alvorlig sykdom, skriver han.
– Det er viktig både for deg selv og for samfunnet, siden presset mot helsevesenet har vært en av hovedårsakene til at det har vært behov for smitteverntiltak i Norge.
At omikron gir mildere sykdom, er ingen grunn til å ikke ta vaksine, mener Nakstad.
– Omikron kan fortsatt gi alvorlig sykdom hos noen, og uvaksinerte personer er overrepresentert blant dem som trenger sykehusinnleggelse i Norge nå, opplyser han.
– Også tidligere friske personer legges inn med omikronvarianten på sykehus fordi de er uvaksinerte. Hvis man vil være godt beskyttet mot alvorlig sykdom, uansett virusvariant, er det lurt å vaksinere seg.
Translation:
The Nakstad quote is used as an argument against vaccines
A statement from assistant health director Espen Rostrup Nakstad has been taken out of context and is now being shared on social media. What did he really mean?
The quote is spread in various groups on Facebook, including in the public groups "No to the vaccine pass and vaccine press", "Varslerhuset Norge AS" and "Are & Kiri - Against the tide".
On the photo of Nakstad is the quote:
And it is not the case that the continents that have had the fewest vaccines have been hardest hit by the pandemic, it may be the opposite. There is also perhaps something to learn from, that it is easy to trust a vaccine as the way out, but it may not always be the only means of action. We see that Europe, for example, despite a highly vaccinated population, is the continent that now has the most infections.
Seven-minute long interview
The quote is taken from an interview with Nakstad on TV 2 Nyhetskanalen on 19 January just after 07.00. The entire interview lasts over seven minutes. But it is the last part of one of Nakstad's answers that people have noticed.
County politician in Rogaland, Susanne Heart (MDG), has shared a 25-second recording from the interview. Her post has over 360 shares. A corresponding video clip has also been shared on the Facebook page "The Politician". There, the video has received over 5,000 views.
Many have commented on the quote shared on Facebook. One writes, among other things: "It must have cost him a lot to say this... But it's good that it comes out".
Another: "Admitting your mistakes is not easy for some people !!". And a third writes: "He has started rowing??? Should see to getting a good outboard motor, and as soon as possible!".
Some are also angry:
- Not an argument against vaccines
Nakstad writes in an e-mail to Faktisk.no that the quote from the live interview is in no way an argument against vaccines. However, there is an explanation for why the uneven distribution of vaccines in the world does not seem to have affected developing countries as much as feared.
He writes that the most important reason seems to be the age composition, since young people get sick less, compared to older people.
- The average age on the African continent is 19.7 years, while in Europe it is closer to 40 years. It has great significance for the proportion of the population that becomes seriously ill, Nakstad emphasizes.
- The population in developing countries also has significantly lower mobility. They do not travel as often by plane, train, bus and ferry for holidays or work meetings as Europeans do.
Nakstad also points out that the climate is different.
- In parts of the world with cold winters, infection rises a lot as a result of increased contact frequency indoors. This is largely the reason why flu waves typically hit Europe in January and February each year.
Published the entire interview
After Faktisk.no contacted TV 2 about the interview with Nakstad, the TV channel has published the interview in its entirety. You can see that here.
It is five minutes into the interview that the news anchor asks:
At the very end Nakstad, somewhat like the status of vaccination, also in the world. How do you stand, for example, in African countries now, which was a challenge considering that omikron established itself, or came from there?
Then Nakstad replies:
You can say that this is interesting with vaccine coverage. It is high in the rich countries of the world. But also middle-income countries are approaching 50 percent vaccine coverage now. And then you have the poorest countries, which are around ten percent.
But we will probably reach a situation halfway through 2022 where most people in the world who want a vaccine are offered the vaccine. And then it looks like, for example in South Africa, that previously experienced illness at least has an effect on the infection numbers.
And it is not the case that the continents that have had the least vaccine have been hardest hit by the pandemic. It is perhaps the opposite - and there is perhaps also something to learn from - that it is easy to rely on a vaccine as a way out. But it may not always be the only means of action. We see that Europe, for example, with a highly vaccinated population, is the continent with the most infections.
Excessive faith in the vaccine alone
In the e-mail to Faktisk.no, Nakstad elaborates that morbidity and mortality in Europe would have been far higher without vaccination.
- But the belief that a vaccine alone is enough to keep control of the pandemic was excessively great in Europe in autumn 2021. The vaccines helped to reduce the R-number from an estimated 5-10 to values ​​down to 1.3 in Norway, he writes.
- But as long as the number of infections is above 1, the pandemic will grow, and over the autumn we had a record number of admissions with the delta variant in Norwegian hospitals. Therefore, it gradually became necessary to reintroduce infection control measures in Norway beyond late autumn.
Nakstad also writes that the vaccine has been shown to protect well against serious disease, but less well against transmission of infection with the new mutated virus variants.
- This does not mean that the vaccines are not effective in limiting the spread of infection, but they obviously cannot do the whole job alone, he states.
- That is why most countries still have advice to stay at home if you are sick, get tested for symptoms and use a mask if you are in trouble. Such measures, together with the vaccine effect, have contributed to the fact that the delta variant has soon been eradicated in Europe.
Encourages vaccination
According to Nakstad, there are several reasons to take the vaccine now, even though many are already infected.
- It is difficult to protect yourself from being infected in Norway now. But if you are vaccinated, you are well protected against serious illness, he writes.
- It is important both for yourself and for society, since the pressure on the healthcare system has been one of the main reasons why there has been a need for infection control measures in Norway.
The fact that omikron causes a milder disease is no reason not to take the vaccine, believes Nakstad.
- Omikron can still cause serious illness in some people, and unvaccinated people are over-represented among those who need hospitalization in Norway now, he says.
- Formerly healthy people are also admitted to hospital with the omicron variant because they have not been vaccinated. If you want to be well protected against serious illness, regardless of the virus variant, it is a good idea to get vaccinated.
