content:
CHECK - Neen, dit is niet zwaarlijvige "generaal Pavel" die door Russische president Poetin uit pensioen zou zijn gehaald
Verschillende internationale kranten brachten vorige maand opvallend nieuws: de Russische president Vladimir Poetin zou een zwaarlijvige 67-jarige generaal teruggeroepen hebben uit pensioen om hem naar de oorlog in Oekraïne te sturen. Een virale foto zou die gepensioneerde 'generaal Pavel' afbeelden. Uit een onderzoek van Knack en VRT NWS blijkt echter dat op de foto in kwestie iemand helemaal anders staat.
Het verhaal over 'generaal Pavel' verschijnt op 25 juni in het Britse boulevardblad The Daily Star. De krant beweerde exclusieve informatie te hebben ontvangen van een 'hooggeplaatste bron binnen de inlichtingendiensten'. The Daily Star schetst een gedetailleerd portret van 'generaal Pavel'. Hij zou 40 jaar gediend hebben in het Russische leger - onder andere in Afghanistan en Syrië - en zou sinds zijn pensioen in een buitenwijk van Moskou wonen. Vijf maaltijden per dag, doorgespoeld met een fles vodka, zorgden er echter voor dat hij nu 127 kilo weegt.
Niettemin zou Poetin de man uit pensioen teruggeroepen hebben om taken te vervullen in Oekraïne, waar verschillende Russische generaals gesneuveld zijn. Daarom zou voor 'generaal Pavel' een speciaal uniform gemaakt zijn, en heeft hij ook twee kogelvrije vesten nodig om zijn omvangrijke lichaam te bedekken, zo schrijft The Daily Star nog.
Heel wat andere kranten namen het verhaal over: eerst Britse en Amerikaanse tabloids, zoals The Sun en de New York Post, later ook allerlei internationale media - ook in ons land. Alleen Newsweek stelde zich wat kritische vragen bij de berichten over 'generaal Pavel'.
Het opvissen van een gepensioneerde generaal met obesitas zou moeten bewijzen dat Poetin ‘wanhopig’ aan het worden is en het onderste uit de kan moet halen om de gesneuvelde Russische generaals in Oekraïne te vervangen.
Het klopt dat de voorbije maanden bij de oorlog in Oekraïne een aantal Russische generaals omgekomen zijn. Maar klopt het verhaal over 'generaal Pavel' wel? Samen met factcheckers van Knack gingen we op zoek naar de herkomst van de foto.
Gezichtsherkenning
De afbeelding bij het artikel over 'generaal Pavel' blijkt al een tijdje te circuleren op het internet. De vroegste versie ervan vinden we op 5 juni op Twitter. Een Russische grappenmaker plaatste de foto toen online met als bijschrift het mopje 'Generaal van de kantine'.
We vinden het beeld in juni ook nog terug in verschillende groepen op het discussieplatform Reddit, waar nog meer grapjes worden gemaakt over de omvang van de man. Ook op verschillende Oost-Europese pagina's met internetmemes maakt men zich vrolijk over de foto. Maar niemand vermeldt de exacte context of wie erop afgebeeld staat.
Met de zoekmachine PimEyes, die werkt via gezichtsherkenning, kunnen we twee personen naast 'generaal Pavel' op de foto identificeren. Helemaal links blijkt Dmitry Litvinov te staan. Hij is het hoofd van de gemeentelijke administratie van het district Jelanski, dat binnen de oblast Volgograd in het zuidwesten van Rusland ligt. Naast hem, met smartphone in de hand, staat Alexander Bondarenko, eveneens een lokale gezagsdrager uit datzelfde gemeentelijke district.
Mogelijk is de foto dus in het district Jelanski genomen, maar waar precies? En wanneer?
Stoeptegels
Via Google Maps vinden we in het centrale park van de stad Jelan, de belangrijkste woonkern van het district, een opvallend oorlogsmonument. Het is ook zichtbaar op de achtergrond van de bewuste foto met 'generaal Pavel'.
Daarnaast blijken ook de speciale stoeptegels op de foto dezelfde als de tegels die op heel wat andere afbeeldingen uit het park van Jelan te zien zijn.
Belangrijker nog: op de precieze locatie waar de foto genomen is, blijkt een typische Russische roodgroene grenspaal te staan, naast een zwarte gedenkplaat. De groene militaire petten die verschillende personen dragen, behoren dan weer tot het uniform van de Russische grenswacht, een onderdeel van de Federale Veiligheidsdienst van de Russische Federatie (FSB).
'Dag van de Grenswacht'
Met de zoektermen 'grenswacht' en 'Jelan' vinden we al snel meer informatie. Op de lokale nieuwssite Elanskie-Vesti verscheen op 1 juni een artikel over hoe op 27 mei 'aan de vooravond van de Dag van de Grenswacht een plechtige bijeenkomst plaatsvond in het Centraal Cultuur- en Vrijetijdspark in Jelan, vlakbij de symbolische roodgroene grenspilaar en de herdenkingsplaat voor de soldaten-grenswachten'.
Elk jaar wordt in Rusland en in heel wat andere voormalige sovjetlanden op 28 mei de 'Dag van de Grenswacht' gevierd. Op de bewuste foto met de zogenaamde 'generaal Pavel' is dus een ceremonie te zien naar aanleiding van die feestdag, in de stad Jelan.
In de reportage van Elanskie-Vesti vinden we een originele, grotere foto terug, waaruit blijkt dat er eigenlijk een bijgeknipte versie circuleerde.
Op de officiële Telegram-pagina van het Jelanski-district staan nog meer foto's van de ceremonie. Ook daarop zien we 'generaal Pavel', die blijkbaar het woord nam tijdens de plechtigheden.
(Lees verder onder de afbeelding.)
Oezbekistan
Uiteindelijk vinden we op het Russische sociale netwerk Odnoklassniki een groepspagina terug van veteranen van de grenswacht uit Jelan. Via deze weg stoten we ook op het persoonlijke profiel van de zwaarlijvige man op de virale foto.
Hij blijkt geen 67-jarige generaal te zijn en hij heet ook niet 'Pavel'. Zijn echte naam is Ivan Ivanovitsj Toertsjin (58). Op het profiel deelt hij allerlei informatie en tientallen foto's over zijn militaire carrière, die liep van 1982 tot 2011. Na heel wat dienstjaren in het Russische leger, werkte Toertsjin van 1999 tot zijn pensioen bij de grenswacht in de Oezbeekse steden Jizzakh en Termiz, aan de grens met Afghanistan.
Uit de foto's die hij online plaatst, blijkt Turchin al minstens sinds 2013 de 'Dag van de Grenswacht' in Jelan bij te wonen. De voorbije weken plaatste hij vooral filmpjes van Russische charmezangers, inspirerende citaten, oude foto's en recepten voor pasteitjes en andere Russische gerechten. Niets wijst erop dat hij opnieuw in actieve dienst zou zijn, laat staan dat hij zich in Oekraïne zou bevinden.
Clickbait
Resteert nog de vraag hoe het artikel over 'generaal Pavel' terechtkwam in de Daily Star. De tabloid brengt normaalgezien vooral nieuws over sport, televisie en beroemdheden. Werd hen iets op de mouw gespeld door een onbetrouwbare bron? Of was het verhaal zelf verzonnen, uit sensatiezucht of als 'clickbait'? Drie jaar geleden werd de krant nog betrapt op het publiceren van een compleet verzonnen interview met acteur Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson.
Onze vragen aan de redactie en de betrokken journalist van de Daily Star bleven voorlopig onbeantwoord.
Conclusie
- De Britse tabloid The Daily Star lanceerde rond een virale foto van een zwaarlijvige man in legeruniform een verhaal over 'generaal Pavel', een 67-jarige gepensioneerde generaal uit Moskou die door Poetin uit pensioen zou zijn teruggeroepen om in Oekraïne te gaan vechten.
- De foto in kwestie blijkt genomen op 27 mei 2022 in het Russische Jelanski-district, tijdens een ceremonie aan de vooravond van de 'Dag van de Grenswacht', een militaire feestdag.
- De zwaarlijvige man op de foto is geen generaal die Pavel heet, maar Ivan Turchin, een 58-jarige voormalige grenswachter en militair.
- We beoordelen de stelling dat het zou gaan om een 67-jarige 'generaal Pavel', die als gepensioneerde door Poetin naar Oekraïne zou zijn gestuurd, dan ook als niet waar.
Dit artikel is geschreven op basis van de beschikbare informatie op de datum van publicatie.
Wil je iets laten checken? Stuur ons dan een mail via check@vrtnws.be.
Meer informatie over de factchecks van VRT NWS lees je in dit artikel.
Translation:
CHECK - No, this is not obese "General Pavel" who was allegedly brought out of retirement by Russian President Putin
Several international newspapers reported striking news last month: Russian President Vladimir Putin reportedly recalled an obese 67-year-old general from retirement to send him to the war in Ukraine. A viral photo would depict that retired 'General Pavel'. However, research by Knack and VRT NWS shows that the photo in question shows someone completely different.
The story about 'General Pavel' appears on June 25 in the British newspaper The Daily Star. The newspaper claimed to have received exclusive information from a 'highly placed source within the intelligence services'. The Daily Star paints a detailed portrait of 'General Pavel'. He is said to have served in the Russian army for 40 years - including in Afghanistan and Syria - and has lived in a suburb of Moscow since his retirement. However, five meals a day, washed down with a bottle of vodka, meant that he now weighs 127 kilos.
Nevertheless, Putin is said to have called the man back from retirement to perform duties in Ukraine, where several Russian generals have been killed. That is why a special uniform has been made for 'General Pavel', and he also needs two bulletproof vests to cover his bulky body, The Daily Star reports.
Many other newspapers took up the story: first British and American tabloids, such as The Sun and the New York Post, later also all kinds of international media - including in our country. Only Newsweek asked some critical questions about the reports about 'General Pavel'.
The fishing out of a retired general with obesity should prove that Putin is becoming 'desperate' and needs to do everything he can to replace the fallen Russian generals in Ukraine.
It is true that a number of Russian generals have been killed in the war in Ukraine in recent months. But is the story about 'General Pavel' true? Together with fact checkers from Knack we looked for the origin of the photo.
Facial recognition
The image accompanying the article about 'General Pavel' appears to have been circulating on the internet for some time. The earliest version of it can be found on Twitter on June 5. A Russian prankster then posted the photo online with the caption 'General of the canteen'.
We also found the image in various groups on the discussion platform Reddit in June, where even more jokes were made about the size of the man. People are also making fun of the photo on various Eastern European pages with internet memes. But no one mentions the exact context or who is depicted in it.
With the search engine PimEyes, which works via facial recognition, we can identify two people next to 'General Pavel' in the photo. Dmitry Litvinov appears to be standing on the far left. He is the head of the municipal administration of Yelansky District, located within Volgograd Oblast in southwestern Russia. Next to him, with smartphone in hand, stands Alexander Bondarenko, also a local authority figure from the same municipal district.
So the photo may have been taken in the Jelanski district, but where exactly? And when?
Pavement tiles
Via Google Maps we find a striking war memorial in the central park of the city of Jelan, the main residential area of ​​the district. It is also visible in the background of the photo in question with 'General Pavel'.
In addition, the special paving tiles in the photo also appear to be the same as the tiles that can be seen in many other images from Jelan's park.
More importantly, at the precise location where the photo was taken, there appears to be a typical Russian red-green border marker, next to a black memorial plaque. The green military caps that various people wear belong to the uniform of the Russian Border Guard, part of the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation (FSB).
'Day of the Border Guard'
We can quickly find more information using the search terms 'border guard' and 'Jelan'. On June 1, the local news site Elanskie-Vesti published an article about how on May 27, 'on the eve of Border Guard Day, a solemn meeting took place in the Central Culture and Leisure Park in Jelan, near the symbolic red-green border pillar and the memorial plaque for the border guard soldiers'.
Every year in Russia and many other former Soviet countries, 'Border Guard Day' is celebrated on May 28. The photo in question with the so-called 'General Pavel' shows a ceremony on the occasion of that holiday, in the city of Jelan.
In the Elanskie-Vesti report we find an original, larger photo, which shows that a cropped version was actually circulating.
There are more photos from the ceremony on the official Telegram page of the Jelanski District. We also see 'General Pavel', who apparently spoke during the ceremonies.
(Continue reading below the image.)
Uzbekistan
Ultimately, we found a group page of border guard veterans from Yelan on the Russian social network Odnoklassniki. This is how we also came across the personal profile of the obese man in the viral photo.
It turns out he is not a 67-year-old general and his name is not 'Pavel'. His real name is Ivan Ivanovich Turchin (58). On the profile he shares all kinds of information and dozens of photos about his military career, which ran from 1982 to 2011. After many years of service in the Russian army, Turchin worked from 1999 until his retirement with the border guard in the Uzbek cities of Jizzakh and Termiz, on the border with Afghanistan.
From the photos he posts online, Turchin appears to have attended the 'Day of the Border Guard' in Jelan since at least 2013. In recent weeks he has mainly posted videos of Russian charm singers, inspiring quotes, old photos and recipes for pies and other Russian dishes. There is no indication that he would be on active duty again, let alone in Ukraine.
Clickbait
The question remains how the article about 'General Pavel' ended up in the Daily Star. The tabloid normally mainly reports news about sports, television and celebrities. Were they being tricked by an unreliable source? Or was the story itself made up, out of sensationalism or as 'clickbait'? Three years ago, the newspaper was caught publishing a completely fabricated interview with actor Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson.
Our questions to the editors and the journalist involved at the Daily Star remained unanswered for the time being.
Conclusion
- The British tabloid The Daily Star launched a story about 'General Pavel', a 67-year-old retired general from Moscow who was allegedly recalled from retirement by Putin to fight in Ukraine, around a viral photo of an obese man in an army uniform.
- The photo in question appears to have been taken on May 27, 2022 in Russia's Yelansky district, during a ceremony on the eve of 'Border Guard Day', a military holiday.
- The obese man in the photo is not a general named Pavel, but Ivan Turchin, a 58-year-old former border guard and soldier.
- We therefore assess the statement that it concerns a 67-year-old 'General Pavel', who was sent to Ukraine as a pensioner by Putin, as untrue.
This article was written based on the information available at the date of publication.
Would you like to have something checked? Send us an email at check@vrtnws.be.
You can read more information about the fact checks of VRT NWS in this article.

Během italských voleb, ve kterých koncem minulého týdne zvítězily krajně pravicové strany, se na sociáních sítích začalo šířit staré video zachycující demonstraci, při níž neofašistická skupina sundala z budovy vlajku Evropské unie a nahradila ji vlajkou Itálie. Taková akce sice skutečně proběhla, ale již v roce 2013, takže video je záměrně vytrženo z kontextu.
„V Římě je vlajka EU stažena a nahrazena vlajkou italskou,” hlásá například tento facebookový příspěvek z 24. září 2022, který obsahuje zhruba třičtvrtěminutové video se skupinou demonstrantů mávajících italskými vlajkami před budovou v Římě. Jeden z nich vyleze na balkón budovy a strhne vlajku EU, kterou hodí na zem, zatímco dav skanduje „Italia, nazione, revoluzione” (Itálie, národ, revoluce).
Toto video bylo sdíleno i v dalších jazycích (například v řečtině, francouzštině či srbštině) jen hodiny před tím, než koalice vedená krajně pravicovou stranou Frattelli d’Italia v čele s Giorgií Meloni zvítězila v italských parlamentních volbách.
Některé z těchto příspěvků zmiňují prezidentku Evropské komise Ursulu von der Leyen, která 22. září prohlásila, že EU má „nástroje na to, jak s Itálii jednat v případě, že by se vydala složitým směrem” – tj. kdyby krajní pravice vyhrála volby.
Tato prohlášení vyvolala italské krajní pravice silné reakce: 23. září uspořádala strana Liga před sídlem Evropské komise v Římě protestní akci. Zúčastnil se jí i vůdce Ligy Matteo Salvini. Podle videoreportéra agentury AFP, který akci natáčel, byl protest velmi klidný. Žádnou staženou vlajku EU prý nezaznamenal.
Video sdílené na sociálních sítích je staré a tudíž je vytržené z aktuálního kontextu. Zachycuje sice protestní akci, která se odehrála před sídlem Evropské komise v Římě, ale bylo natočeno již v roce 2013 a s nedávnými italskými parlamentními volbami z 25. září 2022 nemá nic společného.
Video z prosince 2013
Pomocí zpětného vyhledávání videí se nám na Youtube podařilo najít dvě podobná videa zde a zde. Záběry sdílené na Facebooku jsou na těchto youtubových videích vidět v časech 2:23 a 2:30.
Obě videa byla zveřejněna v roce 2013, a to 15. a 19. prosince. To z 19. prosince zveřejnila neofašistická skupina „CasaPound” působící v Itálii od roku 2003, která podle vlastních slov akci zorganizovala 14. prosince 2013 pro „národní a měnovou suverenitu”. Video zveřejněné 15. prosince bylo použito v článku francouzského zpravodajství Franceinfo pojednávajícího o této krajně pravicové skupině.
O demonstraci na videu informovala 14. prosince 2013 také agentura Reuters, která akci taktéž připisuje organizaci „CasaPound”.
Jedná se tedy skutečně o akci, která se odehrála před zastoupením Evropské komise v Římě, ovšem již v roce 2013 a nikoliv po nějakém prohlášení Ursuly von der Leyen, jež v té době ještě nestála v čele Evropské komise.
Neofašistická skupina „CasaPound” je v Itálii známá obsazováním budov v Římě a svými „akcemi” na pomoc chudým rodinám, ale také protiimigračními a antiglobalizačními postoji.
Tato skupina bývá přirovnávána k řeckému hnutí Zlatý úsvit, které používá podobné metody.
Vyhledávání pomocí klíčových slov v italštině však nepřineslo žádné výsledky o jakékoliv akci zorganizované v poslední době hnutím „CasaPound” v Římě. Poslední zmínka o demonstraci tohoto uskupení pochází z května 2022, kdy mu byl odepřen přístup na římské náměstí Piazza di Santa Maria Maggiore.
Ekonomické reformy Maria Draghiho
Evropská komise v pondělí uvedla, že doufá udržovat s příští italskou vládou konstruktivní vztahy. Komise jako výkonný orgán EU zásadně spolupracuje „s vládami, které vzejdou z voleb”, uvedl mluvčí EU Eric Mamer na tiskovém brífinku. „V tomto případě tomu není jinak. Samozřejmě doufáme, že s novými italskými orgány budeme konstruktivně spolupracovat,” dodal.
Nový italský kabinet nahradí vládu národní jednoty, v jejímž čele stojí od ledna 2021 Mario Draghi, bývalý šéf Evropské centrální banky (ECB).
Mario Draghi vyjednal s Bruselem poskytnutí finanční pomoci Itálii ve výši téměř 200 miliard eur výměnou za hluboké hospodářské a institucionální reformy. Někteří Italové tuto dohodu považovali za další „bruselský diktát”.
Draghi v srpnu prohlásil, že nová vláda bude muset respektovat reformní sliby dané Bruselu a zůstat „v centru EU a mezinárodních spojenectví”.
Postfašistická strana Bratři Itálie v čele s Meloni ve volbách konaných 25. září přesvědčivě zvítězila. Budoucí šéfka kabinetu, která nemá s vládnutím žádné zkušenosti, však bude muset sestavit napříč stranami vládu schopnou vypořádat se s nebývale vysokou inflací a cenami energií. Navíc bude muset udržovat vztahy s nedůvěřivou EU.
K tomu, aby pětačtyřicetiletá Meloni stanula jako první žena v čele italské vlády, potřebuje krajně pravicové spojence – Ligu Mattea Salviniho a Forzu Italia bývalého premiéra Silvia Berlusconiho. Jen s jejich pomocí totiž získá parlamentní většinu.
Evropská komise 27. září schválila druhou splátku postpandemických fondů na obnovu Itálie ve výši 21 miliard eur. Meloni však prohlásila, že chce o dohodě s Bruselem znovu jednat, což by mohlo ohrozit zbytek fondu v celkové hodnotě téměř 200 miliard eur. Přes euroskeptickou minulost Meloni je však podle analytiků ještě příliš brzy na to říci, jaký bude mít s EU vztah.
Translation:
During Italy's election, which was won by far-right parties late last week, an old video of a demonstration in which a neo-fascist group removed the European Union flag from a building and replaced it with the flag of Italy began to circulate on social media. Such an event did indeed take place, but already in 2013, so the video is deliberately taken out of context.
"In Rome, the EU flag is taken down and replaced by the Italian flag," reads, for example, this Facebook post from September 24, 2022, which includes a roughly three-quarter-minute video of a group of protesters waving Italian flags in front of a building in Rome. One of them climbs onto the balcony of the building and tears down the EU flag, which he throws on the ground while the crowd chants "Italia, nazione, revoluzione" (Italy, nation, revolution).
This video was also shared in other languages ​​(such as Greek, French or Serbian) just hours before the coalition led by the far-right Frattelli d'Italia party led by Giorgia Meloni won the Italian parliamentary elections.
Some of these posts mention European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, who said on September 22 that the EU has "the tools to deal with Italy in the event that it goes in a difficult direction" - i.e. if the far right wins the election.
These statements provoked strong reactions from the Italian far-right: on September 23, the Liga party organized a protest in front of the European Commission headquarters in Rome. League leader Matteo Salvini also attended. According to an AFP video reporter who filmed the event, the protest was very peaceful. He said he did not notice any lowered EU flag.
The video shared on social networks is old and therefore out of context. Although it captures a protest action that took place in front of the European Commission headquarters in Rome, it was already filmed in 2013 and has nothing to do with the recent Italian parliamentary elections on September 25, 2022.
Video from December 2013
Using a reverse video search we were able to find two similar videos on Youtube here and here. Footage shared on Facebook can be seen at 2:23 and 2:30 in these YouTube videos.
Both videos were published in 2013, on December 15 and 19. This was published on December 19 by the neo-fascist group "CasaPound" operating in Italy since 2003, which, according to its own words, organized the event on December 14, 2013 for "national and monetary sovereignty". The video, published on December 15, was used in an article by French news agency Franceinfo discussing the far-right group.
On December 14, 2013, the Reuters agency also reported on the demonstration on video, which also attributes the event to the "CasaPound" organization.
So this is really an event that took place before the representation of the European Commission in Rome, but already in 2013 and not after some statement by Ursula von der Leyen, who was not yet the head of the European Commission at that time.
The neo-fascist group "CasaPound" is known in Italy for occupying buildings in Rome and for its "actions" to help poor families, but also for its anti-immigration and anti-globalization stances.
This group is often compared to the Greek Golden Dawn movement, which uses similar methods.
However, a search using keywords in Italian did not yield any results about any recent event organized by the "CasaPound" movement in Rome. The last mention of a demonstration by this group comes from May 2022, when it was denied access to Rome's Piazza di Santa Maria Maggiore.
Mario Draghi's economic reforms
The European Commission said on Monday it hoped to maintain constructive relations with the next Italian government. As the executive body of the EU, the Commission fundamentally cooperates "with the governments that emerge from the elections", said EU spokesman Eric Mamer at a press briefing. "It is no different in this case. Of course, we hope to cooperate constructively with the new Italian authorities," he added.
The new Italian cabinet will replace the government of national unity, headed by Mario Draghi, the former head of the European Central Bank (ECB), from January 2021.
Mario Draghi negotiated with Brussels to provide financial aid to Italy amounting to almost 200 billion euros in exchange for deep economic and institutional reforms. Some Italians considered this agreement another "Brussels dictate".
Draghi said in August that the new government will have to respect the reform promises made to Brussels and remain "at the center of the EU and international alliances".
The post-fascist party Brothers of Italy, led by Meloni, won the elections held on September 25 convincingly. However, the future head of the cabinet, who has no experience in governing, will have to form a cross-party government capable of dealing with unprecedentedly high inflation and energy prices. In addition, he will have to maintain relations with the distrustful EU.
In order for the 45-year-old Meloni to become the first woman to head the Italian government, she needs far-right allies - Matteo Salvini's League and former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's Forza Italia. Only with their help will he gain a parliamentary majority.
On September 27, the European Commission approved the second installment of post-pandemic funds for the reconstruction of Italy in the amount of 21 billion euros. But Meloni has said she wants to renegotiate the deal with Brussels, which could jeopardize the rest of the fund, worth a total of nearly 200 billion euros. Despite Meloni's Eurosceptic past, however, according to analysts, it is still too early to say what kind of relationship he will have with the EU.

Im Vorfeld der Europawahl lassen sich im Netz viele Mythen und Falschaussagen zu Stimmzetteln finden. Der AFP-Faktencheck hat zwei dieser Fake News analysiert. Zusätzlich gibt der Berliner Bezirkswahlleiter Rolfdieter Bohm Antworten auf die Frage, was mit dem Wahlzettel erlaubt ist.
- Wo das Kreuz setzen?
In sozialen Netzwerken wird ein Bild geteilt, das dazu aufruft, sein Kreuz richtig zu setzen. Angeblich würde ein Wahlzettel ungültig, wenn das Kreuz über den dafür vorgesehenen Kreis hinaus gehe (hier der AFP Faktencheck).
Rolfdieter Bohm, Bezirkswahlleiter Berlin Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg: „Es muss klar sein, welcher Wahlvorschlag angekreuzt sein soll. Also ob ich das Kreuz jetzt in diesem Kreischen mache oder vorne bei der Kurzbezeichnung, ist im Prinzip egal.“
- Ecke ab oder Loch im Stimmzettel
Ein anderes Bild zeigt einen Stimmzettel mit Lochung in der rechten oberen Ecke. Angeblich würden so Wahlbriefunterlagen vorab ungültig gemacht. Tatsächlich können Markierungen, wie die abgeschnittene Ecke des Europawahlzettels, Menschen mit Sehbehinderung dabei helfen, eine Schablone zum Ankreuzen anzulegen. Die Markierung, ob Lochung oder Ecke, macht den Wahlzettel also nicht ungültig (hier der AFP Faktencheck).
Rolfdieter Bohm: „Wenn es ein Loch irgendwo am Rand ist, spielt keine Rolle. Und wenn das mal gefaltet ist, irgendwie eine Ecke fehlt, macht den Stimmzettel nicht ungültig.“
- Was macht den Wahlzettel ungültig?
Rolfdieter Bohm:
„Was ungültig macht, sind irgendwelche Kommentare, Anmerkungen, wenn man was drauf schreibt. Von wegen „finde ich blöd“ oder „finde ich toll“ oder sonst irgendwas. Das es kann den Stimmzettel ungültig machen.“
Außerdem muss der Wählerwille klar erkennbar sein. Uneindeutige Zeichen wie Smiley-Gesichter oder ähnliches sind unzulässig. Genauso wie Kennzeichen verfassungswidriger Organisationen.
Die Europawahl findet in Deutschland am 9. Juni statt. Bis zum 7. Juni kann noch Briefwahl beantragt werden.
Weitere Faktenchecks rund um die Europawahl sammelt AFP hier.
Translation:
In the run-up to the European elections, many myths and false statements about ballot papers can be found online. The AFP Fact Check analyzed two of these fake news. In addition, Berlin district returning officer Rolfdieter Bohm provides answers to the question of what is allowed with the ballot paper.
- Where to put the cross?
An image is shared on social networks that calls on people to place their cross correctly. Apparently a ballot paper would be invalid if the cross went beyond the designated circle (here the AFP fact check).
Rolfdieter Bohm, Berlin Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg district returning officer: “It must be clear which election proposal should be ticked. So whether I make the cross in this screech or at the front of the abbreviation, it doesn’t really matter.”
- Corner or hole in the ballot paper
Another image shows a ballot paper with holes punched in the top right corner. Supposedly this would invalidate voting postal documents in advance. In fact, markings, such as the cut corner of the European ballot paper, can help people with visual impairments create a template for ticking. The marking, whether perforated or corner, does not make the ballot paper invalid (here the AFP fact check).
Rolfdieter Bohm: “If there is a hole somewhere on the edge, it doesn’t matter. And once it’s folded, somehow a corner is missing, that doesn’t make the ballot invalid.”
- What makes the ballot paper invalid?
Rolfdieter Bohm:
“What makes things invalid are any comments or notes when you write something on them. Because of “I think it’s stupid” or “I think it’s great” or anything else. That it can invalidate the ballot.”
In addition, the will of the voters must be clearly visible. Ambiguous characters such as smiley faces or similar are not permitted. Just like characteristics of unconstitutional organizations.
The European elections will take place in Germany on June 9th. You can still apply for a postal vote until June 7th.
AFP collects further fact checks about the European elections here.

Bewertung
Das Zitat ist verkürzt, denn aus einem Beitrag Heinrichs wurde ein entscheidendes Wort weggelassen: 2016 schrieb sie, dass Juden und Asiaten «keine weissen Menschen» seien.
Fakten
Die Kurznachricht von Heinrich findet sich auf der Plattform X (vormals Twitter) nicht mehr im Original. Es gibt jedoch eine Sicherung im Internet-Archiv «archive.today». Sie zeigt, dass Heinrich am 10. November 2016 in einer Diskussion schrieb: «Juden und asiaten sind keine weissen Menschen und bei Slawen weiss ichs ehrlich gesagt nicht» (Rechtschreibung wie im Original). Das Adjektiv «weisse» fehlt in dem derzeit kursierenden, Heinrich zugeschriebenen Satz.
Als Heinrich im Jahr 2021 zur Bundessprecherin der Grünen Jugend gewählt wurde, entbrannte eine Diskussion über ältere Tweets von ihr, die von vielen Nutzerinnen und Nutzern als diskriminierend und beleidigend kritisiert wurden. Heinrich sprach später von Beiträgen, die «zum Teil vulgär und beleidigend» seien – und entschuldigte sich. Sie verwies aber auch darauf, dass sie «13/14 Jahre alt» gewesen sei. Ob sie dabei auch über ihre Nachricht über Asiaten und Juden sprach, ist nicht bekannt. Als sie den Beitrag veröffentlichte, war sie 15 Jahre alt.
(Stand: 21.8.2023)
Translation:
Evaluation
The quote is shortened because a crucial word was left out of one of Heinrich's contributions: in 2016 she wrote that Jews and Asians are “not white people”.
Facts
Heinrich's short message can no longer be found in its original form on Platform X (formerly Twitter). However, there is a backup in the Internet archive “archive.today”. It shows that Heinrich wrote in a discussion on November 10, 2016: "Jews and Asians are not white people and I honestly don't know about Slavs" (spelling as in the original). The adjective “white” is missing from the currently circulating sentence attributed to Heinrich.
When Heinrich was elected federal spokesperson for the Green Youth in 2021, a discussion arose about her older tweets, which were criticized by many users as discriminatory and offensive. Heinrich later spoke of contributions that were “sometimes vulgar and offensive” – and apologized. But she also pointed out that she was “13/14 years old”. It is not known whether she also discussed her message about Asians and Jews. She was 15 years old when she published the post.
(As of: August 21, 2023)

Teiginiai
Joe Bidenas prisipažino gimęs Izraelyje.
Verdiktas
Melas. Joe Bideno kalbos stenograma iš apsilankymo Tel Avive ir renginio vaizdo įrašas įrodo, kad prezidentas nesakė, jog yra gimęs Izraelyje.
Melo detektoriaus komentaras
Spalio 18 d. Rusijos naujienų agentūra „Tass“ publikavo straipsnį pavadinimu „Bidenas negali būti renkamas JAV prezidentu, jei gimė Izraelyje – Rusijos diplomatas“ (archyvas). Šią antraštę įkvėpė Rusijos užsienio reikalų ministerijos atstovės spaudai Marijos Zacharovos tvirtinimai, esą JAV vadovas vizito į Tel Avivą metu viešai prisipažino, kad yra gimęs Izraelyje.
Netrukus panašūs teiginiai išplatinti ir socialiniuose tinkluose kartu su trumpa vaizdo iškarpa iš J. Bideno kalbos Izraelyje, tačiau klausant prezidento tariamų žodžių akivaizdu, kad Rusijos propagandistai tiesiog gerai neišgirdo, ką angliškai sakė JAV vadovas.
Tiek dėmesio sulaukusi kalba buvo pasakyta spalio 18 d. vizito Tel Avive, Izraelyje, metu. „Youtube“ platformoje galima rasti visą renginio įrašą (čia). JAV prezidento kalba prasideda maždaug nuo 17:39 min., tačiau socialinių tinklų vartotojus ir Rusijos propagandistus sudomino tik viena konkreti kalbos pastraipa, kurią galima rasti Baltųjų rūmų svetainėje paviešintoje stenogramoje (čia) (aut. past. – pateikiame pastraipos vertimą į lietuvių kalbą): „Izraelio valstybė gimė tam, kad būtų saugi vieta pasaulio žydų tautai. Todėl ji ir gimė. Jau seniai sakiau: Jei Izraelio nebūtų, mes turėtume jį išrasti.“ Angliškai frazė „Todėl ji ir gimė“ skamba, kaip „That’s why it was born“, o, tuo tarpu, melagieną apie tariamą J. Bideno gimimo vietą paskleidę asmenys šią frazę išgirdo, kaip „That‘s where I was born“, kas reikštų „Štai, kur aš gimiau“.
Tiek J. Bideno kalbos vaizdo įrašas, tiek Baltųjų rūmų interneto svetainėje pateikta stenograma įrodo, kad prezidentas neprisipažino gimęs Izraelyje, o išreikšdamas susirūpinimą šalimi, kuri nukentėjo nuo „Hamas“ atakų, užsiminė apie Izraelio valstybės atsiradimą.
Translation:
Statements
Joe Biden admitted he was born in Israel.
Verdict
A lie. A transcript of Joe Biden's speech from a visit to Tel Aviv and a video of the event prove the president did not say he was born in Israel.
Lie detector comment
October 18 The Russian news agency "Tass" published an article entitled "Biden cannot be elected president of the United States if he was born in Israel - a Russian diplomat" (archive). This headline was inspired by Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova's claims that the US leader publicly admitted to being born in Israel during a visit to Tel Aviv.
Soon, similar statements were spread on social networks along with a short video clip from Mr. Biden's speech in Israel, but listening to the president's alleged words, it is clear that the Russian propagandists simply did not hear well what the US leader said in English.
The speech that received so much attention was delivered on October 18. during a visit to Tel Aviv, Israel. A full recording of the event can be found on the YouTube platform (here). The US President's speech starts at approximately 17:39, but social media users and Russian propagandists were only interested in one specific paragraph of the speech, which can be found in the transcript published on the White House website (here) : "The State of Israel was born to be a safe place for the Jewish people of the world. That's why she was born. I said a long time ago: If Israel didn't exist, we would have to invent it. heard "That's where I was born", which would mean "That's where I was born".
Both a video of Mr. Biden's speech and a transcript posted on the White House website show that the president did not admit to being born in Israel, but instead hinted at the creation of the state of Israel while expressing concern for the country, which has been hit by attacks by Hamas.

Non, ce prêtre mexicain qui s'est évanoui lors d'une messe n'est pas mort après avoir été vacciné contre le Covid
Non, ce prêtre mexicain qui s'est évanoui lors d'une messe n'est pas mort après avoir été vacciné contre le Covid
Publié le vendredi 26 novembre 2021 à 16:46
© AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE | 2024 | Tous droits réservés.
- Auteur(s)
Juliette Mansour, AFP France, AFP Mexique
Une vidéo montrant un prêtre mexicain s'évanouir en pleine messe est partagée par des internautes français soutenant que l'ecclésiastique serait "mort après avoir été vacciné contre le Covid-19". C'est faux, le père Ángel Cuevas, qui apparaît sur les images et est à la tête de l'église Notre-Dame de Guadalupe, à Acapulco, est bien vivant et un journaliste de l'AFP a pu le rencontrer le 25 novembre 2021, près de deux mois après les faits. Le prêtre a expliqué que son évanouissement "n'était en aucun cas une conséquence du vaccin", et a assuré aller "parfaitement bien" désormais.
"Un prêtre 'meurt soudainement' pendant son sermon après s'être fait vacciner… Qu’il soit accueilli par St Pierre au paradis des victimes de Big Pharma !", ironise un internaute français dans un tweet accompagné de la vidéo.
Capture d'écran prise sur Twitter le 26/11/2021
Sur les images, un prêtre en train d'animer une messe en espagnol commence à vaciller, et est rattrapé à bout de bras par une femme, alors qu'il s'effondre derrière l'autel. L'extrait se termine en montrant plusieurs fidèles venir lui porter secours.
La vidéo a été partagée plus d'un millier de fois depuis le 23 novembre sur Twitter (1, 2, 3) ainsi que sur Facebook, avec des légendes indiquant à chaque fois que le prêtre serait "mort soudainement après s'être fait vacciner contre le Covid-19". Elle a également circulé en espagnol et en anglais (1, 2).
Capture d'écran prise le 26/11/2021 sur Twitter
Capture d'écran prise le 26/11/2021 sur Twitter
Capture d'écran prise le 26/11/2021
Capture d'écran prise le 26/11/2021 sur Facebook
En commentaires, des internautes assurent que des "dizaines de milliers de victimes" seraient mortes de la même façon à cause des vaccins, et condamnent la position du Pape François qui avait incité les croyants à se faire vacciner au mois d'août.
Capture d'écran prise le 26/11/2021 sur Twitter
"Ce n'est en aucune façon une conséquence du vaccin"
En effectuant une recherche d'image inversée sur Google, une occurrence de la vidéo apparaît dans un article en espagnol, publié le 4 septembre sur le site mexicain 24-horas.
Capture d'écran prise le 26/11/2021 sur Google
L'article explique qu'"un curé de la paroisse Notre-Dame de Guadalupe, Ángel Cuevas, s'est évanoui en célébrant une messe qui était diffusée en direct".
La même vidéo que celle qui circule en France est intégrée dans l'article, publiée par la chaîne Youtube de Quadratin Guerrero, un média mexicain, qui précise que la scène s'est déroulée le 4 septembre 2021.
Là-aussi, les internautes mettent en cause le vaccin dans les commentaires en espagnol, bien que le média n'en fasse jamais mention.
Capture d'écran prise le 26/11/2021 sur Youtube
Avec le nom de l'église et l'adresse, donnés par le média Quadratin Guerrero, il est possible de retrouver le bâtiment sur Google Maps, qui se situe à Acapulco, au Mexique.
Des photos montrent l'intérieur de l'église, qui correspond bien à celui diffusé dans la vidéo virale, comme le montre la comparaison ci-dessous.
Capture d'écran de la vidéo virale
Photo de l'église Notre-Dame de Guadalupe
L'AFP a d'abord contacté par téléphone le Père Ángel Cuevas le 25 novembre, qui a pu expliquer le contexte dans lequel la vidéo virale a été tournée : "C'était simplement une chute de tension, ce n'est pas grand chose. Je vais parfaitement bien" a-t-il souligné.
Il a réfuté les rumeurs liant cet incident à une potentielle vaccination anti-Covid. "Ce n'est en aucune façon une conséquence du vaccin", a-t-il ainsi insisté.
Un journaliste de l'AFP a ensuite rencontré le prêtre le même jour et a pu le prendre en photo :
Le Père Angel Cuevas pose devant un mur décoré d'une fresque religieuse le 25 novembre 2021
Aujourd'hui, le Père Ángel Cuevas continue d'officier, et ses messes sont quotidiennement retransmises en direct sur la page Facebook de l'église Notre-Dame de Guadalupe.
A ce jour, le Mexique a administré plus de 131 millions de doses de vaccins anti-Covid, et un peu plus de la moitié des 126 millions d'habitants de la population est complètement vaccinée.
Le Mexique est le quatrième pays le plus endeuillé au monde par la pandémie avec 293.449 morts du Covid, après les Etats-Unis, le Brésil et l'Inde.
Graphique montrant le nombre de morts du Covid au Mexique depuis le début de la pandémie

Translation:
No, this Mexican priest who fainted during a mass did not die after being vaccinated against Covid
No, this Mexican priest who fainted during a mass did not die after being vaccinated against Covid
Published on Friday November 26, 2021 at 4:46 p.m.
© AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE | 2024 | All rights reserved.
- Author(s)
Juliette Mansour, AFP France, AFP Mexico
A video showing a Mexican priest fainting in the middle of mass is shared by French Internet users claiming that the clergyman “died after being vaccinated against Covid-19”. This is false, Father Ángel Cuevas, who appears in the images and is at the head of the Church of Our Lady of Guadalupe, in Acapulco, is alive and well and an AFP journalist was able to meet him on November 25 2021, almost two months after the fact. The priest explained that his fainting “was in no way a consequence of the vaccine”, and assured that he was “perfectly well” from now on.
“A priest 'dies suddenly' during his sermon after being vaccinated... May he be welcomed by St Pierre to the paradise of victims of Big Pharma!”, quips a French internet user in a tweet accompanied by the video.
Screenshot taken on Twitter on 11/26/2021
In the images, a priest leading a mass in Spanish begins to wobble, and is caught at arm's length by a woman, as he collapses behind the altar. The extract ends by showing several faithful coming to help him.
The video has been shared more than a thousand times since November 23 on Twitter (1, 2, 3) as well as on Facebook, with captions indicating each time that the priest “died suddenly after being vaccinated against Covid-19. It also circulated in Spanish and English (1, 2).
Screenshot taken on 11/26/2021 on Twitter
Screenshot taken on 11/26/2021 on Twitter
Screenshot taken on 11/26/2021
Screenshot taken on 11/26/2021 on Facebook
In comments, Internet users assure that “tens of thousands of victims” would have died in the same way because of vaccines, and condemn the position of Pope Francis who encouraged believers to be vaccinated in August.
Screenshot taken on 11/26/2021 on Twitter
“This is in no way a consequence of the vaccine”
Performing a reverse image search on Google, an occurrence of the video appeared in a Spanish-language article, published September 4 on the Mexican site 24-horas.
Screenshot taken on 11/26/2021 on Google
The article explains that "a priest of the parish of Our Lady of Guadalupe, Ángel Cuevas, fainted while celebrating a mass that was broadcast live."
The same video that is circulating in France is integrated into the article, published by the Youtube channel of Quadratin Guerrero, a Mexican media outlet, which specifies that the scene took place on September 4, 2021.
Here too, Internet users question the vaccine in the comments in Spanish, although the media never mentions it.
Screenshot taken on 11/26/2021 on Youtube
With the name of the church and the address, given by the media Quadratin Guerrero, it is possible to find the building on Google Maps, which is located in Acapulco, Mexico.
Photos show the interior of the church, which matches well with that shown in the viral video, as seen in the comparison below.
Screenshot of viral video
Photo of Our Lady of Guadalupe Church
AFP first contacted Father Ángel Cuevas by telephone on November 25, who was able to explain the context in which the viral video was filmed: "It was just a drop in tension, it's not much "I'm perfectly fine," he said.
He refuted rumors linking this incident to a potential anti-Covid vaccination. “This is in no way a consequence of the vaccine,” he insisted.
An AFP journalist then met the priest the same day and was able to take a photo of him:
Father Angel Cuevas poses in front of a wall decorated with a religious fresco on November 25, 2021
Today, Father Ángel Cuevas continues to officiate, and his masses are broadcast live daily on the Facebook page of the Church of Our Lady of Guadalupe.
To date, Mexico has administered more than 131 million doses of anti-Covid vaccines, and just over half of the population of 126 million is fully vaccinated.
Mexico is the fourth country most bereaved in the world by the pandemic with 293,449 deaths from Covid, after the United States, Brazil and India.

content:
Bewertung
Die Bilder der Sportler stammen aus der Zeit vor der Corona-Pandemie. Das Zitat Bill Gates‘ wird zudem unvollständig wiedergegeben und seine Aussage dadurch verfälscht.
Fakten
Alle Sportfotos sind vor 2020 entstanden. Eins davon zeigt einen realen Notfall auf dem Spielfeld – der jedoch 20 Jahre zurückliegt.
So ist auf dem Foto links in der Mitte der kamerunische Fußballer Marc-Vivien Foé auf einer Trage zu sehen. Foé erlitt im Juni 2003 während eines Spiels zwischen Kamerun und Kolumbien einen Herzinfarkt und starb. Er hatte eine hypertrophe Kardiomyopathie, eine erblich bedingte Vorerkrankung des Herzmuskels, die das Infarktrisiko bei sportlicher Betätigung erhöht.
Das mittig rechts positionierte Bild, das eine Wiederbelebung zeigt, taucht online oft im internationalen Kontext der Informationen und Werbung für Defibrillatoren auf. Auf der Webseite der Argentinischen Gesellschaft für Kardiologie (Sociedad Argentina de Cardiología) wurde das Bild etwa im August 2018 publiziert. Man findet online auch andere Einstellungen dieser Szene. Es scheint daher naheliegend, dass das (inszenierte) Bild bei einem Fotoshooting zum Thema Defibrillatoren entstanden ist.
Das Foto unten rechts lässt sich dem Fotografen Edward Morgan zuordnen. Das als «Agony» («Qual») betitelte Bild wurde laut dessen Angaben auf der Plattform Flickr am 16. Juni 2008 aufgenommen.
Das Bild unten links konnte nicht zweifelsfrei einem bestimmten Ereignis zugeordnet werden. Jedoch illustriert es eine Fachpublikation des American College of Cardiology zum plötzlichen Herzstillstand bei Sportlern. Dieser Artikel ist auf den Dezember 2019 datiert. Somit ist auch in diesem Fall eine Verbindung zu mutmaßlichen Nebenwirkungen der Covid-Impfung ausgeschlossen.
Was hat es mit dem Gates-Zitat auf sich?
Das verkürzt wiedergegebene Zitat des US-Unternehmers Bill Gates stammt wahrscheinlich aus dem BBC-Interview bei «BBC Breakfast» vom 12. April 2020. Darin beantwortete Gates Fragen zu den Auswirkungen der schnellen Einführung eines Covid-19-Impfstoffs auf die Impfstoffsicherheit.
Der Moderator fragte damals, ob «möglicherweise einige Kompromisse in Bezug auf die Sicherheit eingegangen werden müssen, die normalerweise bei der Herstellung von Impfstoffen erwartet wird, da die Zeit von entscheidender Bedeutung ist.» Darauf antwortete Gates: «Natürlich, wenn Sie abwarten wollen, ob die Nebenwirkungen zwei Jahre später kommen, dauert das zwei Jahre.»
Im weiteren Kontext des Interviews betonte der Microsoft-Gründer, dass die Notwendigkeit einer schnellen Reaktion auf eine globale Krise mit gewissen Abwägungen («trade-offs») verbunden sei, die bestimmte übliche (Zeit-)Abläufe außer Kraft setzten. Er sagte jedoch nicht, dass man die langfristigen Nebenwirkungen erst in zwei Jahren kennen werde.
Keine Belege für massenhafte schwere Nebenwirkungen der Impfung
Zu mutmaßlichen Nebenwirkungen der Covid-Impfung werden regelmäßig Informationen fehlinterpretiert, falsche Zahlen verbreitet oder bewusst relevante Zusammenhänge weggelassen. Ein dpa-Faktencheck legte jüngst zum wiederholten Mal dar, dass es bislang in Deutschland keine Belege für massenhafte schwerwiegende Corona-Impfschäden gibt.
(Stand: 24.4.2023)
Translation:
Evaluation
The pictures of the athletes come from before the corona pandemic. Bill Gates' quote is also reproduced incompletely, thereby distorting his statement.
Facts
All sports photos were taken before 2020. One of them shows a real emergency on the field - but it happened 20 years ago.
In the photo on the left in the middle, the Cameroonian footballer Marc-Vivien Foé can be seen on a stretcher. Foé suffered a heart attack and died in June 2003 during a game between Cameroon and Colombia. He had hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a hereditary disease of the heart muscle that increases the risk of a heart attack during exercise.
The center right image depicting resuscitation often appears online in the international context of information and advertising for defibrillators. The image was published on the website of the Argentine Society of Cardiology (Sociedad Argentina de Cardiología) around August 2018. You can also find other shots of this scene online. It therefore seems obvious that the (staged) picture was taken during a photo shoot on the subject of defibrillators.
The photo on the bottom right can be attributed to the photographer Edward Morgan. According to him, the picture entitled “Agony” was taken on the Flickr platform on June 16, 2008.
The image on the bottom left could not be clearly assigned to a specific event. However, it illustrates a specialist publication from the American College of Cardiology on sudden cardiac arrest in athletes. This article is dated December 2019. In this case too, a connection to suspected side effects of the Covid vaccination is ruled out.
What's with the Gates quote?
The abbreviated quote from US entrepreneur Bill Gates probably comes from the BBC interview on “BBC Breakfast” on April 12, 2020. In it, Gates answered questions about the effects of the rapid introduction of a Covid-19 vaccine on vaccine safety.
The presenter asked at the time whether “some compromises may have to be made in terms of the safety that is normally expected in the production of vaccines, as time is of the essence.” Gates replied: "Of course, if you want to wait and see if the side effects come two years later, that will take two years."
In the broader context of the interview, the Microsoft founder emphasized that the need for a quick response to a global crisis involves certain trade-offs that override certain usual (time) processes. However, he did not say that the long-term side effects would not be known for another two years.
No evidence of mass serious side effects from the vaccination
Information about suspected side effects of the Covid vaccination is regularly misinterpreted, false figures are spread or relevant connections are deliberately omitted. A dpa fact check recently demonstrated once again that there is no evidence of mass, serious corona vaccine damage in Germany.
(As of: April 24, 2023)

Geschichten über mythische Unterwasserwelten faszinierten die Menschen schon immer. Nun wird auf Social Media ein Videoclip geteilt, der solche Mythen belegen soll: Man sieht eine bewegungslose humanoide Kreatur, die als eine «Meerjungfrau» bezeichnet wird. Selbst den Beruf dieses Wesens will man herausgefunden haben: «Es wird angenommen, dass sie eine Wache in der Nähe von Unterwasser-Reptilien Schlössern ist, wo hochrangige Gottheiten wohnen.» Doch was ist in dem Video wirklich zu sehen?
Bewertung
Die Kreatur wurde als Filmrequisite für die HBO-Serie «Raised by Wolves» hergestellt.
Fakten
Die dargestellte amphibische Kreatur wurde als 3D-gedrucktes Modell für die US-Serie «Raised by Wolves» erschaffen, die vom Sender HBO Max produziert wurde. Die Puppe taucht in der Science-Fiction-Serie unter anderem in der vierten Episode der zweiten Staffel (US-Erstausstrahlung: 17.2.2022) auf.
Das Video verbreitete sich online und sorgte in vielen Ländern für Spekulationen. Während der deutschsprachige Teil des Internets die Kreatur «vor der Atlantikküste» verortete, wurde auf spanischsprachigen Seiten das Science-Fiction-Monster angeblich «von russischen Fischern» gefangen. In Italien ging man noch weiter und sprach angesichts des Videos von einem «genetisch modifizierten ukrainischen Soldaten».
Einfache Methode um Fakes zu entlarven
Dabei lässt sich die tatsächliche Herkunft solcher Bilder und Videos meist schnell nachprüfen. Ein nützliches Tool dabei ist die Bilderrückwärtssuche. Mit ihrer Hilfe kann man Fotos oder Videoausschnitte online recherchieren und die gefundenen Ergebnisse miteinander vergleichen.
In diesem konkreten Fall lässt sich schnell ein Tweet des 3D-Künstlers Furio Tadeshi finden, der laut seiner Webseite an der Serienproduktion beteiligt war und die angebliche «Meerjungfrau» klar als eine mit einem 3D-Drucker produzierte Filmrequisite entlarvt.
(Stand: 5.5.2023)
Translation:
Stories about mythical underwater worlds have always fascinated people. Now a video clip is being shared on social media that is supposed to prove such myths: You can see a motionless humanoid creature that is referred to as a “mermaid”. They even want to find out the profession of this creature: “It is believed that she is a guard near underwater reptile castles where high-ranking deities live.” But what can you really see in the video?
Evaluation
The creature was made as a film prop for the HBO series “Raised by Wolves”.
Facts
The amphibious creature depicted was created as a 3D printed model for the US series “Raised by Wolves”, which was produced by the broadcaster HBO Max. The doll appears in the science fiction series, among other things, in the fourth episode of the second season (US first broadcast: February 17, 2022).
The video spread online and sparked speculation in many countries. While the German-language part of the Internet located the creature "off the Atlantic coast," on Spanish-language sites the science fiction monster was allegedly caught "by Russian fishermen." In Italy they went even further and spoke of a “genetically modified Ukrainian soldier” in view of the video.
Simple method to expose fakes
The actual origin of such images and videos can usually be quickly checked. A useful tool here is the reverse image search. With their help you can research photos or video excerpts online and compare the results you find.
In this specific case, you can quickly find a tweet from 3D artist Furio Tadeshi, who, according to his website, was involved in the series production and clearly reveals the alleged “mermaid” to be a film prop produced with a 3D printer.
(As of: May 5, 2023)

FALS | Vaccinurile nu scad fertilitatea, iar SarsCov2 nu este o bacterie
FALS | Vaccinurile nu scad fertilitatea, iar SarsCov2 nu este o bacterie
Publicat marți 11 iulie 2023 la 14:08
Ediția din 1 iunie 2023 a emisiunii Starea de veghe, difuzată pe canalul de facebook al Global News, s-a concentrat pe mai multe discursuri de tip antivaccinist. Printre altele, în emisiunea moderată de Adriana Bahmuțeanu au fost făcute următoarele afirmații:
- Vaccinurile cauzează infertilitate la femei – ,,Vaccinurile iată, prima dovadă că ele cauzează infertilitate la femei, dar se pare ca acesta este vârful icebergului și efectele negative secundare ale vaccinurilor sunt mult, mult mai adânci”.
- Funcția reproductivă este afectată de vaccinurile anticovid – „(…) Copiii sunt rezultatul unei funcții a organismului uman, funcția reproductivă, care se pare că a fost afectată în urma acestui vaccin, și lucrul acesta este recunoscut chiar de către EMA. Bineînțeles că a explodat peste ocean, toată presa de peste ocean a explodat pentru că au spus că dom’le da ăștia din Europa recunosc, European Medicines Agency, voi de ce nu recunoașteți? Am dat și eu tweetul doctoritei Simone Gold, că de la ea am aflat și, ce să vezi? Că, de fapt, este pentru prima dată când EMA spune că ar putea exista o scădere a fertilității în rândul femeilor vaccinate, că despre ele vorbim, destul de semnificativă. Lucru care, practic, confirmă, din nou ce am spus noi, dacă ții minte că ne-am zis așa chestia asta: dom’le, nu s-au făcut studii suficiente și pe termen îndelungat legat de fertilitate. Eu am trimis către Simona un grafic, o să o rog pe Simona să afișeze graficul fertilității în țările înalt vaccinate, cu toate țările înalt vaccinate. Ce să vezi, au scăderi drastice începând cam de la sfârșitul lui 2021, pe la jumătatea lui 2021. Este un grafic cu fertilitatea în țările nordice (…).
3. Covid nu este un virus, ci o bacterie – „Iată, medicii din Singapore au făcut o autopsie a unui cadavru cu acest virus. În urma unor cercetări amănunțite s-a descoperit ca acest covid nu exista ca virus, ci ca o bacterie care a afost expusa la radiatii si provoaca moartea omului prin coagularea sangelui. (…) Sursa Ministerul Sănătății din Singapore.”
Ce verificăm?
- Susține Agenția Europeană a Medicamentului că vaccinurile provoacă infertilitate la femei?
- Ministerul Sănătății din Singapore ar fi afirmat că virusul SARS-Cov-2 ar fi de fapt o bacterie?
Verificare
- Supoziția că vaccinul împotriva COVID-19 ar cauza infertilitate la femei s-a distribuit pe mai multe rețele sociale. Printre aceste postări se află și Tweetul doctoriței Simone Gold, recunoscută pentru poziționarea ei antivaccin și întemeierea America’s Frontline Doctors (AFLDS) – o organizație politică americană de dreapta.
Postarea a fost preluată și pe alte conturi.
Totuși, Agenția Europeană a Medicamentului (EMA) nu a comunicat niciodată că vaccinarea anti Covid-19 a cauzat infertilitate la femei. Postările pleacă de la un mesaj scos din context. În octombrie 2022, EMA a publicat un articol care prezintă niște măsuri pentru minimizarea riscului de reacții adverse la vaccinare. Informarea specifică în mod clar că NU există nicio dovadă care să sugereze efecte asupra fertilității, dar enumeră sângerări menstruale mai abundente printre efectele secundare: ,,nu există dovezi care să sugereze că tulburările menstruale experimentate de unele persoane au vreun impact asupra reproducerii și fertilității. Datele disponibile oferă asigurări cu privire la utilizarea vaccinurilor ARNm COVID-19 înainte și în timpul sarcinii. O analiză efectuată de Grupul operativ de urgență al EMA a arătat că vaccinurile ARNm COVID-19 nu provoacă complicații ale sarcinii viitoarelor mame și bebelușilor acestora și sunt la fel de eficiente în reducerea riscului de spitalizare și decese la gravide precum sunt în cazul celor care nu sunt persoane însărcinate”.
2. Cea de-a doua afirmație din emisiunea Global News este cea că Ministerul Sănătății din Singapore ar fi afirmat că virusul SARS-Cov-2 ar fi de fapt o bacterie, în urma unor descoperiri făcute după o autopsie.
Guvernul din Singapore a publicat un comunicat în 2021 care neagă afirmațiile. Și Organizația Mondială a Sănătății a publicat o dezmințire în care afirmă că boala Covid19 este cauzată de un virus și NU de o bacterie.
Dezinformarea are rădăcini vechi și pleacă încă din primele zile ale pandemiei, din 2020.
Pentru specialiști, diferența dintre viruși și bacterii este foarte ușor de determinat, iar chestiunea nu prezintă niciun fel de dubii: Sars-Cov2 este cu siguranță un virus și face parte din familia Coronaviridae.
Bacteriile sunt organisme unicelulare care pot trăi în diferite medii, inclusiv în intestinele umane, unde ajută la digerarea alimentelor, explică Clinica Mayo. În timp ce unele tipuri de bacterii sunt inofensive sau chiar utile pentru oameni, altele pot provoca boli, cum ar fi streptococul. Infecțiile bacteriene pot fi tratate de obicei cu antibiotice.
Diferența dintre bacterii și viruși stă în compoziția pe care o au și felul în care pot fi tratate.
Translation:
FALSE | Vaccines do not reduce fertility, and SarsCov2 is not a bacteria
FALSE | Vaccines do not reduce fertility, and SarsCov2 is not a bacteria
Posted on Tuesday, July 11, 2023 at 2:08 p.m
The June 1, 2023 edition of the State of Vigil broadcast on Global News' Facebook channel focused on several anti-vaccine speeches. Among other things, in the show moderated by Adriana Bahmuțeanu, the following statements were made:
- Vaccines cause infertility in women - "Vaccines are here, the first evidence that they cause infertility in women, but it seems that this is the tip of the iceberg and the negative side effects of vaccines are much, much deeper."
- Reproductive function is affected by anticovid vaccines - "(...) Children are the result of a function of the human body, the reproductive function, which seems to have been affected by this vaccine, and this is recognized even by the EMA. Of course it exploded overseas, all the overseas press exploded because they said that they in Europe admit it, the European Medicines Agency, why don't you admit it? I also gave Dr. Simone Gold's tweet, that I also learned from her, what to see? That, in fact, it is the first time that the EMA has said that there could be a decrease in fertility among vaccinated women, that we are talking about, quite significantly. Something that basically confirms, again, what we said, if you remember that we said this: sir, there have not been enough long-term studies related to fertility. I sent Simona a graph, I will ask Simona to display the fertility graph in highly vaccinated countries, with all highly vaccinated countries. What to see, they have drastic decreases starting from about the end of 2021, about the middle of 2021. It is a graph with the fertility in the Nordic countries (…).
3. Covid is not a virus, but a bacteria – “Look, doctors in Singapore did an autopsy on a corpse with this virus. After thorough research, it was discovered that this covid does not exist as a virus, but as a bacterium that has been exposed to radiation and causes the death of humans through blood coagulation. (…) Source Ministry of Health in Singapore."
What do we check?
- Does the European Medicines Agency claim that vaccines cause infertility in women?
- Did the Ministry of Health in Singapore claim that the SARS-Cov-2 virus was actually a bacterium?
Verification
- The assumption that the vaccine against COVID-19 would cause infertility in women was shared on several social networks. Among these posts is the Tweet of Dr. Simone Gold, known for her anti-vaccine stance and the founding of America's Frontline Doctors (AFLDS) – a right-wing American political organization.
The post was also picked up on other accounts.
However, the European Medicines Agency (EMA) has never communicated that the anti-Covid-19 vaccination has caused infertility in women. Posts start from a message taken out of context. In October 2022, the EMA published an article outlining some measures to minimize the risk of adverse reactions to vaccination. The information clearly states that there is NO evidence to suggest effects on fertility, but lists heavier menstrual bleeding among the side effects: “There is no evidence to suggest that the menstrual disturbances experienced by some people have any impact on reproduction and fertility. Available data provide reassurance regarding the use of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines before and during pregnancy. A review by the EMA's Emergency Task Force has shown that COVID-19 mRNA vaccines do not cause pregnancy complications for expectant mothers and their babies and are as effective in reducing the risk of hospitalization and death in pregnant women as they are in those who are not. they are pregnant people".
2. The second claim in the Global News broadcast is that the Ministry of Health in Singapore has claimed that the SARS-Cov-2 virus is actually a bacterium, following findings made after an autopsy.
The Singapore government issued a statement in 2021 denying the claims. And the World Health Organization published a denial stating that the disease Covid19 is caused by a virus and NOT by a bacteria.
Disinformation has old roots and goes back to the first days of the pandemic, from 2020.
For specialists, the difference between viruses and bacteria is very easy to determine, and the matter does not present any doubts: Sars-Cov2 is definitely a virus and belongs to the Coronaviridae family.
Bacteria are single-celled organisms that can live in a variety of environments, including the human intestines, where they help digest food, the Mayo Clinic explains. While some types of bacteria are harmless or even helpful to humans, others can cause disease, such as strep. Bacterial infections can usually be treated with antibiotics.
The difference between bacteria and viruses lies in their composition and the way they can be treated.

FALS | Bolile ar fi cauzate de paraziți și nu am avea nevoie de medicamente
FALS | Bolile ar fi cauzate de paraziți și nu am avea nevoie de medicamente
Sursa afirmației : Harapan
Publicat miercuri 10 iulie 2024 la 13:16
O pagină de Facebook a încărcat un videoclip în care prezentatorul B1 TV, Dan Gabor, spune, la începutul filmării: „Companiile farmaceutice au deschis o vânătoare de oameni, pentru unul dintre oamenii de știință care au descoperit adevărul înfiorător despre toate bolile și cauzele lor”.
În realitate, filmulețul este un deepfake, realizat cu un program de inteligență artificială – și se poate observa acest lucru și cu ochiul liber, pentru că mișcările prezentatorului sunt nenaturale.
La minutul 0:12, apare și doctorul Mihail Pautov, care ar spune că „un grup de oameni de știință a efectuat, în secret, un studiu, care a arătat că majoritatea bolilor sunt cauzate de paraziții din interiorul oamenilor. Chiar și simptome comune, cum ar fi oboseala, somnolența, un fel de erupție cutanată sau chiar tusea, toate acestea îți spun că ești infectat cu paraziți”.
De fapt, și această afirmație a fost făcută cu un program de inteligență artificială. Videoclipul original, în care apare doctorul, este de acum 4 ani, când acesta a fost invitat într-o emisiune la ProTV. În cadrul emisiunii, el a vorbit despre utilizarea vitaminelor ca suplimente alimentare. Nicăieri în videoclip el nu afirmă cele de mai sus.
Principalele cauze ale bolilor
80% dintre bolile înregistrate la oameni, precum și cele care reprezintă principala cauză de deces prematur, sunt bolile netransmisibile. Printre acestea se numără bolile cardiovasculare, diabet, boli respiratorii cronice, tulburări mintale, afecțiuni neurologice și cancer.
Bolile infecțioase reprezintă principala cauză de deces în unele țări subdezvoltate și în special în rândul copiilor mici. Acestea sunt într-adevăr cauzate de organisme microscopice, cum ar fi bacteriile, virușii sau paraziții și sunt transmise, direct sau indirect, de la o persoană la alta.
Potrivit Organizației Mondiale a Sănătății, în primele 10 cauze ale deceselor se află și boli infecțioase, însă nu preponderent.
*Sursă foto: Organizația Mondială a Sănătății
Cele mai multe dintre acestea sunt boli netransmisibile, adică bolile care nu sunt cauzate de viruși, bacterii sau paraziți.
Într-un articol anterior, Factual.ro a arătat că boli cronice precum cancerul, diabetul și bolile de inimă au nevoie de medicație, în lipsa căreia pot apărea afecțiuni grave sau chiar deces.
Concluzie
Videoclipul încărcat pe Facebook este realizat cu Inteligența Artificială și afirmă, în mod fals, că nu avem nevoie de medicamente, pentru că toate bolile sunt cauzate de paraziți, care pot fi eliminați și fără medicație.
Translation:
FALSE | Diseases would be caused by parasites and we would not need medicine
FALSE | Diseases would be caused by parasites and we would not need medicine
Source of the statement: Harapan
Published on Wednesday, July 10, 2024 at 1:16 p.m
A Facebook page uploaded a video in which B1 TV anchor Dan Gabor says at the beginning of the footage: "Pharmaceutical companies have opened a manhunt for one of the scientists who discovered the horrifying truth about all diseases and their causes ".
In reality, the video is a deepfake, made with an artificial intelligence program - and this can also be seen with the naked eye, because the presenter's movements are unnatural.
At minute 0:12, Dr. Mihail Pautov also appears, who would say that "a group of scientists secretly conducted a study that showed that most diseases are caused by parasites inside people. Even common symptoms such as tiredness, sleepiness, some kind of rash or even a cough, all these tell you that you are infected with parasites”.
In fact, this claim was also made with an artificial intelligence program. The original video, in which the doctor appears, is from 4 years ago, when he was invited in a show on ProTV. On the show, he talked about the use of vitamins as dietary supplements. Nowhere in the video does he state the above.
The main causes of diseases
80% of the diseases recorded in humans, as well as those that represent the main cause of premature death, are non-communicable diseases. These include cardiovascular disease, diabetes, chronic respiratory disease, mental disorders, neurological conditions and cancer.
Infectious diseases are the leading cause of death in some underdeveloped countries and especially among young children. They are actually caused by microscopic organisms such as bacteria, viruses or parasites and are transmitted, directly or indirectly, from one person to another.
According to the World Health Organization, infectious diseases are also among the top 10 causes of death, but not predominantly.
*Photo source: World Health Organization
Most of these are non-communicable diseases, meaning diseases that are not caused by viruses, bacteria or parasites.
In a previous article, Factual.ro showed that chronic diseases such as cancer, diabetes and heart disease require medication, without which serious conditions or even death can occur.
Conclusion
The video uploaded on Facebook is made with Artificial Intelligence and falsely claims that we don't need medicine, because all diseases are caused by parasites, which can be eliminated without medication.
