Factcheck: nee, stress tijdens de zwangerschap bepaalt het geslacht van de baby niet
Deze factcheck is uitgevoerd op basis van de beschikbare informatie op de datum van publicatie. Lees hier meer over hoe we werken.
‘Stress tijdens de zwangerschap bepaalt het geslacht van de baby.’ Dat lazen we in Goed Gevoel. Maar dat moet ernstig genuanceerd worden.
In Goed Gevoel lazen we dat stress tijdens de zwangerschap het geslacht van de baby bepaalt. Er wordt verwezen naar een onderzoek van de universiteit van Granada, waaraan 108 zwangere vrouwen deelnamen. ‘Wat bleek? Gestreste moeders krijgen dubbel zo vaak een meisje.’ Als we het onderzoek online opzoeken, blijkt die laatste uitspraak veel te kort door de bocht. Bij de 108 vrouwen werd zowel hun biologische stress gemeten – op basis van het cortisolniveau in een haarstaal – als hun psychologische stress, met een vragenlijst. Alleen de biologische stress bleek een invloed te hebben: vrouwen die een meisje kregen, hadden gemiddeld een bijna dubbel zo hoog cortisolniveau tijdens het eerste trimester van hun zwangerschap.
‘Dat onderzoek bevat toch wat zwakke punten’, vindt professor Yves Jacquemyn, diensthoofd gynaecologie UZ Antwerpen. ‘Het opvallende resultaat heeft vooral te maken met de beperkte groep van 108 vrouwen. Bovendien werd geen rekening gehouden met deelneemsters die afhaakten wegens zwangerschapsverlies – het geslacht van die baby’s werd ook niet onderzocht. Daarnaast moet je een duidelijk onderscheid maken tussen biologische en psychologische stress. Dat laatste is wat de meeste mensen als stress beschouwen: spanning en zenuwen. Maar die stress heeft dus geen effect, aldus deze studie. Biologische stress, die meetbaar is via cortisolwaarden, wordt beïnvloed door spanning, maar ook door factoren als vervuiling en voedsel.’
Dat biologische stress dus wél een rol speelt, is op zich niet nieuw, benadrukt Jacquemyn. ‘We weten al langer dat er in periodes van grote “stress”, zoals oorlogen of natuurrampen, meer meisjes dan jongens worden geboren. Daarover werd in de jaren 70 al de evolutionair-biologische Trivers-Willard-hypothese gepubliceerd. Die stelt grofweg dat sterke mannen zich gemiddeld meer voortplanten dan sterke vrouwen, maar dat zwakke vrouwen zich meer voortplanten dan zwakke mannen. Uit een reviewartikel blijkt dat na de aardbeving in Japan in 2011 en na de financiële crisis in 2007 er plots meer meisjes geboren werden. Dat was bijvoorbeeld ook het geval na de dood van prinses Diana in het Verenigd Koninkrijk. En ook moslima’s die vasten tijdens de ramadan terwijl ze net zwanger zijn, hebben meer kans op een meisje. Daarnaast weten we ook dat in gezonde situaties iets meer jongens dan meisjes worden geboren: 13 jongens per 12 meisjes. Die “overdaad” raak je dus kwijt in periodes van stress, omdat jongetjes al vanaf het embryonale niveau iets zwakker zijn. Jongens grootbrengen vraagt iets meer investering, wat in harde tijden moeilijker is.’
Ook professor Johan Verhaeghe (gynaecologie, UZ Leuven) vindt dat de resultaten van dit beperkte onderzoek niet zomaar veralgemeend kunnen worden. ‘Ze passen inderdaad in de algemene hypothese dat moeders in minder goede conditie eerder een meisje krijgen dan een jongen. Niet omdat er dan minder jongens verwekt worden, wel omdat er meer zwangerschapsverlies is van mannelijke foetussen. Ze zijn iets kwetsbaarder en hebben een hoger geboortegewicht, waardoor de “investering” iets groter is. We zien ook dat jongens die prematuur worden geboren, een lagere overlevingskans hebben dan meisjes. Vrouwen zijn dus het sterke geslacht, al lang voor de geboorte.’
CONCLUSIE
Dit onderzoek is te beperkt om te besluiten dat stress het geslacht van baby’s bepaalt. Uit eerder onderzoek blijkt wel dat er in tijden van stress, zoals oorlogen of natuurrampen, meer meisjes worden geboren dan jongens. We beoordelen de stelling daarom als eerder onwaar.
BRONNEN
Goed Gevoel, 16 juni 2021
Journal of Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (2021)
Science (1973)
Early Human Development (2017) (achter betaalmuur)
‘Gender Ratio’, Our World in Data (2019)
E-mailverkeer en interview met Yves Jacquemyn (UZ Antwerpen), 22 juni 2021
E-mailverkeer en interview met Johan Verhaeghe (UZ Leuven), 21-22 juni 2021
Alle bronnen werden laatst geraadpleegd op 23 juni 2021.
Meer informatie over de factchecks vindt u op de website van Knack.
U vindt onze factchecks ook terug bij deCheckers, samen met betrouwbare factchecks van andere Vlaamse redacties.

Translation:
Fact check: no, stress during pregnancy does not determine the sex of the baby
This fact check was carried out based on the information available at the date of publication. Read more about how we work here.
'Stress during pregnancy determines the sex of the baby.' We read that in Goed Gevoel. But that must be seriously nuanced.
In Goed Gevoy we read that stress during pregnancy determines the sex of the baby. Reference is made to a study by the University of Granada, in which 108 pregnant women participated. 'What turned out? Stressed mothers are twice as likely to have a girl.' When we look up the research online, that last statement appears to be far too simplistic. The 108 women were measured in both their biological stress – based on the cortisol level in a hair sample – and their psychological stress with a questionnaire. Only biological stress appeared to have an influence: women who had a girl had, on average, almost double the cortisol level during the first trimester of their pregnancy.
“That research does contain some weaknesses,” says Professor Yves Jacquemyn, head of the gynecology department at UZ Antwerp. 'The striking result is mainly due to the limited group of 108 women. In addition, participants who dropped out due to pregnancy loss were not taken into account - the gender of those babies was also not examined. In addition, you must make a clear distinction between biological and psychological stress. The latter is what most people consider stress: tension and nerves. But that stress has no effect, according to this study. Biological stress, which is measurable via cortisol levels, is influenced by tension, but also by factors such as pollution and food.'
The fact that biological stress does play a role is not in itself new, Jacquemyn emphasizes. 'We have known for some time that during periods of great "stress", such as wars or natural disasters, more girls are born than boys. The evolutionary-biological Trivers-Willard hypothesis about this was already published in the 1970s. It roughly states that strong men reproduce more on average than strong women, but that weak women reproduce more than weak men. A review article shows that after the earthquake in Japan in 2011 and after the financial crisis in 2007, more girls were suddenly born. This was also the case after the death of Princess Diana in the United Kingdom. And Muslim women who fast during Ramadan while they are pregnant are also more likely to have a girl. We also know that in healthy situations slightly more boys than girls are born: 13 boys for every 12 girls. You lose that “excess” during periods of stress, because boys are slightly weaker from the embryonic level. Raising boys requires a little more investment, which is more difficult in hard times.”
Professor Johan Verhaeghe (gynecology, UZ Leuven) also believes that the results of this limited research cannot simply be generalized. 'They indeed fit in with the general hypothesis that mothers in less good condition are more likely to have a girl than a boy. Not because fewer boys are conceived, but because there is more pregnancy loss of male fetuses. They are slightly more vulnerable and have a higher birth weight, making the “investment” slightly larger. We also see that boys who are born prematurely have a lower chance of survival than girls. So women are the stronger sex, long before birth.”
CONCLUSION
This research is too limited to conclude that stress determines the gender of babies. Previous research shows that in times of stress, such as wars or natural disasters, more girls are born than boys. We therefore rate the statement as rather false.
SOURCES
Good Feeling, June 16, 2021
Journal of Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (2021)
Science (1973)
Early Human Development (2017) (behind paywall)
'Gender Ratio', Our World in Data (2019)
Email traffic and interview with Yves Jacquemyn (UZ Antwerp), June 22, 2021
E-mail traffic and interview with Johan Verhaeghe (UZ Leuven), June 21-22, 2021
All sources were last consulted on June 23, 2021.

Nav taisnība – apgalvojums neatbilst patiesībai, tam nav pierādījumu, izteikuma autors neapzināti maldina vai melo
Latvija kā totalitāra sekta, kuru okupējusi Eiropas Savienība. Tā sociālajā medijā Facebook pauž dezinformators Aivis Vasiļevskis. Šos apgalvojumus viņš pamato ar jau gadiem sociālajos medijos klīstošiem izrautiem no konteksta, pārspīlētiem vai vienkārši izdomātiem statistikas datiem par Latviju.
Ierakstu Vasiļevskis publicējis Latvijas neatkarības atjaunošanas dienā, 4. maijā. Līdzīgu rakstu ar tiem pašiem datiem viņš publicējis arī pirms trim gadiem. Maldinātājs ierakstā min, ka “vienmēr ir interesanti aplūkot, bet ko tad par Latvijas “veiksmes stāstu” raksta citur pasaulē”. Vasiļevskis atsaucas uz kādu britu publicistu, kurš esot raksta autors:
“(..) Taču minētā raksta autors ir Maikls Valšs (Michael Walsh) – britu publicists un radio personība, kurš sarakstījis 70 dažādas grāmatas. Te nekādu Kremli piesiet nesanāk. Jā, tā ir 3 gadus veca publikācija, taču kas tad ir mainījies, ja ne tikai uz slikto pusi?”
Vasiļevskis atsaucas uz Maikla Volša 2021. gada rakstu “Pasaules skaistākā valsts iesūkta ES purvā”. Tas atrodams kādā interneta vietnē, kas sevi dēvē par pretkara ziņu platformu un publicē pret Ukrainu un ES vērstus rakstus. Volšs (īstajā vārdā Maikls Maklaflins) savulaik bijis viens no britu galēji labējo līderiem. Ar vārdu Maikls Volšs viņš rakstījis pronacistiskas publikācijas.
Taču pirmavots rakstā minētajiem datiem meklējams pirms vairākiem gadiem tepat Latvijā. Lielu daļu viņa minēto skaitļu Re:Check atspēkoja jau 2019. gadā. Toreiz Facebook ar ierakstu, kuram dots virsraksts “Latvijas veiksmes stāsts”, dalījās vairāki tūkstoši cilvēku. Ar nepatiesiem un sagrozītiem datiem no jauna valsts galu sludināja arī 2021. gadā.
Arī toreiz nepatiesi apgalvoja, ka Latvijā ir augstākais PVN, šeit esot trešais augstākais ierēdņu skaits pasaulē, par visu maksājam vairāk nekā bagātās Rietumu valstis un bez jebkāda pamatojuma apgalvoja, ka nodokļu slogs katru gadu pieaug par 9,5%. Vasiļevskis pārstāsta arī izdomātus skaitļus par pašnāvību skaitu Latvijā:
“Tāpat Latvijā ir augstākais pašnāvību rādītājs ES. 2017. gadā tie bija 382 cilvēki, bet nākamajā – jau 443.”
Tie ir meli. Pašnāvību skaits ne tuvu nav augstākais ES. 2020. gadā, par kuru pieejami jaunākie publiskotie Eurostat dati, vēl vairāk pašnāvību, rēķinot pret iedzīvotāju skaitu, tika izdarīts Lietuvā, Ungārijā, Slovēnijā, Igaunijā, vairākos Polijas un Francijas reģionos. Tāpat 2017. gadā tika izdarīts 353 pašnāvību, bet 2018. gadā – 299. Tātad bijis nevis pieaugums, bet gan kritums par 15%.
Nav arī nekāda pamata Vasiļevska apgalvojumam, ka Latviju būtu okupējusi Eiropas Savienība. Iestāšanās ES jau kopš neatkarības atjaunošanas bija valsts ārpolitikas pamatmērķis. Referendumā pievienošanos ES atbalstīja 66,97% Latvijas balsstiesīgo iedzīvotāju.
Tāpat iepriekš skaidrojām, ka Latvijā patiešām ir augsts nevienlīdzības līmenis – viens no augstākajiem Džini koeficienta rādītājiem ES. Taču nav pamata apgalvot, ka Latvijā tas ir augstākais ES. Eurostat dati par 2022. gadu rāda, ka tas vēl lielāks bija Lietuvā un Bulgārijā.
Arī Vasiļevskis raksta par valsts parādu:
“Šodien “Baltijas pērle” nogrimusi dziļos, neatmaksājamos parādos starptautiskām bankām, kuras pārņēmušas pilnīgu kontroli pār latviešu tautu.”
Nav pamata apgalvot, ka Latvija esot nogrimusi parādos un nespēs tos atmaksāt. Latvijai ilgstoši bijis viens no zemākajiem valsts parādiem starp Eiropas Savienības valstīm. Pēc jaunākajiem Eurostat datiem Latvija ierindojas 21. vietā no 27 ES dalībvalstīm. Latvijas parāds ir gandrīz divas reizes mazāks nekā vidēji ES.
“Kopš 1989. gada 800 tūkstoši latviešu ir devušies prom cerībā uzlabot savas dzīves. Citiem vārdiem sakot, tā ir trešdaļa nācijas, lielākoties darba spējīgā vecumā, kas savus talantus un pirktspēju izmanto citās valstīs.”
Centrālās statistikas pārvaldes dati rāda, ka no 1990. līdz 2022. gadam Latviju pametuši 735 tūkstoši iedzīvotāji, bet uz dzīvi Latvijā pārcēlušies 288 tūkstoši. Šajā laikā Latvijas iedzīvotāju skaits sarucis par 30%. Divi lielākie emigrācijas viļņi bija 90. gadu sākumā, kad Latviju pameta citu bijušo PSRS valstu piederīgie un PSRS karaspēks, un pēc 2008. gada ekonomikās krīzes.
Jāpiebilst, ka kopš 2010. gada izbraucēju skaits vienmērīgi samazinājies. Arī migrācijas saldo – starpība starp imigrantu un emigrantu skaitu – ir uzlabojies. 2021. gadā no Latvijas devās prom tikai par 286 cilvēkiem vairāk, nekā pārcēlās uz to. Savukārt 2022. gadā saistībā ar Krievijas pilna mēroga iebrukumu Ukrainā Latvijā vairāk iebrauca cilvēku nekā to pameta.
Pats Vasiļevskis jau iepriekš izplatījis dažādus maldus. Re:Check par tiem rakstīja, piemēram, šeit, šeit, šeit un šeit. Pērn prokuratūra Vasiļevski sodījusi par Krievijas kara noziegumu atbalstīšanu, kā arī nacionālā un etniskā naida provocēšanu.
Secinājums: Facebook ierakstā pārstāstīti maldinoši un sagrozīti dati par Latviju. Dezinformators Aivis Vasiļevskis rakstā atsaucas uz neonacistu no Lielbritānijas Maiklu Volšu.
Šis raksts ir daļa no Re:Check darba, pārbaudot iespējami nepatiesus vai puspatiesus Facebook ierakstus, attēlus un video. Par Re:Check sadarbību ar Facebook lasiet šeit.
Visus Re:Check rakstus lasi ŠEIT!
Ja arī jūs redzat apšaubāmu apgalvojumu, sūtiet to mums uz recheck@rebaltica.com
Par projektu: Re:Check ir Baltijas pētnieciskās žurnālistikas centra Re:Baltica paspārnē strādājoša faktu pārbaudes un sociālo tīklu pētniecības virtuāla laboratorija. Pārbaudīto faktu vērtējumam izmantojam sešas iespējamās atzīmes un krāsas: patiesība (izteikums ir precīzs un faktoloģiski pierādāms), tuvu patiesībai (apgalvojums ir lielākoties patiess, taču ir pieļautas sīkas neprecizitātes), puspatiesība (apgalvojums satur gan patiesu, gan nepatiesu informāciju, daļa faktu ir noklusēta), drīzāk nav taisnība (apgalvojumā ir kripata patiesības, taču nav ņemti vērā būtiski fakti un/vai konteksts, līdz ar to izteikums ir maldinošs), trūkst konteksta – tiek salīdzinātas nesalīdzināmas lietas, izteikums ir pretrunā ar paša iepriekš teikto vai darīto vai trūkst būtiskas papildu informācijas un nav taisnība (apgalvojums neatbilst patiesībai, tam nav pierādījumu, izteikuma autors neapzināti maldina vai melo). Vērtējumu piešķir vismaz divi redaktori vienojoties.

Translation:
It is not true - the statement does not correspond to the truth, there is no evidence for it, the author of the statement is unknowingly misleading or lying
Latvia as a totalitarian sect occupied by the European Union. Disinformationist Aivis Vasilevskis expresses this on the social media Facebook. He substantiates these statements with out-of-context, exaggerated or simply invented statistical data about Latvia that have been circulating on social media for years.
The entry was published by Vasiļevskis on May 4, the day of restoration of Latvia's independence. He published a similar article with the same data three years ago. The deceiver mentions in the post that "it is always interesting to look at, but then what is being written about Latvia's "success story" elsewhere in the world". Vasilevski refers to a British publicist who is said to be the author of the article:
"(..) However, the author of the mentioned article is Michael Walsh (Michael Walsh), a British publicist and radio personality who has written 70 different books. There is no way to tie the Kremlin here. Yes, it is a 3-year-old publication, but what has changed, if not only for the worse?”
Vasilevski refers to Michael Walsh's 2021 article "The most beautiful country in the world is sucked into the EU swamp". It is found on a website that calls itself an anti-war news platform and publishes anti-Ukraine and anti-EU articles. Walsh (real name Michael McLaughlin) was once one of the leaders of the British extreme right. He wrote pro-Nazi publications under the name Michael Walsh.
However, the first source of the data mentioned in the article can be found several years ago right here in Latvia. A large part of the numbers he mentioned was refuted by Re:Check already in 2019. At that time, several thousand people shared the post titled "Latvia's success story" on Facebook. With false and distorted data, the end of the country was again announced in 2021.
Also at that time, they falsely claimed that Latvia has the highest VAT, that here is the third highest number of civil servants in the world, we pay more for everything than the rich Western countries, and claimed without any justification that the tax burden increases by 9.5% every year. Vasilevskis also retells fictional figures about the number of suicides in Latvia:
"Latvia also has the highest suicide rate in the EU. In 2017, there were 382 people, and in the following year - already 443."
It's a lie. The suicide rate is nowhere near the highest in the EU. In 2020, for which the latest published Eurostat data is available, even more suicides per population were committed in Lithuania, Hungary, Slovenia, Estonia, several regions of Poland and France. Likewise, 353 suicides were committed in 2017, and 299 in 2018. So there was not an increase, but a decrease of 15%.
There is also no basis for Vasilevski's claim that Latvia was occupied by the European Union. Joining the EU was the main goal of the country's foreign policy since the restoration of independence. In the referendum, 66.97% of Latvia's voting population supported joining the EU.
Also, we previously explained that Latvia really has a high level of inequality - one of the highest Gini coefficient indicators in the EU. However, there is no reason to claim that in Latvia it is the highest in the EU. Eurostat data for 2022 show that it was even higher in Lithuania and Bulgaria.
Vasilevski also writes about the national debt:
"Today, the "Pearl of the Baltics" has sunk into deep, unrepayable debts to international banks, which have taken over complete control over the Latvian people."
There is no reason to claim that Latvia is in debt and will not be able to repay them. Latvia has had one of the lowest national debts among European Union countries for a long time. According to the latest Eurostat data, Latvia ranks 21st out of 27 EU member states. Latvia's debt is almost two times smaller than the EU average.
"Since 1989, 800 thousand Latvians have left hoping to improve their lives. In other words, it is a third of the nation, mostly of working age, who use their talents and purchasing power in other countries."
The data of the Central Statistics Office show that from 1990 to 2022, 735 thousand inhabitants left Latvia, while 288 thousand moved to live in Latvia. During this time, the population of Latvia decreased by 30%. The two biggest waves of emigration were in the early 1990s, when people from other former USSR countries and USSR troops left Latvia, and after the 2008 economic crisis.
It should be noted that since 2010, the number of departures has steadily decreased. The migration balance - the difference between the number of immigrants and emigrants - has also improved. In 2021, only 286 more people left Latvia than moved there. On the other hand, in 2022, in connection with Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, more people entered Latvia than left it.
Vasilevski himself has previously spread various delusions. Re:Check wrote about them, for example, here, here, here and here. Last year, the prosecutor's office punished Vasilevski for supporting Russian war crimes, as well as provoking national and ethnic hatred.
Conclusion: the Facebook post retold misleading and distorted data about Latvia. Disinformer Aivis Vasilevskis refers to neo-Nazi Michael Walsh from Great Britain in the article.
This article is part of Re:Check's work investigating potentially false or half-truth Facebook posts, images and videos. Read about Re:Check's cooperation with Facebook here.
Read all Re:Check articles HERE!
If you also see a questionable claim, send it to us at recheck@rebaltica.com
About the project: Re:Check is a fact-checking and social network research virtual laboratory working under the auspices of Re:Baltica, the Baltic Investigative Journalism Center. We use six possible marks and colors to evaluate the verified facts: truth (the statement is accurate and factually provable), close to the truth (the statement is mostly true, but small inaccuracies are allowed), half-truth (the statement contains both true and false information, some facts are hidden ), rather it is not true (there is some truth in the statement, but essential facts and/or context are not taken into account, therefore the statement is misleading), there is a lack of context - incomparable things are compared, the statement contradicts what one has said or done before, or there is a lack of essential additional information and is not true (the claim does not correspond to the truth, there is no evidence for it, the author of the statement is unknowingly misleading or lying). The rating is given by at least two editors in agreement.

content:
CHECK - Video over emigrerende Russen die lachen met "westerse waarden" is geen propaganda, wel satire
Op sociale media beweren Russische propagandisten en andere gebruikers onterecht dat een komische sketch propaganda is. We zien een Russisch gezin dat emigreert naar de Verenigde Staten. Tijdens hun vlucht maken ze kennis met zogezegde "Amerikaanse gebruiken" zoals "geen vlees eten in de buurt van vegetariërs". Het zet hen aan om terug te keren naar hun moederland. Miljoenen mensen hebben de video online zien voorbijkomen met de bewering dat het een propagandavideo is die lacht met westerse waarden. Dat klopt niet.
"Hoe lang ik hierop gewacht heb…", zegt een Russische vader gelukzalig tegen zijn vrouw terwijl ze op een vliegtuig richting de Verenigde Staten zitten. Samen met hun zoon verlaten ze Rusland om de "American dream" na te jagen. Een medepassagier draait zich om en vertelt dat "Amerika het meest vrije land ter wereld is". Even later ploft haar partner, een vrouw, naast haar neer. Het Russische koppel schrikt dat homoseksuele relaties toegestaan zijn in het "vrije Amerika".
Zo begint de video die online "Russische propaganda" wordt genoemd en momenteel massaal bekeken wordt. Het gezin maakt tijdens de vlucht kennis met zogezegd "Amerikaanse of westerse gebruiken". Naast een tolerante houding tegenover de LGBTQIA+-gemeenschap, leren ze dat ze geen vlees mogen eten in de buurt van vegetariërs. Mensen met een donkere huidskleur moet je voorrang geven in de rij naar het toilet. "We zijn alle Afro-Amerikanen iets verschuldigd!", vertelt een passagier verwijzend naar de jarenlange onderdrukking door witte mensen.
Bekijk hier de video:
Mobilisatie
Door de gedeeltelijke mobilisatie, die de Russische president Poetin enkele weken geleden aankondigde, pakken heel wat Russen hun koffers. Het nogal absurde filmpje is volgens heel wat socialemediagebruikers een antwoord daarop.
"In de Russische federatie worden video’s verspreid tegen de massale emigratie. Zo zijn er in de VS verschrikkelijke homohuwelijken en "moeten we ons verontschuldigen tegenover mensen van kleur", pent een Twitteraar sarcastisch neer. Het bericht bereikt meer dan 570.000 mensen. In een andere tweet wordt de video door bijna 6 miljoen mensen bekeken.
Met dit soort video’s zou de bevolking overtuigd moeten worden om te blijven. Of dat is toch de redenering van heel wat propagandisten en andere Twitteraars. De video lacht met de westerse waarden, die niet zouden stroken met die van de Russen. Reden genoeg om te blijven dus.
In dit Twitterbericht wordt de video omschreven als "Russische propaganda". Bijna 6 miljoen mensen bekeken het.
Geschrokken door de voor hen onbekende gewoontes beslist het gezin in de video dan ook met een parachute uit het vliegtuig te springen. "Vergeef ons moeder Rusland. We komen terug", roept de vader.
Sketch
Niets lijkt minder waar. Zoals de satirische ondertoon doet vermoeden, gaat het niet om een propagandavideo, maar een sketch uit de Russische komediereeks "ВСЛУХ!" oftewel "Hardop!". Het programma is wekelijks te zien op onder meer RuTube, de Russische variant van YouTube. De makers nemen wel vaker een loopje met het reilen en zeilen in Rusland en ver daarbuiten. Je kan het vergelijken met het bij ons bekende satirische programma "De ideale wereld" op Canvas.
De sketch komt uit aflevering 15 (zie minuut 07:42) van vorige week en heeft de veelzeggende titel "Tolerante vlucht". De video die gedeeld wordt op sociale media bevat overigens niet de volledige sketch, maar een mix van fragmenten.
Ook de acteur die de vader speelde, heeft intussen bevestigd dat het om satire gaat. "Ziet u, als u dit korte verhaal buiten de context van het programma bekijkt, krijgt het misschien het karakter van een antireclame voor emigratie", vertelt Sergey Pogosyan aan het Russische nieuwsmedium NGS42. "Maar het gaat hier om een sketch. (...) Deze ideeën van tolerantie zijn ook gebruikelijk in Rusland. Als ik iemand tegenkom met een niet-heteroseksuele geaardheid, voel ik geen verlangen om hem te beledigen of te vernederen".
In het Radio 1-programma "Het Uur van de Waarheid" vertelt Luc Van Bakel ook over het virale filmpje. Beluister het hier:
De Checkers: Willen handelaars Brussel ontvluchten? Gebruikt Rusland sketches als propaganda?
Telegram
Waarom wordt het dan als propagandavideo opgepikt? Onze zoektocht wijst naar de chatapplicatie Telegram. Daar delen verschillende mensen de volledige sketch in pro-Russische kanalen als "Кремлёвская прачка" (Kremlin Prachka).
Ook de Russische propagandist en tv-presentator Vladimir Solovjov deelt het in zijn Telegramkanaal. Meer dan 305.000 van zijn 1,3 miljoen volgers bekijken het. Naar alle waarschijnlijkheid is de sketch via Telegram in een kortere versie verspreid geraakt op sociale media als Twitter.
Russische ambassade in Spanje
De video doet denken aan een echte, bizarre promotievideo van afgelopen zomer. In nog geen minuut tijd krijgen we als kijker tientallen redenen opgesomd waarom het "tijd is om naar Rusland te verhuizen". Zo zijn er "goedkope elektriciteit en water", "mooie vrouwen", "vodka" en "een economie die duizenden sancties kan doorstaan". De video ging viraal nadat de Russische ambassade in Spanje hem had gedeeld op Twitter.
Het is niet duidelijk of de video serieus moet genomen worden.
Conclusie
- Op sociale media gaat een komische video rond van een Russisch gezin op een vliegtuig op weg naar de VS. Ze leren tijdens hun vlucht "Amerikaanse gebruiken" kennen en besluiten daardoor terug te keren naar hun moederland.
- In tegenstelling tot wat propagandakanalen en andere gebruikers beweren is dit geen propagandavideo om Russen te overtuigen hun land niet te ontvluchten.
- Het gaat om (fragmenten uit) een sketch van de Russische komedieserie "Hardop!".
- We beoordelen de claim dat deze video Russische propaganda is dan ook al misleidend.
Meer informatie over de factchecks van VRT NWS lees je in dit artikel.
Je vindt onze factchecks ook terug bij deCheckers, samen met betrouwbare factchecks van andere Vlaamse redacties.
Wil je iets laten checken? Stuur ons dan een mail via check@vrtnws.be of vul je vraag in op de website van deCheckers.
Translation:
CHECK - Video about emigrating Russians laughing at "Western values" is not propaganda, but satire
On social media, Russian propagandists and other users wrongly claim that a comedy sketch is propaganda. We see a Russian family emigrating to the United States. During their flight they are introduced to so-called "American customs" such as "not eating meat around vegetarians". It encourages them to return to their motherland. Millions of people have seen the video online, claiming it is a propaganda video that makes fun of Western values. That's not right.
“How long I've been waiting for this…” a Russian father says blissfully to his wife as they sit on a plane to the United States. Together with their son, they leave Russia to pursue the "American dream". A fellow passenger turns and says that "America is the freest country in the world." Moments later, her partner, a woman, plops down next to her. The Russian couple is shocked that homosexual relationships are allowed in "free America".
Thus begins the video that is being called "Russian propaganda" online and is currently being viewed en masse. During the flight, the family is introduced to so-called "American or Western customs". In addition to a tolerant attitude towards the LGBTQIA+ community, they are taught not to eat meat around vegetarians. People with a dark skin color must be given priority in the queue to the toilet. “We owe all African Americans something!” says a passenger, referring to years of oppression by white people.
Watch the video here:
Mobilization
Due to the partial mobilization that Russian President Putin announced a few weeks ago, many Russians are packing their bags. According to many social media users, the rather absurd video is an answer to this.
"In the Russian Federation, videos are being distributed against mass emigration. In the US, for example, there are terrible gay marriages and "we should apologize to people of color," a Twitter user wrote sarcastically. The message reached more than 570,000 people. In another tweet, the video is viewed by almost 6 million people.
These types of videos should convince the population to stay. Or that is the reasoning of many propagandists and other Twitter users. The video makes fun of Western values, which are said to be at odds with those of the Russians. Reason enough to stay.
In this Twitter message the video is described as "Russian propaganda". Nearly 6 million people watched it.
Startled by their unfamiliar habits, the family in the video decides to jump out of the plane with a parachute. “Forgive us, Mother Russia. We will come back,” the father shouts.
Sketch
Nothing seems further from the truth. As the satirical undertone suggests, it is not a propaganda video, but a sketch from the Russian comedy series "ВСЛУХ!" aka "Out Loud!". The program can be seen weekly on RuTube, the Russian version of YouTube. The makers often make fun of the goings-on in Russia and far beyond. You can compare it with our well-known satirical program "The ideal world" on Canvas.
The sketch comes from episode 15 (see minute 07:42) of last week and has the telling title "Tolerant flight". The video shared on social media does not contain the full sketch, but a mix of fragments.
The actor who played the father has also confirmed that it is satire. “You see, if you look at this short story outside the context of the program, it may take on the character of an anti-emigration advertisement,” Sergey Pogosyan tells Russian news medium NGS42. "But this is a sketch. (...) These ideas of tolerance are also common in Russia. When I meet someone with a non-heterosexual orientation, I have no desire to insult or humiliate him."
In the Radio 1 program "The Hour of Truth" Luc Van Bakel also talks about the viral video. Listen to it here:
De Checkers: Do traders want to flee Brussels? Does Russia use skits as propaganda?
Telegram
Why then is it picked up as a propaganda video? Our search points to the chat application Telegram. There, several people share the full sketch in pro-Russian channels as "Кремлёвская прачка" (Kremlin Prachka).
The Russian propagandist and TV presenter Vladimir Soloviev also shares it in his Telegram channel. More than 305,000 of his 1.3 million followers are watching it. In all likelihood, the sketch was distributed in a shorter version on social media such as Twitter via Telegram.
Russian embassy in Spain
The video is reminiscent of a real, bizarre promotional video from last summer. In less than a minute, the viewer is given dozens of reasons why it is "time to move to Russia". There are "cheap electricity and water", "beautiful women", "vodka" and "an economy that can withstand thousands of sanctions". The video went viral after the Russian embassy in Spain shared it on Twitter.
It is not clear whether the video should be taken seriously.
Conclusion
- A comical video of a Russian family on a plane heading to the US is circulating on social media. During their flight they get to know "American customs" and therefore decide to return to their motherland.
- Contrary to what propaganda channels and other users claim, this is not a propaganda video to convince Russians not to flee their country.
- It concerns (excerpts from) a sketch from the Russian comedy series "Aloud!".
- We therefore assess the claim that this video is Russian propaganda as misleading.
You can read more information about the fact checks of VRT NWS in this article.
You will also find our fact checks at deCheckers, together with reliable fact checks from other Flemish editors.
Would you like to have something checked? Send us an email at check@vrtnws.be or fill in your question on the deCheckers website.

Počas prvých týždňov ruskej invázie na Ukrajinu začali protisystémové strany hovoriť o prívale nelegálnych migrantov z Ukrajiny, ktorí údajne zneužívajú napätú vojenskú situáciu. Podobné tvrdenie vyslovil 20. novembra v relácii Na telo aj bývalý premiér Peter Pellegrini. Výrok však nie je pravdivý. Väčšinu utečencov z tretích krajín tvorili študenti, turisti a ľudia zamestnaní v ukrajinských podnikoch.
Pellegriniho výrok znel nasledovne:
„Určite zneužili nelegálni migranti aj situáciu na Ukrajine a prvé momenty neviem, aká je situácia aktuálna, ale v prvých týždňoch a mesiacoch prechádzali cez ukrajinskú hranicu nielen ukrajinskí utečenci pred vojnou, ale aj rôzni utečenci z iných krajín, ktorí nemali s Ukrajinou nič spoločné.”
Tesne po začatí ruskej invázie na Ukrajinu sa spustila prvá vlna utečencov z napadnutej krajiny smerom na západ, teda aj do susedného Slovenska. Ako informovali mnohé tunajšie a zahraničné médiá, medzi nimi aj Deutsche Welle, Ukrajinu spočiatku neopúšťali len občania Ukrajiny (ktorých bola výrazná väčšina), ale aj ľudia z tretích krajín. Medzi nimi boli najmä študenti z afrických a ázijských krajín snažiaci sa uniknúť pred konfliktom, ktorých bolo pred začatím vojny na Ukrajine okolo 75 tisíc. Okrem iného sa tam nachádzali aj trvalo pracujúci a turisti.
Práve táto skutočnosť vyvolala vlnu nenávisti, šírenia hoaxov a dezinformácií. Jedným zo zdrojov týchto neprávd bola strana ĽSNS, konkrétne jej predseda, Marian Kotleba, ktorý na youtube šíril hoaxy o údajnom prívale utečencov z Ázie a Afriky bez kontroly.
Polícia SR promptne reagovala na svojom facebookovom profile, kde vyvrátila tvrdenia o nekontrolovatelnom prívale migrantov cez naše hranice. Ministerstvo vnútra potvrdilo, že 90 percent ľudí prekračujúcich našu schengenskú hranicu tvorili Ukrajinskí občania, prevažne ženy a deti (nariadenie stanného práva neumožňovalo mužom opustiť krajinu).
Medzi 24.- 28. februárom celkovo prešlo hranicu 53 136 osôb, z toho viac ako 46-tisíc boli Ukrajinci, 1774 občanov EÚ a 4 774 príslušníkov tretích krajín, uvádza Polícia SR.
Mesiac od začiatku ruského útoku zaznamenalo ministerstvo vnútra viac ako 269 000 utečencov. Ukrajinci z tejto skupiny tvorili viac ako 92 % (takmer 249 000). Cez slovenské hranice tiež prešlo 12 106 príslušníkov tretích krajín a 8 245 príslušníkov EÚ. Spolu išlo o občanov 145 štátov. Väčšinu tvorili ženy a deti.
Pre študentov a občanov väčšiny týchto krajín bol taktiež zriadený vládny špeciál z krajín pôvodu, a teda boli následne transportovaní zo Slovenska, ako bol prípad študentov z Indie.
Translation:
During the first weeks of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, anti-establishment parties began to talk about the influx of illegal migrants from Ukraine, allegedly abusing the tense military situation. Former Prime Minister Peter Pellegrini made a similar claim on November 20 in the Na telo show. However, the statement is not true. The majority of refugees from third countries were students, tourists and people employed in Ukrainian enterprises.
Pellegrini's statement was as follows:
"Illegal migrants certainly abused the situation in Ukraine and the first moments, I don't know what the current situation is, but in the first weeks and months, not only Ukrainian refugees before the war, but also various refugees from other countries who had nothing to do with Ukraine crossed the Ukrainian border. "
Immediately after the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the first wave of refugees from the invaded country started westward, i.e. also to neighboring Slovakia. As reported by many local and foreign media, including Deutsche Welle, initially not only citizens of Ukraine (of which there was a significant majority) left Ukraine, but also people from third countries. Among them were mainly students from African and Asian countries trying to escape from the conflict, of whom there were around 75 thousand in Ukraine before the start of the war. Among other things, there were also permanent workers and tourists.
This very fact caused a wave of hatred, the spread of hoaxes and misinformation. One of the sources of these falsehoods was the ĽSNS party, specifically its chairman, Marian Kotleba, who spread hoaxes on YouTube about the alleged influx of refugees from Asia and Africa without control.
The SR Police responded promptly on their Facebook profile, where they refuted claims about an uncontrollable influx of migrants across our borders. The Ministry of the Interior confirmed that 90 percent of people crossing our Schengen border were Ukrainian citizens, mostly women and children (martial law did not allow men to leave the country).
Between February 24 and 28, a total of 53,136 people crossed the border, of which more than 46,000 were Ukrainians, 1,774 EU citizens and 4,774 members of third countries, according to the Slovak Police.
A month after the start of the Russian attack, the Ministry of the Interior recorded more than 269,000 refugees. Ukrainians from this group made up more than 92% (almost 249,000). 12,106 members of third countries and 8,245 members of the EU also crossed the Slovak border. In total, they were citizens of 145 states. The majority were women and children.
For students and citizens of most of these countries, a government special was also established from the countries of origin, and thus they were subsequently transported from Slovakia, as was the case with students from India.

Yemen: Video af skibsbrand stammer ikke fra missilangreb
-
På det sociale medie X er en video af en voldsom brand på et amerikansk skib ud for Yemens kyst gået viralt
-
Branden skulle være brudt ud efter et nyt missilangreb, fremgår det af opslagene, som er set flere millioner gange
-
Men videoen er ikke fra et missilangreb i den nuværende konflikt. Den stammer fra en skibsbrand i 2021
“USA-ejet fragtskib er lige blevet ramt af et missil ud for Yemens kyst”, står der i mange opslag på X med en tilhørende video af en stor brand på et skib.
I opslagene kan man se en video, der angiveligt viser en voldsom brand i et amerikansk skib.
Opslagene taler ind i, at verden i fredags vågnede op til nyheden om, at USA og Storbritannien havde ramt militære mål for Houthi-bevægelsen i Yemen.
Houthi-bevægelsen har siden den 19. november ramt flere civile fragtskibe i Det Røde Hav, hvilket altså fik USA og Storbritannien til at svare igen - med opbakning fra blandt andre Danmark.
Men videoen, som nu deles af mange profiler på X, stammer slet ikke fra konflikten i Det Røde Hav.
Containerskib brændte i 12 dage
For at finde ud af, hvor videoen originalt stammer fra, har vi taget et screenshot af klippet og uploadet det til den russiske søgemaskine Yandex.
Den omvendte billedsøgning giver mange præcise resultater svarende til videoen på X, og det står hurtigt klart, at videoen stammer fra en helt anden begivenhed, nemlig en skibsbrand i 2021.
“Brand på skib fra Sri Lanka er endelig blevet slukket; Shipping-firma fra Singapore er blevet sagsøgt for maritim-forurening”, står der i overskriften på en artikel fra The Straight Times tilbage i juni, 2021.
“Ilden raser, stor eksplosion smadrer stort containerskib”, står der i en anden artikel.
Den 25 maj i 2021 skete der nemlig en eksplosion på fragtskibet X-Press Pearl, som var på vej fra Singapore til Indien.
På skibet var der blandt andet kemikalier og olie, hvilket betød, at myndighederne var 12 dage om at slukke branden.
Mandskabet på skibet blev hurtigt evakueret og eksplosionen var kun skyld i mindre personskader, men til gengæld blev plastikforureningen af branden kaldt for en af de værste i Sri Lankas historie.
Ingen tilskadekomne efter missilangreb
Selvom videoen er taget ude af kontekst, så er informationerne i de mange opslag ikke trukket ud af den blå luft, for mandag blev et amerikansk skib rent faktisk ramt af et missil.
“Iransk støttede Houthi-militante fyrede et anti-skib, ballistisk missil fra Houthi-kontrollerede områder i Yemen og ramte M/V Gibraltar Eagle”, skrev den amerikanske centralkommando selv på deres X-profil mandag eftermiddag
“Skibet har ikke rapporteret personskader eller skade af betydning på skibet og fortsætter dets rejse,” tilføjede de i opslaget.
Houthi-bevægelsen har sidenhen taget ansvaret for angrebet, og bevægelsens talsmand Yayha Saree har understreget, at yderligere angreb fra USA og Storbritannien vil blive mødt med “modsvar” og “straf”.
Translation:
Yemen: Video of ship fire not from missile attack
-
On the social media X, a video of a violent fire on an American ship off the coast of Yemen has gone viral
-
The fire should have broken out after a new missile attack, according to the postings, which have been viewed several million times
-
But the video is not from a missile strike in the current conflict. It originates from a ship fire in 2021
"A US-owned cargo ship has just been hit by a missile off the coast of Yemen", many posts on X say, with an accompanying video of a large fire on a ship.
In the posts, you can see a video that allegedly shows a violent fire in an American ship.
The reports speak to the fact that the world woke up on Friday to the news that the USA and Great Britain had hit military targets for the Houthi movement in Yemen.
Since November 19, the Houthi movement has attacked several civilian cargo ships in the Red Sea, which caused the United States and Great Britain to respond again - with support from, among others, Denmark.
But the video, which is now shared by many profiles on X, does not originate from the conflict in the Red Sea at all.
Container ship burned for 12 days
To find out where the video originally came from, we took a screenshot of the clip and uploaded it to the Russian search engine Yandex.
The reverse image search gives many exact results similar to the video on X, and it quickly becomes clear that the video originates from a completely different event, namely a ship fire in 2021.
“Fire on ship from Sri Lanka finally extinguished; Shipping company from Singapore has been sued for maritime pollution”, reads the headline of an article from The Straight Times back in June, 2021.
"Fire rages, large explosion smashes large container ship," another article says.
On 25 May 2021, an explosion occurred on the cargo ship X-Press Pearl, which was on its way from Singapore to India.
Among other things, there were chemicals and oil on the ship, which meant that the authorities had 12 days to extinguish the fire.
The crew on the ship was quickly evacuated and the explosion was only responsible for minor injuries, but on the other hand the plastic pollution from the fire was called one of the worst in Sri Lanka's history.
No injuries after missile attack
Although the video is taken out of context, the information in the many postings is not pulled out of thin air, because on Monday an American ship was actually hit by a missile.
"Iranian-backed Houthi militants fired an anti-ship ballistic missile from Houthi-controlled areas in Yemen and hit the M/V Gibraltar Eagle," the US Central Command itself wrote on their X profile on Monday afternoon
"The ship has reported no casualties or significant damage to the ship and is continuing its voyage," they added in the post.
The Houthi movement has since taken responsibility for the attack, and the movement's spokesperson Yayha Saree has emphasized that further attacks from the US and Great Britain will be met with "retaliation" and "punishment".

Es sind abenteuerliche Informationen, die der angebliche Journalist Frank Peter Hellmann in einem 3Sat-Beitrag preisgibt: Auf einer Veranstaltung in Moskau sei ihm 1999 eine Akte des russischen Geheimdienstes zugesteckt worden. Es gehe um die Formel eines Neurotransmitters, der das Gehirn durcheinander bringe, um neue Realitäten in den Köpfen der Menschen zu konstruieren und sie zu manipulieren. Laut dem Mann werde die Substanz durch Flugzeuge über der Bevölkerung versprüht, eine EU-Finanzierung schließe er nicht aus.
Das Video verbreitet sich auf Tiktok, Twitter, Whatsapp und auf mehreren Video–Plattformen. Es wird als „Sensation” bezeichnet, die „blanke Wahrheit“ komme „nun in offiziellen Medien“, heißt es.
Doch der Inhalt ist frei erfunden. Der Beitrag ist Teil einer Diskussionssendung über Verschwörungen, die 2012 auf dem öffentlich-rechtlichen TV-Sender 3Sat ausgestrahlt wurde. Sie sollte zeigen, was Verschwörungerzählungen ausmache und wie sie funktionieren. Der angebliche Journalist ist Schauspieler, der Film „von Anfang bis Ende erfunden”, wie Gert Scobel, Moderator der Sendung, in der längeren Originalfassung der Sendung sagt.
Verschwörungsvideo von 3Sat ist „von Anfang bis Ende“ erfunden und im Original auch so deklariert
Unter dem Twitter-Beitrag, in dem das gut zwei Minuten lange Video geteilt wird, postete ein Nutzer einen Youtube-Link. Dort findet sich ein Video der ganzen Sendung, sie dauert fast eine Stunde. Dazu heißt es, sie sei am 6. September 2012 auf 3Sat ausgestrahlt worden. Andere Videos der Sendung wurden mit denselben Angaben auf Youtube veröffentlicht.
In der 3Sat-Mediathek ist die Sendung nicht mehr abrufbar, unsere Anfrage an die Pressestelle von 3Sat, ob sie an besagtem Tag lief, wurde bislang nicht beantwortet. Mehrere Medien und andere Portale schrieben 2012 über die Sendung. In einem Facebook-Beitrag von 2012 bewarb die 3Sat-Redaktion ein Interview mit dem angeblichen Enthüllungsjournalisten Frank Peter Hellmann – dass die Person nur erfunden ist, wird aus dem Beitrag aber nicht ersichtlich.
Bei Minute 3:49 der 3Sat-Sendung beginnt jener Part des Videos, der in Sozialen Netzwerken aktuell geteilt wird. Bei Minute 7:13 sagt Moderator Scodel dann „Natürlich haben Sie es gemerkt, dieser Film war ein Fake und ist erfunden von Anfang bis Ende“. Dieser Teil fehlt im verbreiteten Ausschnitt. Die Formel, die im Beitrag gezeigt wird (Minute 4:43) und die angeblich eine benebelnde Wirkung haben soll, sei übrigens die Formel von Alkohol. Der Film enthalte aber, so Scobel, „wie jede gute Verschwörungstheorie“, Elemente, „die einen für Momente ins Grübeln bringen“.
Der kurze Beitrag von 3Sat sieht also auf den ersten Blick wie eine echte Dokumentation aus, sein Inhalt ist aber frei erfunden. Solche inszenierten Dokumentarfilme, die den Zuschauenden etwas vortäuschen, werden auch Mockumentaries genannt (aus dem Englischen „to mock“: vortäuschen, nachahmen, verspotten). In der Regel könne man sie an den „auf die Spitze getriebenen Unwahrscheinlichkeiten“ erkennen, wie die Universität Kiel schreibt.
Ein erfundener Journalist und ein Historiker, der Desinformation verbreitet
Nachdem der Moderator Scobel den Film als Fälschung enttarnt, stellt er die Gäste seiner Sendung vor, mit denen er über Verschwörungen diskutiert. Einer davon ist Daniele Ganser, eine Schweizer, der als Historiker, Energie- und Friedensforscher vorgestellt wird. Ganser verbreitete später, im Jahr 2014, in einem Vortrag Verschwörungstheorien zu dem Anschlag auf das World Trade Center, schrieb das Schweizer Magazin Republik. Mittlerweile äußert er sich zu Themen wie Corona und dem russischen Angriffskrieg, die FAZ nannte ihn kürzlich den „Star der Putin-Versteher“. In einem Hintergrundtext von uns über eine prorussische Influencerin kommt er am Rande ebenfalls vor. Gegen Gansers öffentlichen Auftritte gab es in der jüngeren Vergangenheit Proteste.
Und wer ist der Mann, der im Verschwörungsvideo als Journalist Frank Peter Hellmann auftritt? Er ist kein Journalist, sondern Schauspieler und heißt eigentlich anders. Wir konnten ihn ausfindig machen und haben mit einer Vertreterin seiner Agentur telefoniert. Die bestätigt, dass er damals in dem Video mitgespielt hatte. Er habe aber nach der Ausstrahlung „schlimmste Drohungen” erhalten, deswegen bitte er, namentlich nicht genannt zu werden.
Redigatur: Paulina Thom, Uschi Jonas
Translation:
It is adventurous information that the alleged journalist Frank Peter Hellmann reveals in a 3Sat report: At an event in Moscow in 1999, he was given a file from the Russian secret service. It's about the formula of a neurotransmitter that confuses the brain in order to construct new realities in people's heads and manipulate them. According to the man, the substance is sprayed over the population by planes and he does not rule out EU funding.
The video is spreading on Tiktok, Twitter, Whatsapp and several video platforms. It is described as a “sensation”, the “blank truth” is “now coming out in official media”, they say.
But the content is fictitious. The article is part of a discussion program about conspiracies that was broadcast on the public TV channel 3Sat in 2012. It should show what conspiracy narratives are and how they work. The alleged journalist is an actor, the film is “invented from start to finish,” as Gert Scobel, host of the show, says in the longer original version of the show.
Conspiracy video from 3Sat is made up “from start to finish” and declared as such in the original
A user posted a YouTube link under the Twitter post in which the two-minute long video was shared. There is a video of the entire program there, it lasts almost an hour. It is said that it was broadcast on September 6, 2012 on 3Sat. Other videos from the show were published on YouTube with the same information.
The program is no longer available in the 3Sat media library, and our request to the 3Sat press office as to whether it was broadcast on that day has not yet been answered. Several media and other portals wrote about the show in 2012. In a Facebook post from 2012, the 3Sat editorial team advertised an interview with the alleged investigative journalist Frank Peter Hellmann - but it is not clear from the post that the person is fictitious.
At minute 3:49 of the 3Sat broadcast, the part of the video that is currently being shared on social networks begins. At minute 7:13, presenter Scodel says “Of course you noticed, this film was a fake and is made up from start to finish”. This part is missing from the widespread excerpt. The formula shown in the article (minute 4:43) and which is supposed to have a dizzying effect is, by the way, the formula of alcohol. However, according to Scobel, “like any good conspiracy theory,” the film contains elements “that make you think for a moment.”
At first glance, 3Sat's short contribution looks like a real documentary, but its content is fictitious. Such staged documentaries that make the audience believe something is also called mockumentaries (from the English “to mock”: to pretend, imitate, mock). As a rule, you can recognize them by the “improbabilities taken to extremes,” as the University of Kiel writes.
A fictional journalist and a historian spreading disinformation
After the presenter Scobel exposes the film as a fake, he introduces the guests on his show with whom he discusses conspiracies. One of them is Daniele Ganser, a Swiss woman who is introduced as a historian, energy and peace researcher. Ganser later spread conspiracy theories about the attack on the World Trade Center in a lecture in 2014, wrote the Swiss magazine Republik. He now speaks out on topics such as Corona and the Russian war of aggression; the FAZ recently called him the “star of those who understand Putin”. He also appears in passing in one of our background texts about a pro-Russian influencer. There have been protests against Ganser's public appearances in the recent past.
And who is the man who appears as journalist Frank Peter Hellmann in the conspiracy video? He is not a journalist, but an actor and his actual name is different. We were able to locate him and spoke to a representative from his agency on the phone. She confirms that he starred in the video at the time. However, he received “the worst threats” after the broadcast, which is why he asked not to be named.
Editing: Paulina Thom, Uschi Jonas

Factcheck: Nee, dit is niet ‘Mary’, ‘gestorven aan de effecten van 5G’
Deze factcheck is uitgevoerd op basis van de beschikbare informatie op de datum van publicatie. Lees hier meer over hoe we werken.
Op Facebook verschijnt een foto van een gewonde vrouw die ‘Mary’ zou heten en zou overleden zijn aan de effecten van 5G. Het blijkt te gaan om een selfie van de tv-persoonlijkheid Yasmine Pierards, die hem op haar Instagramaccount plaatste nadat ze werd aangevallen. Volgens privacyjurist Matthias Dobbelaere-Welvaert is dit soort misbruik van foto’s strafbaar.
Op 12 augustus verschijnt onderstaand bericht op de Facebookpagina Gustaaf Verschraegen. Bij de pagina, die bijna 2000 volgers heeft, hoort een duidelijk bewerkte profielfoto van een oudere man, bij de infosectie lezen we dat Verschraegen zichzelf omschrijft als ‘een echte Vlaemsche volksheld’. Wat op de pagina wordt gepost, lijkt niet serieus bedoeld, het betreft eerder een vorm van satire of parodie.
Het bericht staat amper 24 uur online, wordt in die tijd 17 keer gedeeld en lokt 384 reacties uit, onder meer van mensen die zich boos maken, niet alleen over de inhoud maar vooral over de bij het bericht gebruikte foto. In totaal wordt het bericht door 36.800 Facebookgebruikers gezien. Op 13 augustus, na het verschijnen van deze factcheck, wordt het offline gehaald.
Het bericht bevat een foto van een zwaar toegetakelde jonge vrouw met een mondmasker rond de kin. In het bijschrift wordt verteld dat de vrouw ‘Mary’ zou heten, en dat ze zou gestorven zijn aan 5G. De tekst bevat ook een waarschuwing: haar geest zou er nu op uit zijn om iedereen die 5G gebruikt te vermoorden.
De foto komt ons meteen bekend voor. Ook enkele mensen die reageren op de post, hebben de foto herkend: hij blijkt afkomstig van het Instagramaccount van Yasmine Pierards, een 23-jarige Belgische die in 2018 als verleidster deelnam aan het VT4-programma Temptation Island en nadien ook te zien was in de realityreeks Ex on the Beach op MTV.
Pierards postte de foto op 10 augustus. In het begeleidende bericht legt ze uit dat ze werd mishandeld door een man die na een feestje haar huis niet wilde verlaten. Verschillende media berichten op 11 augustus over het incident, onder meer Het Laatste Nieuws en De Standaard.
Strafbaar
Volgens Matthias Dobbelaere-Welvaert, privacyjurist en docent ‘Copyrights & Mediarights’ bij Erasmus Hogeschool Brussel, is wat de auteur van dit bericht doet een duidelijke inbreuk op het auteursrecht, dat de maker van de foto beschermt. Omdat het om een selfie gaat, is dat in dit geval Pierards zelf.
‘Bovendien is het is een inbreuk op het recht op afbeelding, ook portretrecht genoemd, dat de persoon op de foto beschermt. En natuurlijk is het ook een zuivere inbreuk van de privacy van Yasmine Pierards’, zegt Dobbelaere-Welvaert.
‘Het is niet omdat de dame bekend is van tv dat zij geen portretrecht of privacy meer zou hebben. Politici of bekende personen kunnen zich moeilijk verweren tegen foto’s die bijvoorbeeld gemaakt zijn in het parlement of in een tv-studio, maar in dit geval gaat het om een ‘intieme’ foto die absoluut niet tot doel had om te worden misbruikt. Het feit dat Pierards de foto deelde op Instagram speelt daarbij geen rol.’
Voor de schending van het auteursrecht zou Pierards volgens Dobbelaere-Welvaert een schadevergoeding kunnen vragen, en kunnen eisen dat foto en bericht worden weggehaald. ‘Wat haar privacy betreft, ligt het moeilijker. De GDPR-wetgeving voorziet in straffen en boetes voor ondernemingen en overheden die onze data misbruiken, maar helaas niet voor natuurlijke personen.’
‘Pierards zou wel een strafprocedure kunnen opstarten wegens laster en eerroof.’ Dat de foto hier misbruikt wordt bij een manifest onwaar bericht, zal volgens Dobbelaere-Welvaert meespelen in de beoordeling van de rechter.
CONCLUSIE
De vrouw op de foto bij het bericht van Gustaaf Verschraegen heet niet ‘Mary’ en ze is niet overleden aan 5G, zoals de auteur beweert. De foto is afkomstig van het Instagramaccount van de tv-persoonlijkheid Yasmine Pierards. We beoordelen het bericht daarom als onwaar.
BRONNEN
Facebook (12 augustus 2020)
Instagram (10 augustus 2020)
Het Laatste Nieuws (11 augustus 2020)
De Standaard (11 augustus 2020)
Mailverkeer met Matthias Dobbelaere-Welvaert op 12 en 13 augustus 2020
Alle bronnen werd laatst geraadpleegd op 13 augustus 2020.
*Op 13 augustus 2020 om 16:27 werd het bericht bijgewerkt: we vermeldden uitdrukkelijk dat de Facebookpagina Gustaaf Verschraegen als satire bedoeld is (omdat uit boze reacties op het bericht bleek dat dat niet voor iedereen duidelijk was), en dat het bewuste bericht ondertussen offline was gehaald.
**Op 8 oktober 2020 om 11:40 werd in de inleiding de zin ‘Volgens juristen is dit soort misbruik van foto’s strafbaar’ vervangen door ‘Volgens privacyjurist Matthias Dobbelaere-Welvaertis dit soort misbruik van foto’s strafbaar’, omdat die formulering beter correspondeert met de inhoud van het artikel.

Translation:
Fact check: No, this is not 'Mary', 'died from the effects of 5G'
This fact check was carried out based on the information available at the date of publication. Read more about how we work here.
A photo of an injured woman allegedly called 'Mary' appears on Facebook and is said to have died from the effects of 5G. It turns out to be a selfie of TV personality Yasmine Pierards, who posted it on her Instagram account after she was attacked. According to privacy lawyer Matthias Dobbelaere-Welvaert, this type of misuse of photos is punishable.
On August 12, the message below will appear on the Gustaaf Verschraegen Facebook page. The page, which has almost 2,000 followers, includes a clearly edited profile photo of an older man, and in the information section we read that Verschraegen describes himself as 'a real Flemish folk hero'. What is posted on the page does not appear to be intended seriously, rather it is a form of satire or parody.
The message has been online for barely 24 hours, has been shared 17 times in that time and provoked 384 reactions, including from people who are angry, not only about the content but especially about the photo used in the message. The message was seen by a total of 36,800 Facebook users. On August 13, after the publication of this fact check, it will be taken offline.
The message contains a photo of a badly injured young woman with a face mask around her chin. The caption states that the woman's name was "Mary" and that she died of 5G. The text also contains a warning: her ghost is now out to kill anyone who uses 5G.
The photo immediately looks familiar. Some people who responded to the post also recognized the photo: it appears to come from the Instagram account of Yasmine Pierards, a 23-year-old Belgian who participated as a seductress in the VT4 program Temptation Island in 2018 and subsequently also appeared in the reality series Ex on the Beach on MTV.
Pierards posted the photo on August 10. In the accompanying message, she explains that she was abused by a man who would not leave her house after a party. Various media reported on the incident on August 11, including Het Laatste Nieuws and De Standaard.
Punishable
According to Matthias Dobbelaere-Welvaert, privacy lawyer and lecturer in 'Copyrights & Mediarights' at Erasmus Hogeschool Brussels, what the author of this message is doing is a clear infringement of copyright, which protects the creator of the photo. Because it is a selfie, in this case it is Pierards himself.
'Moreover, it is an infringement of the right to image, also called portrait right, which protects the person in the photo. And of course it is also a pure violation of Yasmine Pierards' privacy," says Dobbelaere-Welvaert.
'Just because the lady is known from TV does not mean that she no longer has portrait rights or privacy. Politicians or famous people find it difficult to defend themselves against photos taken in parliament or in a TV studio, for example, but in this case it is an 'intimate' photo that was absolutely not intended to be misused. The fact that Pierards shared the photo on Instagram plays no role in this.'
According to Dobbelaere-Welvaert, Pierards could ask for damages for copyright infringement and demand that the photo and message be removed. 'As far as her privacy is concerned, it is more difficult. The GDPR legislation provides for penalties and fines for companies and governments that misuse our data, but unfortunately not for natural persons.'
"Pierards could initiate criminal proceedings for defamation and defamation of character." The fact that the photo is misused here in a manifestly untrue message will, according to Dobbelaere-Welvaert, play a role in the judge's assessment.
CONCLUSION
The woman in the photo accompanying Gustaaf Verschraegen's message is not called 'Mary' and she did not die from 5G, as the author claims. The photo comes from the Instagram account of TV personality Yasmine Pierards. We therefore rate the message as false.
SOURCES
Facebook (August 12, 2020)
Instagram (August 10, 2020)
The Latest News (August 11, 2020)
De Standaard (11 August 2020)
Email traffic with Matthias Dobbelaere-Welvaert on August 12 and 13, 2020
All sources were last consulted on August 13, 2020.
*On August 13, 2020 at 4:27 PM, the message was updated: we explicitly stated that the Gustaaf Verschraegen Facebook page is intended as satire (because angry reactions to the message showed that this was not clear to everyone), and that the message in question has since been deleted. was taken offline.
**On October 8, 2020 at 11:40 AM in the introduction, the sentence 'According to legal experts, this type of misuse of photos is punishable' was replaced by 'According to privacy lawyer Matthias Dobbelaere-Welvaertis, this type of misuse of photos is punishable', because that wording corresponds better with the content of the article.

Végéhez közeledik Amber Heard és Johnny Depp tárgyalása. A két színész pere az elmúlt hetekben túlzás nélkül elárasztotta a nemzetközi sajtót, és a különféle közösségi média platformokat.
A hatalmas médiafigyelem mellett - köszönhetően a tárgyalás folyamatos, élő közvetítésének – a rajongók is folyamatosan gyártják ugyanis a “tartalmakat” a perrel, annak szereplőivel, és lehetséges kimenetelével kapcsolatban. Látványos hozadéka az ügynek,hogy Johnny Depp rajongói rengeteg olyan posztot tesznek közzé, amelyben nemcsak támogatásukról igyekeznek biztosítani bennük a színészt, de igyekeznek minden lehetséges módon bizonyítani azt is, hogy Amber Heard nem mond igazat.
Akár hamis hírek terjesztésével is.
Johnny Depp 50 millió dollárra perli volt feleségét, Amber Heard színésznőt egy 2018-ban írt véleménycikke miatt. Ebben ugyan a színésznő nem nevezte meg volt férjét, ám az őt ért családon belüli erőszakról írt. Depp álláspontja szerint a Washington Postban megjelent cikk miatt több szerepet is elveszített. Az elmúlt hetekben a nyilvánosság előtt zajló tárgyaláson Depp és Heard kölcsönösen vádolta egymást különféle (fizikai és lelki) bántalmazással, a színészek, ügyvédeik, illetve a tanúk megszólalásait pedig azonnal kivesézte a sajtó, és természetesen a pert másodpercről másodpercre követő rajongók is.
Halim Dhanidina büntetőjogi védőügyvéd a New York Postnak azt nyilatkozta: ha az esküdtszék végül Johnny Deppnek ad igazat, az „visszatartó erővel hathat és elriaszthat más áldozatokat attól, hogy nyilvánosság elé álljanak”. Szerinte bármilyen rágalmazási perről is legyen szó, ha az a fél nyer, aki a pert indította, az visszatartó erővel bír az áldozatok számára, „hogy előálljanak és felszólaljanak intézményekkel, szervezetekkel vagy hatalommal rendelkező emberekkel szemben, mert úgy érzik, hogy egy világ omolhat rájuk”. A védőügyvéd hozzátette azonban azt is, hogy „másrészt nem akarunk olyan világot, ahol az emberek úgy érzik, azt mondhatnak, amit akarnak, még akkor is, ha tudják, hogy az nem igaz”.
Bárhogy is záruljon azonban az ügy, rágalmazási perről van szó, így börtönbe senki nem kerül a végén – legfeljebb kártérítést kell fizetni.
A per kapcsán azonban érdemes beszélni arról, hogy az elmúlt hetekben több olyan hír is elkezdett terjedni, amelyek elsősorban a színésznőt tűntették fel kifejezetten rossz színben – ám amelyek később hamisnak bizonyultak. Ezek közül gyűjtöttünk össze néhányat.
A YouTube mellett a “kölcsönvett” idézetekről szóló tartalmak a TikTokon, a Twitteren is rendkívül népszerűek voltak (magyar nyelven például ebben a cikkben írnak a témáról, és ebben a publicisztikában is utalnak rá).
A leggyakrabban azt a részletet emelték ki a Tehetséges Mr. Ripley című filmből, amikor Gwyneth Paltrow karaktere azt mondja: “A dolog Dickie-vel… Olyan, mintha rád sütne a nap, és ez csodálatos. Aztán elfelejtkezik rólad, és akkor nagyon-nagyon hideg lesz.” Ezt a sort idézte Heard, de értelemszerűen a nevet Johnny-ra cserélve.
Valóság: Ez talán a legtöbb alkalommal cáfolt hamis hír a tárgyalással kapcsolatban. Többek közt az AFP, a PolitiFact és a FullFact.org, de még a Hinduistan Times is cáfolta az állítást, miszerint a színésznő vallomásában filmekből lopott idézeteket. Erre pedig elég könnyen volt lehetősége minden tényellenőrzőnek, ugyanis a tárgyalást élőben is lehet nézni, illetve bármikor visszanézhető.
Az AFP például mind a május 4-én, mind május 5-én elhangzott vallomást végignézve azt találta, hogy a fentebb kiemelt mondatok nem hangzottak el, a legközelebb talán az állt a filmbeli idézetekhez, amikor Heard egy ponton úgy fogalmazott:
"Amikor Johnny közelében voltam, a világ legszebb emberének éreztem magam. Tudod, láthatónak éreztem magam, úgy éreztem magam, mint egy millió dollár.”
Később pedig úgy fogalmazott: "És akkor eltűnik, és akkor egyszerűen nem lehet megfogni, nem lehet kapcsolatba lépni vele."
Ám az, hogy a színésznő konkrétan idézett volna filmekből, nem igaz.
A videó ide kattintva nézhető meg.
Amber Heard vallomástétele után sokan úgy vélték, hogy a színésznő csak megjátszotta, hogy sírt, és valójában a könnyei nem voltak igaziak, erről is rengeteg közösségi médiaposzt készült, amelyekben gúnyt űznek Heard sírásából (itt egy példa, amely már 6 millió lájkot kapott).
Valóság: Az ügyben a Snapchat szóvivője is megszólalt, aki a TMZ pletykaoldalnak azt nyilatkozta, a filtert hat hónappal a tárgyalás előtt kezdték el fejleszteni, azaz jóval azelőtt, hogy a színésznőről elkészültek a tárgyaláson azok a képek, amelyek aztán bejárták a sajtót. Vagyis nem Amber Heard inspirálta a Snapchat filterét.
Több mint egy millió megtekintés van a videón, amely azt állítja, hogy a színész gyermekei is tettek vallomás az ügyben. A videóhoz csatolt nyitóképen Depp fia látható, alatta a felirat: “Tönkretetted az apámat”, mellette Heard: “Nem az én hibám”.
Valóság: Egy újabb, viszonylag könnyen ellenőrizhető tény: Johnny Depp gyerekei nem tettek vallomást a bíróság előtt, ahogy az kiderül a tárgyaláson készült felvételekből is (nem mellesleg pedig egyetlen újság sem számolt be erről a momentumról). A videó címe és nyitóképe hamisan sugallja, hogy a gyerekek részt vettek a tárgyaláson, miközben maga a 8 és fél perces klip mindössze összevágja azokat az alkalmakat, amikor Depp és Heard a tárgyaláson a gyerekekről beszél.
A Newsweek arra is felhívja a figyelmet, hogy a nyitókép manipulált, úgy tűnik, mintha Depp fia, Jack mögött a háttér a tárgyalóterem lenne, a kép azonban eredetileg 2020-ban készült Franciaországban, és a The Daily Mail tette közé.
Az alig 13 másodperces videót közel 15 millió alkalommal nézték meg eddig.
Valóság: A Ben Nye márka valóban kiadott olyan termékeket, amelyeket “zúzódáskészletnek” neveznek, és Bruise Wheels néven futnak, ám ezek nem olyan alakúak, mint amilyen sminkpaletta a fotón látható. Olyan terméke a márkának nincs, mint amilyenről a TikTok videóban beszélnek, az állítás tehát hamis.
Amber Heard ettől függetlenül kényelmetlen helyzetbe került, amikor egyik ügyvédje bemutatott egy olyan korrektorpalettát, amelyet állítása szerint a színésznő arra használt, hogy elfedje az arcán a Depp által okozott zúzódásokat. Ám a palettát gyártó márka, a Milani TikTokon közzétette, hogy a konkrét terméket csak 2017-ben dobták piacra, egy évvel azután, hogy Heard beadta a válópert.
“Szó szerint szippantott egy kis kokaint az emelvényen?” – áll a videó fölött. Ahogy azonban arra a PolitiFact is rámutat, a kiragadott részlet egy hosszabb, a YouTube-on megnézhető videóban is fellelhető, ahol az látszik, hogy a színésznő már korában magához veszi a zsebkendőt, hogy kifújja az orrát (12:05-kor), majd néhány perccel később látható az a jelenet, ahol ismét felemeli a zsebkendőt, és újra kifújja az orrát.
A YouTube-videó leggyakrabban lejátszott része egyébként épp ez a néhány másodperc.
A Politifact szerint azonban semmilyen bizonyíték nincs arra, hogy mindeközben a zsebkendőre kokain került volna, és Heard azt szippantotta volna fel. A Facebook erre figyelmezteti is azokat, akik a posztra kattintanak.
Arról, hogy Depp rajongói milyen nyomás alatt tartják, maga Amber Heard is beszélt a tárgyalás utolsó napjainak egyikén. A színésznő elmondása szerint több száz halálos fenyegetést kap naponta. “Minden egyes nap zaklatnak, megaláznak, fenyegetnek” – fogalmazott a tárgyaláson, hozzátéve, hogy még a gyerekét is halálosan megfenyegették.
Mindeközben Johnny Depp, ha a pert egyelőre nem is, de a közvéleményt már megnyerte magának (ezzel kapcsolatban ezt, ezt és ezt a cikket ajánljuk). Jellemző példa arra, hogy a színésszel kapcsolatban milyen hírek jelennek meg: miután volt párja, Kate Moss is tanúskodott a tárgyaláson, a rajongók egyből azon kezdtek el spekulálni, hogy vajon a színész és az egykori topmodel ismét egy párt alkot-e, illetve hogy milyen jó lenne, ha megint összejönnének. Igaz, korábban viszont az az elmélet tejedt, miszerint Depp az ügyvédjével, Camille Vasquezzel jött össze.
A rágalmazási perben végül természetesen az esküdtek, és nem a közvélemény dönt majd.
Címlapkép: BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI / POOL / AFP
Translation:
The trial of Amber Heard and Johnny Depp is coming to an end. The trial of the two actors has, without exaggeration, flooded the international press and various social media platforms in recent weeks.
In addition to the huge media attention - thanks to the continuous, live broadcast of the trial - the fans are also constantly producing "content" related to the trial, its actors, and its possible outcome. A spectacular result of the case is that Johnny Depp's fans publish a lot of posts in which they not only try to assure the actor of their support, but also try to prove in every possible way that Amber Heard is not telling the truth.
Even by spreading fake news.
Johnny Depp is suing his ex-wife, actress Amber Heard, for $50 million over an opinion piece she wrote in 2018. In it, the actress did not name her ex-husband, but she wrote about domestic violence against her. According to Depp's point of view, he lost several roles because of the article published in the Washington Post. During the public hearing in recent weeks, Depp and Heard mutually accused each other of various (physical and mental) abuses, and the statements of the actors, their lawyers, and the witnesses were immediately criticized by the press and, of course, by the fans who followed the trial second by second.
Criminal defense attorney Halim Dhanidina told the New York Post that if the jury ultimately finds Johnny Depp right, it "could act as a deterrent and deter other victims from coming forward." According to him, in any defamation case, if the party who started the case wins, it acts as a deterrent for victims "to come forward and speak out against institutions, organizations or people in power, because they feel that the world could come crashing down on them. ". However, the defense attorney added that "on the other hand, we don't want a world where people feel they can say whatever they want, even if they know it's not true."
However, however the case ends, it is a defamation lawsuit, so no one will go to jail in the end - at most, compensation will have to be paid.
However, in connection with the lawsuit, it is worth talking about the fact that in recent weeks, several news stories have started to spread, which primarily portrayed the actress in a particularly bad light - but which later turned out to be false. We have collected some of them.
In addition to YouTube, content about "borrowed" quotes was also extremely popular on TikTok and Twitter (in Hungarian, for example, they write about the topic in this article and refer to it in this publication).
The most cited part of The Talented Mr. Ripley is when Gwyneth Paltrow's character says, “The thing with Dickie... It's like the sun is shining on you, and it's wonderful. Then he forgets about you, and then he gets really, really cold.” This line was quoted by Heard, but by definition changing the name to Johnny.
Reality: This is perhaps the most debunked fake news story about the trial. AFP, PolitiFact and FullFact.org, among others, and even the Hinduistan Times denied the claim that the actress stole quotes from movies in her testimony. And all fact-checkers had the opportunity to do this quite easily, because the trial can be watched live and can be rewatched at any time.
For example, AFP, after reviewing the testimony given on May 4 and May 5, found that the sentences highlighted above were not uttered, perhaps the closest to the quotes in the film was when Heard said at one point:
"When I was around Johnny, I felt like the most beautiful person in the world. You know, I felt visible, I felt like a million bucks."
And later he put it like this: "And then he disappears, and then you simply cannot hold him, you cannot contact him."
But it is not true that the actress specifically quoted from movies.
The video can be viewed by clicking here.
After Amber Heard's testimony, many believed that the actress was just pretending to cry and that her tears weren't real, and there were plenty of social media posts mocking Heard's crying (here's an example that already has 6 million likes).
Reality: Snapchat's spokesperson also spoke on the matter, who told the TMZ gossip site that the filter began to be developed six months before the trial, i.e. long before the pictures of the actress were taken at the trial, which then circulated in the press. In other words, Amber Heard did not inspire the Snapchat filter.
The video, which claims that the actor's children have also testified in the case, has more than a million views. In the opening image attached to the video, Depp's son can be seen, with the caption: "You ruined my father" below, and Heard: "It's not my fault".
Reality: Another, relatively easy-to-verify fact: Johnny Depp's children did not testify in court, as can be seen from the recordings made at the trial (and by the way, not a single newspaper reported on this moment). The video's title and opening image falsely suggest that the children were present at the trial, while the 8-and-a-half-minute clip itself simply cuts together the times Depp and Heard talk about the children at the trial.
Newsweek also points out that the opening image is manipulated, it appears as if the background behind Depp's son Jack is the courtroom, but the image was originally taken in 2020 in France and was shared by The Daily Mail.
The barely 13-second video has been viewed nearly 15 million times so far.
Reality: The Ben Nye brand has actually released products they call "bruise kits" and go by the name Bruise Wheels, but they are not shaped like the makeup palette in the photo. The brand does not have a product like the one talked about in the TikTok video, so the statement is false.
Regardless, Amber Heard found herself in an uncomfortable position when one of her lawyers showed off a concealer palette that he claims the actress used to cover bruises on her face caused by Depp. But the brand that makes the palette, Milani, posted on TikTok that the specific product wasn't launched until 2017, a year after Heard filed for divorce.
"Did he literally snort some cocaine on the platform?" says above the video. However, as PolitiFact points out, the excerpt can also be found in a longer video that can be viewed on YouTube, where the actress is seen taking the tissue to blow her nose at an early age (at 12:05) and then a few minutes later, you can see the scene where he picks up the handkerchief again and blows his nose again.
By the way, these few seconds are the most played part of the YouTube video.
According to Politifact, however, there is no evidence that cocaine was on the handkerchief in the meantime and that Heard snorted it. Facebook also warns those who click on the post.
On one of the last days of the trial, Amber Heard herself spoke about the pressure Depp's fans are under. According to the actress, she receives hundreds of death threats every day. "Every single day they harass, humiliate and threaten," he said at the hearing, adding that even his child was threatened with death.
In the meantime, Johnny Depp, even if the lawsuit has not yet won him over, has already won over public opinion (in this regard, we recommend this, this, and this article). A typical example of the kind of news that appears about the actor: after his ex-partner, Kate Moss, also testified at the trial, fans immediately began to speculate whether the actor and the former top model were once again a couple, and what it would be nice if they got together again. It's true, but earlier there was a theory that Depp got together with his lawyer, Camille Vasquez.
In the defamation trial, of course, the jurors and not the public will decide in the end.
Cover photo: BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI / POOL / AFP
