Please note, Airbnb will not cooperate with the French state against single-sex private swimming
Please note, Airbnb will not cooperate with the French state against single-sex private swimming
Published on Monday January 17, 2022 at 12:28 p.m.
© AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE | 2024 | All rights reserved.
- Author(s)
Nathan GALLO, AFP France
In the name of the fight against "Islamist separatism", will the Airbnb platform cooperate with the French state at the risk of stigmatizing the Muslim community, as stated in multiple articles and posts shared several thousand times on Twitter and Facebook? Since January 10, many Internet users have denounced a future collaboration aimed at controlling the rental of properties with swimming pools in order to prevent single-sex private swimming, reserved for women. But both the State and the rental platform denied this assertion, taken from an article in Le Monde published on January 10. The daily also published a correction the same day.
Allowing the State to control whether single-sex swimming takes place in private residences rented on Airbnb in disregard of respect for public freedoms is what many Internet users are denouncing. Several representatives and organizations of the Muslim community have protested against a potential collaboration between the platform and the State intended to “track Muslims”, as stated by The Collective Against Islamophobia in Europe (CCIE). The collective notably launched a call to challenge Airbnb on Twitter in a post shared nearly 150 times since January 11. Marwan Muhammad, the former director of the now dissolved organization Collective Against Islamophobia in France (CCIF), also asked for explanations from the government and Airbnb, notably via a tweet retweeted more than 1,300 times.
The call to challenge Airbnb on Twitter by the Collective against Islamophobia in Europe (screenshot taken on 01/13/2021) (Nathan Gallo)
Several news accounts on Twitter such as Brèves de Presse (retweeted more than 400 times) also relayed the information, as well as pages and sites covering the Muslim community - from Alnas to Al-Kanz. Turkish media, such as the French version of the official Anadolu news agency or the TRT World news channel, also covered the information in articles and videos.
“Off-the-shelf” information from a senior official at the origin of the assertion
So where does this statement come from? The information originally appeared in an article in Le Monde, published on January 10, 2022 and entitled "Fight against 'Islamist separatism': the reinforced arsenal of the State".
In this article on the government's new surveillance tools against "Islamist separatism", the newspaper reports a statement from a senior official who welcomes "future cooperation with Airbnb in order to identify individuals renting properties villas with swimming pools to organize single-sex swimming for women. His name is not mentioned.
But both the Interior Ministry and Airbnb have denied this claim. “No agreement exists or has been envisaged between the Ministry of the Interior and the company Airbnb on the monitoring of its reservations”, underlined on Twitter on January 11 the General Secretariat of the Interministerial Committee for the Prevention of Delinquency and radicalization (SG-CIPDR). Airbnb, for its part, affirmed to AFP and several times on Twitter that it had had "no discussions of this kind with local authorities, and does not intend to initiate this type of collaboration in the future.”
A response from Airbnb to a user on Twitter, January 13, 2022 (screenshot taken on January 13, 2022) (Nathan Gallo)
The article in Le Monde has since been corrected on the evening of January 10 by the editorial staff. The passage in question no longer mentions cooperation, but confirms the comments of the senior official interviewed off the record and saying he was concerned "that individuals are circumventing republican principles by renting villas with swimming pools to organize single-sex swimming for women ". The daily also specifies that “the organization of single-sex private swimming is neither the responsibility of the State nor of the courts”.
The correction from Le Monde, published on January 10 at 11:40 p.m. (screenshot taken on 01/12/2022) (Nathan GALLO)
Following the correction, some Internet users and pages on Facebook, such as Marwan Muhammad and Al-Kanz, also updated their publications, as did the Anadolu press agency, which published an article on Airbnb's denial .
The American platform has indeed highlighted its actions to combat discrimination. “Since 2016, we have removed more than 1.5 million people from Airbnb for refusing to treat third parties without judgment or bias,” explains the group on its site. Since the summer of 2020, Airbnb has also collaborated with the government and the Central Office for the Suppression of Trafficking in Human Beings (OCRTEH), to fight against prostitution, notably through "the development of internal procedures to effectively support police investigations linked to human trafficking.
The “law reinforcing republican principles” came into force at the beginning of January
This controversy comes in a context where the Muslim community considers itself increasingly stigmatized, in the middle of the presidential campaign and facing a government which is fighting against what it calls "Islamist separatism".
Many are particularly concerned about the new law “reinforcing republican principles” adopted on August 24, 2021. While this law has offered new prerogatives to prefectures since January and regulates the subsidizing of associations, the Human Rights League or even Amnesty International criticized a text that could undermine respect for the rights to freedom of association and expression.
In this context, the president of the French Council of Muslim Faith Mohammed Moussaoui called on the candidates for the presidential election to calm the debates and avoid amalgamations, in an article published in Le Monde on January 13. “It is clear that, under the cover of the fight against extremism claiming to be Islam, the speech of some has become almost a call to get rid of Muslims,” he regretted.
